Title: Does what a movie is supposed to do.
Review:
And that is to entertain. I was entertained by this movie, and that's good enough for me, especially with a lot of the terrible stuff being churned out these days.

Is it a bit silly? Yes, and that isn't necessarily a bad thing. The movie doesn't take itself too seriously, and it's meant to be lighthearted and fun. I see nothing wrong with that. The main actors, including Radcliffe and Pitt, deliver what they were intended to, and did it well.

It's been compared to 'Romancing the Stone' (a great movie in itself) and that also is not a bad thing. You can see the similarities if you've seen that movie, and I think that is fine as it's trying to take what made that movie good and use those themes, without being a 'Romancing the Stone 2'.

If you are just looking for a good movie to relax to and spend time with your partner, this is for you.

Title: If you want to waste some time
Review:
Sadly this movie is ridiculous in so many ways. Sandra Bullock's botox/plastic surgery is so obvious and detracts from the already weak movie. Although she is 57 years old, she has maintained her shape, so I suspect she also wants to prove that she doesn't age by pairing herself with a man (Channing Tatum) who is 15 years younger than she is. Her editor's wig is also silly and so obvious. Perhaps I'm being petty, but this all detracted from an already weak plot and movie, which could have and should have been entertaining. Bad Pitt's role was also totally silly and short. Perhaps that's what was planned for this movie - a total over the top spoof. A spoof that just bombs. Again, sadly.

Title: Disappointing - stick wit the trailer

I'm glad I didn't see it in a movie theatre as I had planned. I ended up not even finishing the movie. Why bother with uninspired writing. Ho hum. Dumb.

Title: Bullock, Pitt, Radcliffe, and Tatum make this a worthwhile comedy romp.
Review:
My wife watched this movie a couple of months ago on the plane from Chicago to Houston, she wasn't very impressed. In fact she thought it was a waste of her time.

So tonight I watched it (alone) at home on Amazon streaming and found it to be a totally entertaining movie. It doesn't take itself very seriously at all, and the final scene with Bullock, Pitt, and Tatum in a yoga class, punctuated that sentiment.

The movie is mostly a parody of such movies as "Raiders", in fact the opening scene where there are lots and lots of snakes all over is one parody, they ask "Where did all these snakes come from? Who feeds them?" The thoughts I had when watching that scene in "Raiders" in the giant tomb with all the snakes. I also found it to have elements of "Romancing the Stone" because Bullock plays a romance novelist and Tatum is her cover model. They end up lost in the jungle (filmed in the Dominican Republic).

So in this movie a wealthy treasure hunter (Radcliffe) searches for a mythical treasure on a volcanic island, he needs someone to translate a portion of ancient markings, hoping to provide a clue. When she doesn't go voluntarily she is kidnapped. So most of the movie involves action on the island where they try to escape.

Anyone who goes into viewing this and expecting a serious drama will certainly be disappointed. Viewed for its comedy absurdity, it is nicely entertaining.

Title: Had to turn it off!
Review:
I'm a sucker for a cheesy movie and expected this to be a good example. I love Sandra , so will watch most things she is in. I expected something along the lines of Miss Congeniality. I really wasn't expecting much from this just a cheesy chick flick that you can veg in front of and not have to engage the brain and be mildly entertained. What I saw was truly awful. Like, really really bad, not even Brad could save this. For a film that really had a stellar cast with great acting talent, this was truly awful. I had to turn off after half an hour as I asked myself if I cared about any of the characters or what happened to them or cared about what happened next. After I asked myself that question and got a resounding no! I switched off!!!

Title: A fun popcorn movie
Review:
I wouldn't pay a premium price to see this, but it's funny and fun. Some great laughs, Gotta say, Sandra Bulloch's behind looks pretty fine for a woman in her fifties. Channing Tatum is a good foil for Bulloch's brainy character, although his character's evolution doesn't seem very consistent throughout the movie. Dan Radcliffe makes a convincing villain and Brad Pitt is a very amusing supporting character without stealing the movie. It just goes to show that good actors and a decent plot and writing can make even lightweight fare quite satisfying, for an afternoon matinee, at least. There's a sequel suggested...I'd definitely consider seeing that one.

Title: Couple laughs at best
Review:
What a disappointment this was. The plot itself is fine, romance writer abducted by evil mogul to help find some lost artefact.

Whilst a few people were laughing in the cinema, most were dead quiet. This felt like it was made 10 years ago, or was your average Netflix movie.

It had its moments, a couple laughs from Channing, Brad Pitt also delivered for the short amount of time he was involved, but Sandra Bullock was just awful. You could tell this was merely a pay check and she really did not care about this movie.

Overall, badly written jokes, full of plot holes, and a disappointing supporting cast and performance from Bullock. Definitely save this one for when it arrives on Netflix in 6 months.

Title: Fun idea - poorly executed
Review:
A novelist and a model get dragged into an adventure looking for a hidden treasure.

This is a silly adventure film but it lacks any sense of story-telling so it just feels dull and tedious.

The actors say the words needed to progress the plot but there is no real sense of characterisation or chemistry - just people talking.

Everything is bare minimum.

Even the sets are bad.

We enter the jungle so we get shots of a bunch of trees.

Is the jungle dark and mysterious? Is it filled with swarms of insects or dangerous animals? Is it tranquil and beautiful?

No, its just a bunch of trees that Sandra and Channing can run around so that is enough.

There are some great moments (especially with Brad Pitt) and the main characters have great potential - with snippets of insight.

But on the whole it doesn't feel like anyone cares about this.

I love Sandra Bullock but she doesn't bring any of her talent or energy to this. I didn't buy she was an author, an academic or a widow - she is just there goofing around.

About a quarter of the cast can just be cut along with all their scenes and the film would be better for it.

There are a lot of dad-jokes and obligatory embarrassment gags "oh gosh! I can see your penis" or "oh no! My dress is up my bum!" which is probably funny if you are about ten.

I was really hoping for another Jumanji or Jungle Cruise but instead got a very long made-for-TV movie that is already fading from my memory.

Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Ouch
Review:
Somewhat humorous, very predictable fluff. Not sure what Sandra Bullock was thinking when she made this. Maybe she just wanted something light rather than the heavy drama she'd been doing. The script just seems to strive too hard for witty one liners and comebacks. It may have been better with someone less accomplished than Bullock, since we expect more from her.

Channing Tatum was amusing and certainly nice to look at in his bare-it-all scenes. Daniel Radcliffe was funny, but at times seemed to be acting in a different movie. Storyline is preposterous and all over the place with many elements that make no sense whatsoever.

Title: The Lost Movie
Review:
Oh Geeze. This was truly awful. Let's see, I think I may have chuckled twice? I was hoping for a fun romcom but this was movie was just stupid. Of course, the plot was expected to be silly, but couldn't there have been any truly funny scenes? I can't imagine what Sandra Bullock was thinking when she took on this project. Absolutely no chemistry with Channing Tatum (who really needs to stop shaving his head). Daniel Radcliffe made the movie bearable, but just. Lousy lousy writing. I'm so mad I paid the for the rental and even more that I wasted my time.

The role Brad played was so fantastic and he played it so perfectly. I cannot say enough good things.

Title: Fun and funny! Sometimes a silly movie is super welcome.
Review:
I'm not a fan of comedy films, I like it when the comedy is inserted but it's not the focus of the production, but by irony of fate, some productions with this focus amuse me a lot, like "The Nice Guys", "Crazy, Stupid, Love " and "The Lost City" itself. It's super fun! I went without expectations, and ended up being very surprised!

The biggest hit of this movie is in the performances! The main couple (Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum) are sensational, each one in their own moment of the character, but with a very well developed chemistry, around small "dramatic" lines and a lot of unusual situations, thus generating the comedy. Daniel Radcliffe and Brad Pitt are super good. Emphasizing here that Brad P.'s participation is small, but it's too sensational.

But obviously not just flowers! The film has some problems, I think most of them coming from the script. The progress of the story doesn't seem very natural, it's as if to follow the adventurous story booklet, the text forced some situations so that you can get where you want. Another point is the villain, extremely cartoonish, without many layers, he's just there to get in the way.

In short, it's a fun movie! Anyone who enjoys adventure, comedy and even a hint of romance will definitely enjoy it! Those who don't like it, like me, might be surprised, if you give it the chance and go with an open mind. Fun, uncompromising, no loose ends, well rounded, with a few slips, but that don't compromise the experience as a whole.

Title: Flat, uninspiring chick flick
Review:
This is just a waste of talents. You have Pitt, Bullock, Radcliffe and yet the movie came out pretty dull and unfunny. Channing Tatum is not a good actor and that's why there was absolutely no chemistry between him and the other actors.

The idea of the movie should give them a good opportuntiy to provide exciting adventour movie like Indiana Jones or Romancing the Stone. Well, basically, this is similar to Romancing the Stone but Bullock-Tatum were in no way providing such a duet performance like Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner.

The movie itself is so flat. Half way of the movie, no real excitement, just dull unfunny dialogues and uninspiring comedy.
4 out of 6 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: ugh
Review:
The stars are for Daniel Radcliff and the the cameo from Brad Pitt, the only good parts of the film.

Watch as Sandra Bullock flops around like a human water wiggle and expects us to find it funny when she's mean to nice people and continues to drag the dead carcasses of crude jokes out long, loooooooong after we're tired of them.

A deeply unfunny film, which baffles when you realize the entire plot rests on Sandra Bullock being such a horrible, unhelpful *****, that she refuses to assist a (completely legal and sanctioned by the local government!) archeological dig in her tiny, very niche area of interest, with a spot of translating which literally took her all of 5 minutes.

After being told these priceless discoveries were in danger of being lost forever due to an impending eruption if they could not be found and preserved in time!

I think she's going to have to revoke her professor card for that.

There's a feeling of incredulity that this entire cluster**** mess with multiple deaths and a destroyed temple wouldn't have happened if she'd given less than an hour of time to Daniel at the beginning, and I spent most of the film feeling sorry for his character, since all he wanted was to find this treasure and prove he wasn't crazy to his family.

Title: An unwatchable mess
Review:
I like Bullock and Pitt, of course. The Harry Potter kid is good too, but Tatum is annoying. This seems to be a ripoff of Romancing the Stone, but what that film had was romantic chemistry and humor. This has neither. They should have made RTS with Pitt and Bullock.

The writing is hack. The whole thing is a mess. I was bored out of my mind and I had to fast forward through most of it.

Title: Not so funny comedy
Review:
The tone of this film is not well defined and it is difficult to know if it wants us to take it seriously or not.

There are times where the movie doesn't want us to take it seriously, but there are other parts where it gets very serious and even emotional, so it's hard to know its tone, if it's a ridiculous comedy or an emotional story accompanied by humor, for me it was a little of both, but still the comical didn't make me laugh so much, there are a few jokes that left me laughing for a while but it wasn't for the whole movie, so it felt very short on humor. The story is interesting, and even though it takes several directions, I think it's an easy story to follow, as its characters have decent development and some can be more endearing than others. The romantic situation is predictable despite the circumstances the characters find themselves in, which are different from what we usually see in romantic movies. The performances are decent, but I think Channing Tatum does an outstanding job compared to the other cast, Sandra Bullock has more talent to give a better performance, although this one was not bad. The locations where it was filmed are good, reflecting the difficulty of the journey through the jungle, the editing is not good since there are many scenes that you can tell were cut very suddenly and there are some others where there is action and you can't see it well what's going on.

I think it doesn't work at all as a comedy that doesn't take itself seriously, but if it can give us a story that's a little different from what we're used to seeing in romantic comedies, it still needed more work on the script to be memorable and to be a good comedy, especially with how talented the cast is, which is the best part of the movie.

Title: THE COMEDY WAS ON POINT
Review:
No matter what the other reviews say, I LOVED THIS MOVIE, IT WAS ONE OF THE BEST COMEDY MOVIES I'VE EVER WATCHED. I did lose some interest towards the end of the movie, but other than that this film was so funny and enjoyable to watch.

Title: Doesn't work, in any way
Review:
Not funny, not clever, no chemistry, no interesting storyline. A shame really with a bunch of respectable actors. It's almost like Bullock thought let me produce the most brainless blockbuster just to secure my pension.

Title: The book to be judged by its cover
Review:
As soon as I've seen the trailer of this movie I knew what to expect from it - that it would be a dumb brainless adventure flick but Sandra Bullock, Dan Radcliffe and Brad Pitt bought me up so I watched it. And I have to admit that "don't judge a book by its cover" rule does not apply here whatsoever as this is just a case of judging it for exactly what it is - a piece of shlock.

The screenplay to "The lost city' was written by 4 people and none of them was even slightly funny or innovative with it. Even if I were a ten year old I would have probably not died laughing at some of the scenes, - now I only scowled and rolled my eyes all the time. Sandra is a versatile actress and she can act so I don't get why she agreed to do this humorless "Romancing the stone" rip-off in the first place; her character, Channing's, Daniel's and every other is not just paper-thin - they're sand, you go 'puff' and the whole character vanishes in the air without a trace of interest.

The script in general is lazy writing through and through and at times I felt like most of the dialogues were improvised on the spot and left in the movie for whatever reasons - I just can't see someone with a tiny bit of talent writing those pathetic dialogues passing around from character to character.

Overall I feel like the movie industry rapidly degenerates because I remember some twenty years ago I thoroughly enjoyed the similarly themed "The rundown" with Dwayne Johnson or "National treasure" with Nicolas Cage - those were also dumb, over the top adventure flicks but they've had deeper characters that you cared for and a nice story to stick around for but "The lost city" has neither of those criteria. In fact it doesn't have anything good to say about, I can only vaguely compliment Channing Tatum's feeble attempts at bringing his character some depth but they were mostly left unnoticed behind the huge cringe of the whole movie so please do judge a book by its cover (if you've read many and know your books) and don't waste your precious time.

Title: Fails as a comedy and romance
Review:
Yeah, it tries to be a Romancing the Stone (1984) clone. But it fails at being properly fascinating like Romancing the Stone was. It feels like a cheap lazy copy in comparison. The budget is great, the acting fine, and much of the action is good. The main issue that drags it down is how terrible Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum are as a love interest couple. Not a single scene between them works in any way whatsoever. The main story is fine. A middle-aged author writes romance novels. Her husband is dead and she refuses to leave the house. So of course she ends up on a dangerous adventure. It's cliche and could work, but it doesn't. She's funny 20% of the time in the weird situations the rest of the time she's just acting quirky and it doesn't work as she's a middle-aged woman with a botox face and mediocre comedy skills. Maybe a young woman experiencing similar stuff could sell the role? Channing Tatum is the very stupid model who tries to save her while constantly screwing up. And she doesn't like him as he's stupid. Yeah, that's it. She just doesn't like stupid guys. They don't do anything more with this conflict. Of course they have to be forced together via the plot. It's basically Romancing the Stone with a few rewrites. But Romancing the Stone took a silly idea and made it good by creating a great plot around it DESPITE the concept. Here they fully and lazily rely on forcing silly romance situations and they never feel real or funny as you can see how the writer and director forced the silly scenes to happen. So the romance is utterly dead here and replaced by cringe.

The big positive is the great island setting and the funny Daniel Radcliffe. Daniel Radcliffe actually hits all his comedy marks and makes it funny. The rest are just trying to act silly and the comedy falls flat. So while much of the movie works and the script never becomes bad the overall product is a letdown. It's not really a movie I can recommend. It does the bare minimum of big budget Hollywood production, but as the humor falls flat it's a failed comedy. As the romance falls flat it's a failed romance. And there is not enough action to carry the movie by itself. You'd need to cut out 15 min of romance and another 15 min of silly comedy to make it work. Then you'd have a silly short acceptable movie. As of now it's just way too cringe overall. Many scenes are clearly there to stretch out the movie runtime and totally pointless and boring. They are added in to make it long enough and it's painfully obvious. The movie drags a ton in some scenes which for a comedy is a dead sentence. But it's not completely bad in all aspects. It just feels pointless and has too many boring scenes to be worth it overall.

Title: Good to see Sanj before her hiatus
Review:
Daniel Radcliffe goes off - still trying to shed his wizard's robe.

Bullock and Tatum work but Reynolds probably would've been more suitable only coz Channing seems more quirky, believe it or not, than Bullock.

Brads Pitts is pretty funny in his role. It's the best slow-motion "walk" away from an explosion I've ever seen.

The script was playing it very safe but it's got to appeal to everyone from teens to grandmothers so ... Of course I reflected on having watched Romancing The Stone back in the day. Movies were a much bigger deal back then. I don't know if it was because it was a pandemic movie but I predicted the look of the film. It's Bullock and Tatum in from of CGI backgrounds (very well done, mind you) and stand-ins for the wider location shots. Some of the sets seemed 100% authentic, yes, but nothing beats having the actors on real locations. But, like I said, the pandemic caused heaps of problems for folks wanting to travel.

Sandra Bullock has been the biggest mainstream comedy/drama/all-rounder actress of my adult life. Seeing as she's taking a break, supposedly, it was great to be able to see her on the big screen before she goes.

Title: No. Just no
Review:
I tried to like this movie. The opening scene looked promising, however things quickly went south after that. Extremely generic plot, flat humour, Daniel Radcliffe just does not suit the role he got and he is basically always playing the same character. Sandra Bullock - wasted potential in this movie. Why was Brad Pitt featured so shortly? Another waste.

It is embarrassing to watch this movie, knowing how much money was spent on a truly mediocre product. What a waste.

Title: "Only a fool chooses a horse by its color."
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Title: Horrible waste of time and money, why did they even bother
Review:
OK, so they started weirdly, and went on even more and more cheesy and unpleasant. Managed to wedge in a couple of jokes that may fool the innocent into not running away from the cinema - which only ensures more disappointment later, because this movie is baaad.

Not long ago I'd seen Sandra Bullock explaining how one cannot know if the movie he/she stars in will turn out good or bad. It was an older fragment of a Graham Norton Show, I think. She was talking about that "All about Steve" flop she starred in, which I also remember having the displeasure of partially watching. But now this movie?! Is she sleepwalking and starring in movies? Is she being blackmailed into starring in these horrendous ones? Does she have to do a bad movie, as soon as people managed to forget the latest bad one she was in?

No use detailing why this is so rubbish. Why? Just go see it yourselves, so there can be more of us having bad dreams about it. Yuck... the plot, the interpretation, the costumes, the way they used famous songs, cut short to pay less for them or something... the way they used one famous actor, similarly... the nudity, the cheap jokes... how did they tricked those actors to make fools of themselves?

Do they want to prove from time to time that actors are like empty vessels, nothing without good directing, scripts and the rest of the cast team?

Title: Really boring
Review:
After Brad Pitt is in it, stop watching this pale imitation of Romancing The Stone.

Moderately interesting opening, fairly interesting middle bit, boring and predictable ending.

Bulloch plays Bulloch, Tatum plays a cowardly idiot, Pitt plays the hero, Ratcliffe is ok as the antagonist.

Title: Disturbing Plastic Surgery and Disappointing Ending
Review:
I really wanted to like this movie, and I did enjoy Daniel Radcliffe and the other male leads. The first half of the movie was funny and I enjoyed myself.

But two complaints really impaired my enjoyment. First of all, the movie turned into a mostly serious action movie instead of a satirical take on one, and that wasn't what I was looking for. It also just didn't hold my interest. It also didn't seem to be written as well and the end had a "what was the point" vibe.

Second problem; the plastic surgery!! Oh my goodness, Sandra Bullock's face was so unnatural and distracting, and it hindered her acting abilities due to lack of facial mobility. I would have preferred an older normal looking actress than one who looks plastic and unhappy with herself. It saddened me. It was hard to focus on anything else which brought this rating down.
5 out of 6 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Terribly Disappointing & Flat
Review:
The film is... well, lost. It's flat, poorly scripted, and only contains a few chuckles. Most of the funny parts were given away in the trailer and the moral is incredibly predictable.

Bullock and Tatum give it their best shot to have some screwball-esque chemistry but it's not believable and the supporting cast is actually funnier. Radcliffe (and even Tatum) tries to be charming, but just comes across as formulaic.

It must be much harder to write a good Rom-Com than I thought because despite (what I hope was) a valiant effort by all who were involved, The Lost City just feels lazy and uninspired. It's as if they knew there were major flaws but hoped we as the viewers would be distracted by the shiny view (that view being Tatum's body, the pretty scenery, and literally Bullock's shiny outfit). We deserve better.

Verdict: Don't Watch.

Title: Funniest movie of the year
Review:
We enjoyed it so much! Too much cussing for mom but we laughed and laughed. Best movie by Sandra since PROPOSAL. Bratt spoofs himself. Channing is the anti-hero you root for. Put this on your list for sure!

Title: A Perfect family movie...
Review:
Loretta Sage (Sandra Bullock) is a romance novelist. Her late husband was an archeologist and she based some of her writings on his findings. They were on a mission to find the Crown of Fire when he died.

Her latest book describes the Crown of Fire and billionaire Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Readcliffe) - determined to find this jewel - kidnaps Loretta so she can decipher a tribal language which might lead to the location of the Crown of Fire. The cover model of 20 of her books, Alan (Channing Tatum), hires a CIA operative, Jack Trainer (Brad Pitt), to find her, and he goes along on the rescue mission. They follow her to an island, where Abigail took her.

With a volcano on the island threatening to erupt, time is of the essence and the film therefore is a race against time. I enjoyed the adventure element and the location allowed for some beautiful cinematography. Although the film is a bit slapstick at times, it was otherwise quite funny. There was maybe a bit too much humour for my liking, but this is a comedy after all.

Channing Tatum is in great shape with an awesome body. I couldn't quite place his character, though. Although Alan is the film's romantic lead, he came across as gay more often than not. He even remarked "He loved me", referring to Jack Trainer. And he packs face masks, ointment, and a nail file on a rescue mission! Not to mention him screaming like a girl on several occasions, and slapping the enemy instead of hitting them with his fists...

I love treasure hunt movies and 'The Lost City' was indeed entertaining. I was expecting more for the film's climax, but it was all good still. This is the perfect family movie.

Title: Another Bland Rom-Com
Review:
This film looked WAY funnier and more enjoyable in the trailer. Unfortunately, the trailer lied and wasted two hours on this 'Romancing The Stone' wannabe.

The jokes weren't funny and got stale after five minutes. Tatum and Bullock had zero chemistry. The plot meandered and seemed like it didn't know what it was doing.

I honestly don't care enough about this movie to write a proper bad review for it. It was just... boring and lifeless. A waste of my time, and it'll probably be a waste of yours, too.

Title: SO UN-F×××ING-FUNNY
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: This movie had me rolling on the floor literally!!!!
Review:
At first I thought that this movie was going to be an alright "just to laugh" movie but it turned out to be way more then that. This movie had it all, the acting, the writing, the laughs, and action, like what else could you ask for. This movie was die hard funny for most of the movie and a lot of it was together so there would be whole 15 min sections where I couldn't breathe because I was laughing so much. And this wasn't a laugh then forget about it kinda movie. This was a I'm going to use some of those lines type of movie. It was also very heartfelt in multiple parts, which is something that a lot of rom coms like this nowadays are missing. And even for how short the movie was it had enough time to have a lot of character development all the way through which again lots of new movies are missing and not even rom coms it's all genres of movies that are missing this! So over all just a great and well made movie!!

Title: Basic comedy-adventure film
Review:
The plot of the movie was basic, but kinda interesting and I was definitely gonna watch that movie. The storyline was just nice, nothing innovative (it followed the same concept every adventure-comedy movie does). The characters were very interesting, well-developed, so likeable and really funny. The filming location of the movie was really good, a small tropical island. In my opinion, the most boring part of the film was, the first 20 minutes. Especially, the opening scene wasn't very well executed. Of course, it was a funny movie that had many jokes. Also, it was a very intense movie, full of action filled scenes and they were very well portrayed. It wasn't an unexpected movie, I mean there weren't any plot twists and the ending was expected. Moreover, the casting was really good and the acting was nice, as always. Last but not least, the post credits scenes was really weird and kinda complicated. Anyway, I don't think they're gonna make a sequel, even though it was a nice movie.

Title: Truly amazed these actors signed up for this.
Review:
Two minutes into this film and you know what you're going to get. And what you get is a studio product, the very definition of mediocrity. Despite ripping off the premise from the infinitely superior Romancing The Stone the writing is atrociously unfunny and the direction completely by-the-numbers. As if the director was telling everyone he needed so many shots that day so let's get on and get through the pain of it as efficiently as possible.

I realise Sandra Bullock has had a lot of work done on her face, which is now permanently dour, but she looks embarrassed and bored in almost every scene. Even being carried away from an explosion her lifeless facial muscles are completely expressionless and she is discernibly counting down in her head to the detonation. Channing Tatum has difficulty even just playing himself and is he's clearly bored too, as indeed is Brad Pitt in his cameo, evidently thankful for the brevity of his role (taken as a reciprocal favour to Bullock for her cameo in his movie, Bullet Train). None of them manage to wring any excitement or life out of the terrible script and dialogue and the adventure itself is so utterly boring that not even the lazy vista shots can help.

The people who like this movie are clearly an undemanding generation, who have probably never seen more skilfully crafted examples within this genre such as the aforementioned Romancing The Stone.

Anyway, do yourself a favour and avoid this one. It's genuinely awful and you can easily tell that even the cast thought so too. They certainly don't need this kind of rubbish so why they signed up for this drivel is anyone's guess.

Title: Fun movie to watch...
Review:
Finally got my wife to watch a movie other than Horror. Don't get me wrong, I like horror movies...don't get me wrong, but sometimes I like to watch a movie with a happy ending...like this little gem called Lost City. Kind of reminds me of Romancing the stone. I watched that move a dozen time and I still love it. Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum do a great job in this movie. They have good chemistry and the movie is just fun to watch. I was surprised to see Brad Pitt in this movie, however. His role in it was so limited...it's weird to see him in a film for such a small role. His part had a lot of action in it, though. Anyway! It's a really good movie to watch and you won't be disappointed you had to rent it off of Youtube for 7.99. Peace.

Title: Good fun. Feel good movie
Review:
If you're looking for something deep and meaningful this isn't for you. The story has been told a million times before. And you know how it's going to end.

But.... It's a great ride along the way. Bullock once again proves she's a great comedic actress. Tatum plays the part of the dumb pretty boy well. The chemistry between the two of them is great.

Brad Pitt has a great cameo and delivers a fantastic performance. Da'Vine Joy Randolph hits the mark every time. The weakest link in the ensemble is Daniel Radcliffe who just looks too nice to be a villain.

The whole cinema was laughing and chuckling all the way through at the screening I went to.

So if you want a feel good movie that you can just sit back, relax and enjoy. This is the one.

Title: Jack Trainer!
Review:
Unique and quirky, this film produced genuine laughs. Unfortunately, most of the funny moments were in the trailer. It was cheesy at times, but the performances were fun to watch. Really, I just need a whole movie of Brad Pitt as Jack Trainer. There was too little screen time with his character.

Title: Such a cool and fun movie
Review:
Unpretentious, light hearted and actually funny - which is something I can say about 1 in every 100 comedies, at most. I won't try to rationalize why and how the director makes you care about the characters, but if you have a heart (like this movie), you will. The script is well written, another rarity these days, and the acting is excellent, even when the scripts calls for larger-than-life and exaggerated performances. It just works, pacing is great, soundtrack is spot on, what more could a viewer possibly wish for? This isn't my favorite genre but I'm giving it 10/10 because I think it deserves better than its current rating.

Title: REally Bad Rip OFF
Review:
I was going to rate it at 5, but took off 2 points for the stupid post credits scene. Absurd, insulting and not funny -that scene for sure, but could apply to most of the film as well.

Bad Rip Off? Romancing the Stone of course. This film is the manifestation of so much that is wrong with the movie business these days. Bullock is cute, but in trying to look 35 when she is 55 sort of works, but sort of doesn't. The DIE (Diversity, Inclusion, Equity) casting is painfully obvious and does not do anyone any favours. Black? Check. Asian? Check. Gay? Check. Obese? Check. Yawn... I pay for entertainment, not social justice agendas.

A few good lines, a few good scenes, that sadly stand out as good against a tapestry of boring, plagiarized, trying too hard and failing miserably.

Pitt is classic, but his role and character are insultingly betrayed by the credits scene. Radcliffe is a moustache twirling bad guy who is suitably overplayed. For the rest, give it a big miss.

Title: Bullock and Pitt Having Fun
Review:
Sandra Bullock is the best since Lucille Ball at physical-comedy-shows-personality and she demonstrates it here, but the joy is how great Brad Pitt is at farce, including a bit after the credits roll. The comedy and romance are understated, perhaps too much, and the violence is not to be taken seriously. This is just a couple of great actors having fun for our enjoyment.

I'd happily see this again at home in preference to anything showing at my local mega-theater. We are awash in imperfect movies this year, so this movie stands taller than it might in a more shining era, but a benefit of the deluge is that there are some good movies, such as this one, even in underrepresented niches such as romantic comedy. If you like heroines you can laugh with, you'll probably like this movie.

Title: Fun comedy that picks up the pace as it goes along
Review:
The lost city is a good mix of action, comedy and some 12 rated romance. It was also nice seeing an older woman, Sandra Bullock, in a leading role as well as Daniel Radcliffe in a villainous role. Both quite uncommon in films!

The plot is run of the mill but I enjoyed it regardless and it's rarely a dull film if not a masterpiece. I especially enjoyed the parts with Brad Pitt in and the power struggle / rivalry between his and Channing Tatum's characters. There are a couple of very unexpected moments which is nice for a comedy film that was otherwise quite predictable, which doen't make it a bad film at all but having unpredictable moments adds to the excitement.

I don't remember much about the music which means it at least wasn't noticeably bad but I can't say it was anything special.

7/10: Good fun.

Title: Fun movie.
Review:
Light hearted, fun movie. Entertaining story, lots of action, familiar faces and a good way to forget your troubles for a while. Sometimes, that is exactly what I want, to be transported into a movie and be entertained.

Title: Let's make 'Romancing The Stone' 'Lite'
Review:
In the adventure/romance genre, this film is hugely disappointing. It adds nothing new, and lacks basic elements that are necessary to make such films 'work.' Bullock. Appealing as usual, and an extended cameo by Brad Pitt are the two saving graces, for their fans, though both are failed by a muddled, simplistic storyline and generally unfunny dialogue.

Tatum's man-child demeanor as the protagonist romance novelist (Bullock)'s fellow adventurist-and potential romantic interest, is miscast. Bullock's mega-star presence eclipses his. His super-nice hunky- guy character moons over her, seeming at times as if he's medicated with something that keeps him from displaying emotion. It isn't bad acting- it's emotion-free acting. Bottom-line: the Bullock/Tatum 'chemistry' does not work here. See 'Romancing The Stone' for an example of how this should* have worked. Fan favorite Daniel Radcliffe plays the (far too-mildly) eccentric heavy, pursuing Bullock/Tatum. He seems to try to make the best of the character, but- again- screenplay and direction disappoint.

It's 'just' watchable for fans of the cast.. I suppose.

Title: Light-hearted adventure for the entire family...
Review:
I went to watch the 2022 movie "The Lost City" on a spur of the moment decision, as this is normally not something I would deem worthy the admission of a cinema ticket. But I went to go with my family, and I have to say that the movie was actually more enjoyable than I had initially anticipated.

The storyline in "The Lost City", as written by Oren Uziel, Dana Fox, Adam Nee and Seth Gordon, actually turned out to be a well-written one, and it was a storyline that had lots of different elements to it. "The Lost City" is a good combination of adventure, action and comedy, and it was done in such a way that it was actually rather enjoyable.

Now, I mentioned that this is not something I would normally spend a cinema admission on earlier, and that is because I am by no means a fan of Channing Tatum, and while Sandra Bullock does have a handful of good movies to her name then she is not cinema-worthy for me.

Directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee managed to put together a good and fun adventure movie. I liked the ways that the comedy elements were laced into the storyline, and there was also a good amount of nicely choreographed action.

While Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum are not my first pick of go-to performers, then I will say that they were nicely cast for the movie and they definitely put on good performances on the screen. So thumbs up for the casting. But I have to say that it was Daniel Radcliffe and Brad Pitt that made my day in the movie, they were just brilliant in "The Lost City".

"The Lost City" makes for a good popcorn movie, where you just lean back in the seat, enjoy the snacks and watch the movie for what it is. If you like light-hearted adventure movies, then it is definitely worth a watch. However, I doubt that this is a movie I will ever return a second time.

My rating of "The Lost City" lands on a six out of ten stars.

Title: Would not recommend
Review:
Bad rip off of Romancing the Stone. There was no chemistry between Sandra and Channing. The PR character was not needed. The after-credit scene was like most of the movie, not funny. As much as Sandra is a bit of a one-note actress, she's good at what she does. But she grated a bit here as well. The best thing that this movie did as others had mentioned, is highlight how hard it is to be an actor and make me see Brad Pitt in a different light. I feel he is a bit one-note too. But he shines in this movie. There is something about him that made me want to watch him. He was funny. He made the character interesting. When he and Sandra were together, those scenes were interesting and the chemistry was on point.

Title: Good Lord, why was this made?

Brad Pitt's character is fun, but his presence is so minimal that it doesn't really help the overall feel of the movie. Daniel Radcliffe could have been replaced with a cardboard cutout.

Where did the $75 million budget go? Did the stars eat up the budget?

Title: Weird looking film work
Review:
Weird looking film work. I'm not sure what was going on with it. Maybe it was that I was watching it on someone else's TV, but I don't think so. Backgrounds look like they were filmed elsewhere and inserted via green screen. Some people's skin changes from mottled to smooth and back again during a scene. Wrinkles on foreheads appear and disappear, as though photoshopping is inconsistent. The lighting is really weird too.

Dialog is really bad. Was there a writer, a director? The biggest question is how they managed to get the likes of Sandra Bullock, Brad Pitt and Daniel Radcliffe to do this film. There were signature awkward romantic comedy scenes I expect from Sandra Bullock, but totally devoid of any chemistry or humor, as though the person writing and directing the scenes was just going through the motions.

Title: Granted it's silly
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Funny, Charming and Delightfully Refreshing
Review:
The trailer for The Lost City caught my eye mostly for what wasn't in it. No clues about an existing property it was attached to, no comic book characters or Oscar bait material..... how did it get the green light from the studio? City felt very old fashioned and with some interesting names in the cast, I was intrigued. Starting with the plot and characters, Lost City doesn't rewrite the book on this genre of movie but it avoids too many of the tropes. It's helped along by the fact that it's such an oddity in 2022. I was disarmed by the story's earnestness and straightforward nature. The screenwriters could have wrote a tighter plot but the phrase "good enough" comes to mind. It was never intolerable or grating and while Loretta being a stick in the mud could have been too familiar or Alan being a useless idiot could have been too easy, I found the movie was able to toe the line without being too lazy or cliche. The story and characters get the job done (with the exception of Allison whose jokes consistently elicited no laughs).

Sandra Bullock has been bouncing around, hopping between genres and projects to varying degrees of success. She's a versatile actress but The Lost City feels like a throwback to her days doing movies like The Proposal and Miss Congeniality. Regardless of what you think of those movies, she's one of the few who could pull those roles off consistently and she's more than game here as over-the-hill writer Loretta. She doesn't play it up too hard, she walks a fine line between capably anchoring the movie yet being game to roll with Tatum or whomever she's sharing the screen with. Tatum's re-invention as a comedian has been such a joy to witness. He's got serious comic chops and he has great chemistry with Bullock. The two of them together had me chuckling throughout. Brad Pitt was great in his role, he's on exactly the same wavelength he needs to be and while I knew he was capable of being funny, I was surprised at how deftly he played his character. I always like seeing Daniel Radcliffe pop up in things, he's got a very diverse portfolio of characters and he always seems to be throwing his all into it. He's a lot of fun here, I did have a couple of notes on his character but his performance always had the requisite energy and spirit. Da'Vine Joy Randolph was also a welcome addition, she walks a similar line to Bullock and she never failed to deliver her punchlines in a way that didn't leave a smile on my face.

I could pick this movie apart if I really wanted to. The script could have been stronger, there are extra scenes that don't really gel with the overall narrative, the movie can't make up its mind on how villainous they want Fairfax to be. But despite the flaws, I didn't want to penalize The Lost City too heavily with for its missteps. As I mentioned above, I was taken aback by The Lost City. Not every joke lands, not every narrative decision plays but the movie works more often than it doesn't and it didn't dampen my enthusiasm as the film went along.

The Lost City made for a refreshing viewing experience. The mid-size movie is fading into obscurity and while most of us love the huge tentpoles or the obscure indie fare, I'm glad there's still an audience that's willing to go out for this kind of romp. Bullock and Tatum are on point, the story has enough laughs and heart baked in to keep you interested and there's plenty of fun to be had (it's not completely family friendly as there were some kids in my theatre that witnessed some pretty "adult" jokes). It won't make any top 10 lists but The Lost City adds up to a couple of well spent hours at the theatre. If you're tired of superheroes and weepy dramas, give this a shot and maybe you'll exit the cinema pleasantly surprised like I did.

Title: The Lost City is one of this year's surprises, managing to vary the well-known formulas of the genre in a creative, fun manner.
Review:
If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free thoughts, please follow my blog to read my full review :)

"The Lost City is one of this year's surprises, managing to vary the well-known formulas of the genre in a creative, fun manner.

By making the most of the hilarious, chemistry-filled performances from Channing Tatum and Sandra Bullock, the Nee brothers explore the distinct protagonists, Alan and Loretta, beyond what's expected in generic rom-coms, developing their misleading appearances through a genuinely exciting adventure.

Unfortunately, only the main character arcs receive this level of care, as everything secondary lacks the same interesting treatment and better entertainment. Still, a thematically rich ending compensates for any cliches.

Definitely, a family viewing party recommendation."

Rating: B.

Title: Ignore the low rating it's fairly good !!!
Review:
The lost city is a 2022 action comedy adventure film starring Channing Tatum, Sandra bullock, Brad Pitt and Daniel Radcliffe. When I saw the trailers I thought it looked really good and wanted to go to cinema to see it but never got a chance. After reading the mixed reviews I kind of got put off but I thought what the hell I'm going to watch it. The movie was better than expected I really enjoyed it Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum are as good as ever and never seem to disappoint. Very talented. The storyline silently different to some other films which was good ( a little predictable in places) but certainly keeps you hooked. The acting was superb was funny in places. It was a good film more comedy than action but definitely worth the watch. Ignore the negative reviews and watch it for yourself it certainly is entertaining to watch. If you are a fan of Channing Tatum and Sandra bullock then you will love this. A good light hearted action comedy to watch. Get the popcorn out and watch the film. Currently streaming on paramount plus.

Title: A fun and harmless comedy romp
Review:
While far from a laugh riot or a product that in anyway, shape or form tries to rewrite the romantic comedy adventure rulebook that has long been a staple of such well liked films as Romancing the Stone, Aaron and Adam Nee's The Lost City is a consistently enjoyable and pleasing Hollywood ride that coaxes along off the chemistry between its leading duo to produce a now rare type of studio film that never tries too hard while embracing what it is and what its end goal entails.

Following the exploits of Sandra Bullock's widowed novelist Loretta Sage and her cover model Alan Caprison (played by a once-more dimwitted Channing Tatum) as the two mismatched adults find themselves on an exotic jungle covered island that Daniel Radcliffe's resentful billionaire Abigail Fairfax has partially claimed in order to find some fabled lost treasure, City surprises little in any of its narrative beats or formulaic delivery but like comfort food the Nee's film provides exactly what has been prescribed in any of the films trailers or marketing campaigns, allowing the film to be one of the more successful high-profile comedies of recent memory.

Wasting little time on anything that could be considered attempts at providing anything deeper than getting easy laughs from Bullock's double wedgies or Tatum's battle against blood sucking leeches, City understands what it is and who its for as Bullock brings her Miss Congeniality comedic skills and Tatum brings his 21 Jump Street smarts to the film that gives its duo plenty of material too work with, even if their both overshadowed by a scene-stealing Brad Pitt as mysterious son of a weatherman Jack Trainer.

Bouncing off one another with ease and clear enjoyment, Bullock and Tatum make for perfect partners in crime as they battle Fairfax's incompetent goons, the dangerous jungle and inappropriate footwear and their interplay with one another goes a long way to cover over the films cracks that are constantly appearing in the rather daft story and adventure components and the fact the film suffers from genuinely killer set pieces that the best of Hollywood comedies have alongside the filler chuckles.

These cracks and missteps of the film matter rather little in the overall proceedings of the film and while City is a film you're unlikely to be quoting to your friends or remembering months down the line, City reminds us all that sometimes middle tier films such as this that exist merely for easy wins and mindless entertainment have a place in our movie going lives as much as any other products we consume.

Final Say -

Getting a boost from its on song leads and easy going charm, The Lost City isn't groundbreaking stuff buts its a perfectly fun and harmless comedic adventure that is sure to entertain the masses.

3 CrossFit certifications out of 5

For more reviews check out Jordan and Eddie (The Movie Guys)

Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Enjoyable
Review: Trying to revive a Romancing The Stone (1984), Jewel of the Nile (1985) vibe, Sandra Bullock, Tatum O'Neal, along with a surprise lengthy cameo part for Brad Pitt, this comedy romance has all the typical trappings though at times, there are a few uneasy scenes of drama and violence. Daniel Radcliff from Harry Potter gets to play bad guy. Tatum's character at the beginning is almost offensively and perhaps unintentionally two-dimensional and off-putting. This romance, comedy, adventure movie though adds two nice elements to the genre. First, there is an increasing element of seriousness and a touching measure of maturation or at least revelation of the humanizing of Tatum's character and an added depth for the typical relational component of romance in this movie. Second, the anticlimax of the movie is somehow more refreshing and connective to today's audience that has been bombarded with the more outrageous. Whether the inclusion of the final scene that comes after the major ending credits was tacked on by the producers to allow for a better audience focus-group reaction is at present unknown. Overall, this rom-com is a nice contribution to the genre.

No this is worse then bad. Nothing works, all is overdone, and just Bratt Pit's performance, way too short, gives some smile at the movie, although it is one eye, in the land of the blind.

I gave up and put it off, my wife, even if she hated it too, continue watching..... But boy, she should be rewarded for tis.

Title: Entertaining at least
Review:
So I finally got around to watching this film after putting it off for some time. It's basically one of those movies you watch when you don't know what else to put on or wanna kill some time. At least that was my reason. Definitely not making any headlines or awards but has an A-list set of actors with a mediocre script that doesn't do them justice. We've all seen that one before right? I will say Brad Pitt was probably the best part of the whole movie and stole the show as he usually does in the little screen time he was given. The rest of the film was pretty much your average cookie cutter stuff you usually see in rom-coms, with a woke feminist take sprinkled in. As other reviewers have said it tries too hard to be funny at times and ruins the authenticity. But enough critiques, If you want something light-hearted that will make you laugh then this is the movie for you. Personally seeing it once was enough for me.

Title: The Lost City
Review:
This potential comedic adventure proved to be a dull bore. To its credit, the film's leads have genuine chemistry throughout and have some funny scenes together. There are also some over the top antics and cameos that are downright hilarious. However the film falters agonizingly through an overdone and predictable plot as well as a being painfully boring. It was clear throughout that the film desperately needed an outlandish performance from its cast or something to truly stick out in a pool of forgettable comedies, but this film takes the blandest route in its execution. It didn't help that the characters didn't seem too interested in the adventure occurring until the end, which should tell the audience about how much care they should give to the film overall. Despite the films obvious flaws and bland execution though, it wasn't completely unwatchable with some redeeming qualities. However, in the end it made for a forgettable comedy that will just fall into an unfortunate fold.

Title: A lacklustre Romancing The Stone clone.
Review:
Joan Wilder should sue: romance novelist Loretta Sage (Sandra Bullock) has totally stolen her schtick, the archaeologist turned best-selling writer becoming involved in the search for a long-lost treasure hidden in a jungle, unexpectedly finding love along the way.

The Lost City rips off Romancing the Stone something rotten, but hasn't the charm or wit of the 1984 Kathleen Turner/Michael Douglas adventure. At 54, Bullock is way too old for this kind of material (Turner was 30 when she made RTS), making Channing Tatum seem too young for his role as cover model Alan, the man Loretta falls for. The age gap mightn't have mattered so much if the pair had some kind of on-screen chemistry, but they are unable to replicate the Turner/Douglas magic, their supposedly funny banter more irritating than amusing. Meanwhile, Daniel Radcliffe as villain Abigail Fairfax is just terrible - how does this guy continue to have an acting career?

Only Brad Pitt impresses with his cameo, playing a rugged Special Ops agent hired to rescue kidnapped Loretta: he embraces the stupidity of his role and looks like he's having a lot of fun parodying the macho stereotype. Shame he wasn't in the film more.

As far as the action is concerned, it's mediocrity all the way, the set-pieces lacking in originality, imagination and excitement.

3.5/10, begrudgingly rounded up to 4 for IMDb.

Title: Very stupid and very crowd-pleasing
Review:
I mean, technically just about every aspect of this movie is pretty mediocre. It has an extremely formulaic plot, very standard visual direction, a crushingly boring villain (despite Daniel Radcliffe's solid performance), and a bland, underdeveloped romance arc.

But something about it makes it very difficult to dislike, and that something is the actors.

Really, every single performance is remarkably spot-on, and constantly charismatic and entertaining. The humorous beats are diverse and fast-paced, and I was never bored, despite rolling my eyes occasionally.

For the most part, The Lost City is an adventure romp that knows exactly what it is, and is completely okay being just that. And for that reason, I'm completely okay with it too.

Title: Seen it all before, great to see it all again
Review:
Great fun. The twist is the central male character.

Otherwise its Romancing the Stone, Uncharted, Indiana Jones, and any number of other similar exploring movies.

Sandra Bullock is Sandra Bullock.

Channing Tatum is a surprise.

Brad Pitt is brilliant.

Daniel Radcliffe continues going about his business playing interesting roles in whatever takes his fancy and always impressing.

Theres not much original here in the story. But its really enjoyable. Funny and well done.

Title: Excellent Well Written Comedy
Review:
Not really sure why my review for this film kept being rejected or just not going through. I have evaluated this 3 times now and all 3 times were very positive reviews.

I am not a fan of American comedies, but this one was a pleasant surprise. What I like about this movie is that it is witty and a lot of the short minor jokes were creative and unexpected. Many of the jokes are not direct, but uses insinuation and and implication, which is really just genius in my opinion

The overall plot is formulaic, but that is expected in comedy especially when they're often parodies. However, my only issue with this film is the editing which bloated the run time. I think it could be trimmed cleaner by cutting a lot of the slow talking parts which don't really add anything to be plot other than trying to build the relationship between the two protagonists.

Overall, a good 7/10.

Review:

Title: Romancing The Seashells
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Very interesting and Just like Indiana Jones
Review: "The Lost City" isn't an especially unique film; its premise draws on "Romancing the Stone" and countless other adventure movies. Its punchlines are recognizable from a distance as the volcano dominating the remote island where most of the story takes place. This is a movie you can get a clear sense of from its opening moments, every beat clearly telegraphed. There is, however, a significant amount of comfort and delight in all this familiarity. Directors and co-writers Adam and Aaron Nee understand exactly what their audience wants-much like a good romance novelist might-and deliver an undeniably charming (and refreshingly IP-free) romantic romp. This is a movie you watch in the theater, with popcorn, then again and again on streaming, with a glass of wine. Loretta Sage (Sandra Bullock) is a burnt-out romance writer whose grief after the loss of her husband threatens to derail her career. Her disdain for her books is only matched by her dislike of their cover model, Alan (Channing Tatum), a seemingly dim beefcake who indulges her readers at signing events. After an event promoting her latest book, Loretta is abducted by explorer/rich guy Abigail (it's a gender-neutral name, apparently) Fairfax, played by Daniel Radcliffe. "The Lost City" may get dinged by some for being formulaic and silly, but it does many things well that are notable. It's bright, both visually and atmospherically. It's an original story, told by filmmakers who get what kind of movie this is. Most importantly, its central relationship displays a real understanding of the emotional sensitivity and vulnerability that make romance attractive as a genre. Ultimately, "The Lost City" is interested in hitting viewers' expectations head on. It does so on a level that may seem obvious, but is done with an amount of care that's sure to hold up to repeat viewings.

Title: Terrific (but silly) entertainment in a 'Romancing The Stone' stylee
Review:
Similar to 1984's "Romancing The Stone" (and it's 1985 sequel "The Jewel Of The Nile") adventure rom-com "The Lost City" has reclusive romance novelist Sandra Bullock (on fine form) whisked off on a remote treasure-hunting jungle adventure, in her case with 'dumb' cover-model Channing Tatum, helped by the likes of Brad Pitt, Da'Vine Joy Randolph & Oscar Nuñez - while evading baddie Daniel Radcliffe (surprisingly perfect in the role). It's great fun and the fine & likeable cast appeared to enjoy making it, which comes across via directors Aaron & Adam Nee (who also co-wrote it with Oren Uzil & Dana Fox). It is undeniably silly mush, and yet is still terrific entertainment.

Title: Intentionally cheesy romcom parody that turned out awesome
Review:
Great casting and witty dialogue between characters felt pretty natural. It has a good balance between making fun of cheesy romcoms and steamy romance novels while still being one at the end. The action and adventure theme pulled it all together creatively and made it much more entertaining than just a standalone love story with no other objectives.

Didn't feel as forced or cause any eye rolling like traditional films of this genre for me, because of the bit of parody element they worked in. The parts that I generally find cringey were made intentionally awkward with the character dynamics and it just worked much better.

Personally being in the entertainment field, it showed the dichotomy that a lot of people in the field go through. The character you're playing versus your true self. The more often or longer you play a character, you can sacrifice your own identity. Seeing this play out in a comical way between a writer and the cover models' real identities versus their on stage roles for interviews which were the polar opposites was a pretty accurate depiction of how working in the field can be and the expectations of always being "on character" with the fans expectations.

For mindless mild fun, I recommend it.

Title: Great Escapist fun
Review:
My Review- The Lost City - My Rating 7/10

I enjoyed The Lost City it's slapstick escapist fun in the spirit of the 1980's movies like Romancing the Stone and Indiana Jones but not quite as good.

However it has a great cast and enough funny "Shtick" moments to make it a good Saturday matinee style movie in the true sense of the word . I think it would be lost on television as it's an old fashioned cinema comedy adventure movie in the tradition going right back to The Keystone Cops or Jungle Jim and Tarzan era.

It's unpretentious well produced , yes at times silly but I'd rather see ten films like The Lost City than one like a certain pretentious Viking box office disaster that's screening at the moment .

The plot is simple with similarities to Romancing the Stone (1984) but it's not a remake in my opinion as there's enough difference's in the plot to make it stand on its own. We do have a jaded disillusioned romance novelist Loretta Sage /Angela played by Sandra Bulloch who through dramatic circumstances after her latest book launch organised by her literary agent Beth Hadden in a fun performance from Da'Vine Joy Randolph.

Loretta is kidnapped by Abigail Fairfax an eccentric bratty billionaire (Daniel Ratcliffe) who explains his name as gender neutral while trying to get Loretta to reveal the whereabouts of the "Crown of Fire", a priceless treasure.

Loretta's handsome cover model Alan or Dash played by Channing Tatum as his book fans know him sees the kidnapping and pursues her captors aided by rugged ex combat fighter Jack Trainer(Brad Pitt).

Dash or Allan appears all brawn and no brain but has a heart of gold and Loretta who at first is indifferent to him soon warms to his clunky buffness.

That's enough plot line from me the movie was filmed in the Dominican Republic and only wrapped up on October 2021 principle photography began in March 2021 and there is talk of a sequel already.

The Lost City is proof that a relatively modest budget of $64-74million dollars can do well at the Box Office as it's already earned Worldwide $130.6 million.

Don't expect the techno brilliance of Dune or Star Wars but if you like an uncomplicated unpretentious adventure escape with some really good performances especially from Channing Tatum Sandra Bulloch and Daniel Ratcliffe as the villain of the piece I recommend The Lost City.
