Title: Better Left Lost - The Lost City
Review:
Brad Pitt picked up a payday in this film, but realy doesn't add much to the film. Sandra Bullock makes a decent straight man for his lame jokes. I guess I should mention Chaning Tatum, but there really no reason to. The acting? Is barely believable and the silly plot and script were probably written on the car ride into work on a cell phone. This film is not exactly rocket science, nor is it the greatest treasure hunt ever told. As a matter of fact, it is pretty ho-hum from the beginning of the film onward. No one should be forced to fork over ten bucks for this average fare when there are so many other superior options. Don't bother.

Title: Adventure Comedy does its job...but no more than that
Review:
This film wants to be Romancing the Stone but its not on that level. It's not even The Jewel Of The Nile. It is a solid film though without an original idea in it. Its a fun film in a Sunday Afternoon turn your brain off sort of way. Bullock and Tatum give solid performances, Daniel Radcliffe is good. The scene stealer is Brad Pitt in an all too brief appearance. Action scenes are passable but nothing that truly sticks in the memory. The big gripe i have with the film is at times the humour is just too silly, borderline annoying. Plot is paint by numbers, however the reveal of the treasure is a nice surprise. Everything seems set up for a sequel, and if that does happen i would be interested to see what direction they take these characters.

Title: First 25 minutes were pretty darn funny and promising...then...
Review:
The movie falls apart after an opening half hour. I suppose that it was just too hard to keep the momentum going after that point given the 'meh' script and formulaic ideas in play.

At first, the cast had excellent chemistry. Things were really building steam, but after Brad Pitt's character briefly appeared and left the film it was all downhill.

4/10 - Highly entertaining for a while then devolves into an utter lack of creativity.

For a better film of this type, visit (or revisit) "Romancing the Stone" or even "Jewel of the Nile."

Title: Great mix of adventure, comedy, and romance
Review:
It is good to see movies putting fun as a priority. There was a scene that had the theater laughing as hard as you can possibly laugh. There is comedy, romance, adventure, and there is nice story about feeling like a fraud, but then learning something about yourself and wrong assumptions you make about others.

Title: Negative 0 stars times infinity
Review:
This movie is an example of how everting that comes out of Hollywood these days is such schlock bad remake of a better idea. Romancing the Stone is a legendary film about a romance writer who goes on a real life adventure that could fit into one of her stories and meets the man of her dreams.

This film is an intentional cheap knock off. It's badly written, acted, and the sets look awful and the makeup is bad and the cinematography are appalling. Sandra Bullock is about as likable as sitting bare butt on a porcupine, and Channing Tatum fails on every conceivable level.

I hated this film from the moment it started and I wish I had just turned it off. I hope these filmmakers never work again.

Review:

A real mistake using Tatum Channing as a "lead" (seriously?!) Sandra Bullock deserved better, you know, as someone who could equal a comedic role?! Title: A decent romance adventure comedy
Review:
Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum make a fine duo in this farcical comedy which is a more contemporary take on the plot from Romancing the Stone (1984). Daniel Radcliffe actually makes a fantastic villain in this movie with some really funny dialogue.

Overall, the movie has plenty of funny bits despite having some jokes that fall flat and the movie occasionally gets dull during the first half before it starts to pick up during the second half. The movie benefits from some really good casting decisions and Bullock's usual deadpan delivery feels balanced against Tatum and Daniel Radcliffe's over-the-top quirky personas. Bullock portrays a jungle romance writer who's lost all passion for writing romance books but when she gets entangled in a jungle adventure of her own, she regains her lust for writing as well as romance. Despite the majority of the film containing over-the-top comedy, there are some serious moments where Bullock and Tatum's characters are fleshed out. Overall, there's a fair amount of drama mixed in with the film's comedy.

Reportedly, this is going to be Bullock's last film for a while as she's planning to take an extended break from acting in Hollywood so I really recommend this film if you're a fan of Sandra Bullock and rom-coms in general.

Title: Great Fun From Start To Finish!
Review:
The Lost City

It was great fun!

A grieving and somewhat accidental best selling author, Sandra Bullock, goes on a life changing adventure, with her novel's dashing cover model, Channing Tatum and regains her mojo.

This was a light and fluffy romcom expertly played by the two leads, you got exactly what was on the tin, it was genuinely funny and I laughed out loud throughout.

The chemistry and comedy between these two worked in spades, and I know I shouldn't but Sandra Bullock must have the best plastic surgeon in Hollywood, looking 37 when actually 57, it really is remarkable, when the close up shots were merciless.

For shear entertainment, and I could tell everyone around me loved this movie, I'm giving it a firm 7 outta 10, meaning such fun!

Title: Enjoyable most of the time.
Review:
I'd rate this somewhere between a 6 and a 7.

The first half of the movie is hilarious and I'm not sure how they got away with a pg-13 rating.

Second half of the movie they tried to focus on the plot more and it was sort of "meh".

Overall, it's worth seeing, I laughed a ton but the overall plot and trying to put in romance and serious moments in the second half sort of fell flat.

Title: Hilarious
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

I was cry laughing during this entire movie. I don't get the bad reviews at all. The whole entire cast is fanatic and has so much chemistry. A great story. I haven't seen one like this in a while. A better romancing then stone.

Title: Mediocre
Review:
I'd not classify this film as bad, but there are alot of slow bits that feel like they're dragging and a lot of weak writing especially the awful narrative humour where they're just pointing out the obvious in silly ways.

It's decent, but the fact is I don't see it as a real comedy as it's doubtful you'd want to see it again.

Sandra is 58! I mean she looks unreal fair play!

CT was alright, but he's played the Handsome idiot to death at this point.

Brads cameo was great.

I feel sorry for Radcliffe, Harry Potter was huge but he's grown into such an awful actor, everything I see him in he's atrocious, I genuinely believe it's that potter love that gets him gigs. He is one of the worst villains I've ever seen in a movie.

Title: Consistently funny.
Review:
Good romantic adventures are very hard to make. The Lost City works, remaining funny right from the opening moments until the post-credits coda.

All three of the stars are convincing, and there's plenty of chemistry between the two leads. Brad Pitt's extended cameo is flat-out hilarious, and it neatly sets up a contrast to Channing Tatum's deliberately pared-back tone. The writing is modern but not forcedly woke.

Everyone involved deserves credit for taking on a difficult genre without resorting to self-deprecation and glum navel gazing.

Plenty to enjoy for both genders, young(ish) and old.

Title: Love it!
Review:

Other than that this movie gives you everything you need, bullock and Tatum are on top form as expected they bounce off each other. Glad to see Tatum starring as I read he replaced Ryan Reynolds (love Reynolds) but he does more than enough movies. Definitely get your selves down to the cinema for this one, it's worth it.

Title: Does what it says on the tin
Review:
To be mad at this film is like being mad at a microwave meal, expecting it to taste like restaurant quality. So I'm giving this a generous 7, simply because there's nothing bad to say about this film.

It's exactly what you should expect.

High budget, good acting, easy to watch and enjoyable. With a few things thrown in, like Brad Pitts role which I hadn't expected.

If you're watching this for something new/ original, then you've come to the wrong place.

This came out around the same time as Unchartered and it's very similar. The only difference is you can actually complain about Unchartered and the lost opportunity it had to be something punchy, well-written and original.

Title: Flat jokes and uninventive story
Review:
What's most preposterous about the movie, it starts with a main character complaining how the narrative she creates doesn't make logical sense, and then the movie goes at length to defy logic in the scenery, situations and narrative.

There are some bright moments here and there, though they quickly sink into the general puddle of half-hearted jokes, dull villains and generic predictable story.

A disappointment.

Title: The proposal 2.0 on drus
Review:
Just if a maniac wrote a satire out of it. I enjoyed every bit of it, it's entertaining and fun, but just a guilty pleasure. Is good for entertaining, but don't expect much art out of it.

The story might be clicheed, but I find the evolution of the characters interesting. Is a cross over Nim's Island with Sandra's The proposal, full of jokes and exaggeration.

A film to watch with the girls while sipping wine, or to watch by yourself when you put on makeup and stay home alone. So, definitely, a film for women in their 30's or older.

The only thing that was a bit off was the ending, and maybe the ultimate message. It was supposed to be 'if you aren't happy with what you have is because you didn't realize what was in front of yourself', but I find it a bit tasteless how they conveyed that ending with all the grievance the main character was thorugh...

Title: Wow a lot of negative reviews
Review:
Peter Debruge of Variety said, "The result can feel a little rickety in places, but the Nee brothers - who share screenplay credit with Oren Uziel and Dana Fox - have punched it up with off-color jokes, looped over moments when the characters' mouths are off-camera. In this and myriad other ways, The Lost City proves they do in fact make 'em like they used to." Writing for Rolling Stone, David Fear said "The movie itself is trying to excavate a long-lost genre: the big-budget action-adventure movie-star rom-com. It wants to be a modern Romancing the Stone so badly you can almost see the flop-sweat dripping down the screen..

This is the the way cinema works. I remember the return of Jedi and that film was just fun not this film. This is art.

Title: Flesh and blood cartoons
Review:
The moment one reads about a recluse novelist any thought about originality goes flying out of the window. Kathleen Turner from Romancing the Stone and Jodie Foster from Nim's Island pop immediately to mind. So I knew I was walking into a cliche from the very start. The only question was, how are they going to breath life into it. Well, it was a team effort but they did breath life into a whole series of cliche. Or, using a more appropriate term in this case - a set of cartoons from the recluse novelist to her dim witted cover model who wants her to take him seriously. And then her overbearing literary agent; the megalomaniac millionaire with the big inferiority complex; and the list goes on. Almost everyone on screen is a walking talking cartoon of a cinematic and literary cliche. And still it does work.

Recently I spoke on these pages a lot about well written roles. Well, here we had well written cliche but a superb cast headed by Sandra Bullock Channing Tatum, both of whom have already shown the ability to laugh at their own image and a surprising comic performance from Daniel Radcliffe whose acting prowess grows in leaps and bounds. All of them together, playing one of the others, make this collection of cliche work. I spoke a long while ago about Rowan Atkinson's ability of making a cartoon character human enough for us to care for him as Johnny English. Here we got a whole series of cartoons becoming real flesh and blood humans on screen - just enough for us to bond with them and care for them.

Title: Some parts work, others don't
Review:
The dialouge in this film isn't great, but the actors enhance the material. Especially Brad Pitt and Daniel Radcliffe, who are much better than what the film calls for.

Pitt and Bullock have great chemistry, in the few short times he is in the film, and I found myself astounded that they have somehow never worked together before. Considering they are film stars from the same era I found that quite surprising, and found myself wishing they'd work together again.

The Pitt and Bullock chemistry actually kind of takes away the chemistry from Tatum and Bullock, thought I have to say they do have chemistry also, just not as much as she does with Pitt. Some parts of the film also just were not really that funny, and I could have done without them.

Title: Didn't laugh one time
Review:
Update: I did finish watching this movie. Still hadn't laughed once-not even on the inside. Unless you pay me a decent amount of money, I have no desire to ever watch this movie again.

This movie tries too hard to be funny. I was looking forward to seeing it.

I subscribed to Paramount+ so my kids could see Sonic 2 and was excited that this movie was included. I am halfway through it and have no desire to see anymore. Not one scene is funny-they are clearly trying too hard. So disappointed. Don't even bother wasting your time...or do and you will agree.

Brad Pitt did bring something entertaining, but still not enough to bring any laughs.

Title: Charming - with charismatic leads
Review:
Like most folks, I barely gave THE LOST CITY any notice when it came and went in movie theaters earlier in 2022. This Sandra Bullock/Channing Tatum vehicle looked derivative from earlier films (most notably 1984's ROMANCING THE STONE with Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner) and it blew in and out of theaters with hardly a notice. But...sitting on an airplane...I ran across this flick and thought I'd give it a go.

And...I'm glad I did! For THE LOST CITY is a fun, charming film with 2 charismatic lead actors that you will want to go on this adventure with.

Written by Oren Uziel, Dana Fox and Adam Nee and Directed by Adam and Aaron Nee, THE LOST CITY tells the tale of Romance Novel Writer Loretta Sage (Bullock) who gets caught up in a treasure hunt when a crazed Mega-Millionaire (played with a spry twinkle in his eye by Harry Potter himself, Daniel Radcliffe) kidnaps Loretta for she had written something in her latest novel that he thinks is a clue to find the titular LOST CITY. Coming to her rescue? Her clue-less Fabio-like Cover Model (played with charming density by Channing Tatum). What could possibly go wrong?

With that sort of premise, the rest of the story is fairly predictable and pedestrian, so the weight of the entertainment value of this film falls squarely on the shoulders of the charm, charisma and chemistry of the 2 leads - and the Direction of the Nee's.

And...I'm surprised (and happy) to state that these all come through with flying colors making THE LOST CITY a pretty enjoyable romp.

Let's start with Bullock and Tatum. They are really looking like they are enjoying themselves - and each other. Bullock is no stranger to playing emotionally repressed intellectuals and Tatum is no stranger to playing dumb lugs...and they both embrace these stereotypes and had fun brining these two to life. Add to this the aforementioned performance of Radcliffe as the comedic villain and an extended cameo from a very recognizable "A-List" performer - and the charm and charisma meter in this film is off the hook.

The Nees, then, play to the strengths of these performers and move the film quickly from set piece to set piece, wisely only slowing down the action to let these performers play. The Directors show a light touch to this piece - and the audience is rewarded by this.

Not the type of movie that will cause focus groups to sit around and discuss it after, but if you are looking for a fun romp, summer action/comedy flick to sit on the couch some summer afternoon/evening with a bowl of popcorn and your favorite beverage, look no further than THE LOST CITY.

Letter Grade: A-

8 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

Title: Lost the plot
Review:
There are over one thousand reviews, so no-one will read this, which is a pity because I really want people to know how insultingly bad is this movie.

I don't mind light-hearted fluff movies. Tune out. Get those Beta waves humming. Sleep soundly.

I don't know the motivations of the decision-makers who green light such drivel. Tax purposes perhaps? And surely the actors are experienced enough to know poor writing and bad plots... why did they agree to participate? It's not location because mostly it was shot in a studio, and a badly designed one at that.

Elsewhere in these reviews it was suggested it's a throwback to yesteryear. Hope and Crosby road movies? Zany adventures? Whatever, it fails to the point of insulting the viewers.

Title: A Lot of Fun
Review:
It is a ridiculous, upbeat, laugh out loud romantic comedy. If you go in wanting to have a good time, you will. If you are expecting something believable at all, you will be sorely disappointed but if you have seen a single trailer or even a movie poster, you shouldnt have those expectations. I love the way Sandra Bullock makes ordinary situations relatably funny, like high stools. They are impossible to get on without looking stupid. Channing Tattum does a great job at trying to be the charming hero. Some of his lines are hiliarious and if you arent paying attention you will miss them entirely. So sit back and just enjoy the comedy for what it is meant to be.

Title: Not Indiana Jones or even close
Review:
With such high profile cast members, I thought this would be a good watch but I was disappointed. I found the acting weak, especially from Tatum. I didn't warm to his character, despite his heroics. In all I found it a very bland, forgettable film.

Daniel Radcliffe played a major part of the story but he wasn't on screen that much. Perhaps that was part of the problem - we're too used to seeing him in the lead role. Sandra Bullock came across as a stronger character and I wish I could walk in her "mountain trekking" boots!

The dialogue was hard to follow at times and I didn't understand some of it. I wouldn't recommend it to adults but perhaps young teenagers may like this film as it has a bit of slapstick action, mild violence and some mild peril.

Not to disrespect the actors as they've all previously played great roles but I won't recommend this film or will watch it again.

Title: Mummies are Human
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Funny...
Review:
"The Lost City" is an Action - Comedy movie in which we watch a romance novelist being kidnapped while her cover model tries to save her. They both find themselves into a jungle adventure and they have to try to work as a team if they want to survive.

I found this movie very funny and the plot was simple but also interesting enough for this kind of movie. The interpretations of both Sandra Bullock who played as Loretta Sage and Channing Tatum who played as Alan were hilarious and very good. Another interpretation that has to be mentioned was Brad Pitt's who played as Jack Trainer. Lastly, I have to say that "The Lost City" is a nice comedy movie to spend your time with and I recommend you to watch it because I am sure it will make you laugh and have a great time.

Title: Harmless fun movie to watch on an airplane flight
Review:
I watched this yesterday on a flight from Madrid to Toronto. And of all the movies I watched this was the one I enjoyed the most. Fun and funny. Yes, we've seen this kind of thing before but I don't care.

What did surprise me was Channing Tatum playing someone against type and boy was he good. All I could think of was him on Bear Grylls' National Geographic show where he took part in every rock climbing/diving/outdoor adventure Bear threw at him with gusto and relish. And aplomb! Channing was excited about it all, not even remotely scared like most of Bear's other guests. So seeing him play someone so inept and inexperienced at outdoor adventure was very funny.

And the leech scene - so good to see a man being naked in a movie for once and not the woman.

Title: Uncharted - meets Artemis Fowl - meets Eat Pray Love
Review:
* * * ...Overall #TheLostCity gives Uncharted - meets Artemis Fowl - meets Eat, Pray, Love.

The film is cute and adventurous, but it's a pretty safe film that I don't see as something worthy of spending a theater coin on in my opinion, nor rushing to see.

Highlight: First, Daniel Radcliffe was fun to watch as a villain. I also just love how effortless Sandra Bullock's comedic delivery is in this film. Additionally, the film moves quite well to keep up engagement.

Could've Been Better: Though I enjoyed Bullock's delivery, I think more thought could've been had regarding her character-her as a writer was "aight," but I personally feel it wasn't the best character choice for her. I think her as an uppity, entitled actress or the book model with Tatum as the writer could've been interesting (and the story of course being focused on the book model in that context).

And speaking of Tatum, his character also needed a little more time at the brainstorming table. I grew to adore him as the film progressed, but I wasn't 100% sold on him in the beginning.

Sandra Bullock is suited for the role she plays; but having an evil Harry Potter harass her just does not work. I thought I was watching John Cena as Sandra's co-star only to be told it was Tatum Channing. Either way, the two clicked. It's a fun romantic romp, but don't watch it with someone who is overly critical of what is and isn't possible when it comes to the make up of live volcanoes.

Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Another treasure hunt
Review:
The simple story about a writer and a male model getting involved in an exotic adventure didn't have many surprises if you saw other adventure comedies before. It feels a bit like an episode from "Relic Hunter" with 100 times the budget, but not necessarily better ideas. The count of funny scenes against unfunny scenes is at best 50/50. The movie was okay to watch once but doesn't shout for repeated viewings.

The actors are mostly good. Sandra Bullock is slightly older than me and still doing action movies in a tight suit - hats off to her. Channing Tatum does not have a good chemistry with her. Daniel Radcliffe was better than I expected, a good parody of a Bond villain with big money and gadgets. Da'Vine Joy Randolph as the writer's agent, never giving up the search for her, was a good choice as well. Brad Pitt steals the show in the (too) few scenes he's in.

Title: Let's go on a funny adventure with a comedy duo made for it!
Review:
For an original comedy adventure, it sure feels like a Romancing the Stone remix! A recluse writer takes her adventures into the real world after being kidnapped by Harry Radcliffe himself Daniel Radcliffe/Harry Potter)! There's even a musical sound track that sounds suspiciously familiar to the Harry Potterverse!

The interesting role reversal works fabulously, though the "damsel in distress" is given a great retribution, being a male and all! The layered characters enhance their roles and lift the premise of the film, slightly.

A nice change for Radcliffe, though not for Hollywood-bad guys-with-foreign-accents (and, Yes, British is foreign for Yanks!). The paper thin plot is given fluff with the great comedic timing of the leads. Pitt's cameo beats his Deadpool one by a fraction!

A nice change of pace for many of the stars, and a welcome breath of fresh, island air for viewers! A no-brainer worth the view!

Title: "I'm Certified CPR, I'm Certified CrossFit, I Have Snacks."
Review:
It would be easy to say that The Lost City is exactly what one would expect, but it's more accurate to say that it's exactly what one would expect minus a little of everything. The film is conceived as a remake/rip-off of Romancing the Stone but the people in charge never bothered to develop the script past this first conceit.

The film is extraordinarily lazy and rehashed, checking off narrative boxes and filmed in the obligatorily flat, unconvincing monotone of contemporary cinema. It's a stunning return for sentimental, schmaltzy romcoms after the release Marry Me just a month ago. Is it possible the dam is just beginning to burst? Is it possible some of them will be funny?

The film follows romance novelist Loretta Sage as she's kidnapped and taken to a remote island by billionaire Abigail Fairfax, who seeks a magnificent ancient treasure. Hot on their trail is Sage's cover model Alan, out to prove he's more than just a pretty face. Along the way, the two learn about the peril and pleasures of love, professional gratification, and self-esteem.

This film is bland. Everything is weirdly sterilized and glossy, starting with the script. The above bit about not developing the script past the initial premise was not a joke. There are several promising moments in The Lost City which begin to be setup but are immediately abandoned halfway through. The only consistent source of attempted humor is the glibness of the cast, who are uniformly aloof. The only bold choice The Lost City makes is bringing a rough draft into production.

The direction is equally lazy and bare. Most of the visual landscape is flat and uninteresting, despite the film being shot almost entirely on location in the Dominican Republic. Why directors Aaron and Adam Nee decided to aim for a synthesized, glamorous veneer for a deadly jungle is anyone's guess. Smart money's on studio mandates of course, but whatever the case, the decision doesn't work. Sage and Alan's trek through the jungle looks like a comfortable camping trip, and hardly any of the cast seem to be physically exerting in the slightest. For all its faults, Romancing the Stone didn't completely ignore the "action" in action/romcom.

The cast can't come close to saving the material, but at least it looks like they're having fun. Every performer is nestled deep within their comfort zone: Sandra Bullock as a frustrated but fierce author trying to turn the tables on her captor, Channing Tatum as a meatheaded lunk trying to prove himself as a capable, responsible adult, Brad Pitt as a hunky but enigmatic savior, Daniel Radcliffe as a psychopathic but blandly polite spoiled punk, and Da'Vine Joy Randolph as a sassy, exasperated editor. They all play into the glib, spiceless material.

There's just not much to anything here. The action is lifeless and obligatory, the structure is hopelessly rote, and the few jokes consistently fall flat. The Lost City is as shallow as a kiddie pool, crassly recycling tropes and characters from other, better films and hoping no one's the wiser. It's weird to even see this type of movie in the theater. Non-vulgar romcoms have been dead for the better part of a decade, so one would think Nees and company would at least put a little effort into the resurgence. One would be wrong. See it if it's your chosen genre, but don't expect anything fresh or innovative; The Lost City picks up right where Anna Faris and Katherine Heigl left off. Abysmal.

Title: More to a film than it's trailer.
Review:
A thrilling adventure full of exhilarating action, passionate and fiery romance and deep, emotional acting. The plot is passable, the setting is well used and the cast work well together, although the villain could have been more eccentric.

Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: You'd be better off watching "Romancing The Stone"
Review:
The opening scene reminded me of "Romancing The Stone" with Kathleen Turner and Michael Douglas, and as such, I couldn't help but compare "City" to "Stone" although this film. My verdict is that "Romancing The Stone" is funnier, better acted, and a just all-around better movie.
4 out of 6 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: Fun, enjoyable movie!
Review:
Ok, so of course it's not academy award material! But these reviews are why nobody risks making comedy flicks anymore. If you go into it expecting a masterpiece, than yes, you will be sorely disappointed. But if you are just looking for some laughs and a good time?? The Lost City does not disappoint! Great humor, great cast, great acting, absolute beautiful scenes at times, and an interesting (however cliche that it may be) premise to boot. A film that keeps you wanting more. The character development started out strong and falters a little bit on the second half. They could have developed the chemistry a little more, but it was solid and enjoyable. This film deserves a high rating to make up for the haters. This definitely deserves higher than a 6.1 on IMDB and is much better than the typical cheesy rom-coms they come out with these days. Let's stop being so harsh and critical of comedy movies! They are not SUPPOSED to be anything of epic proportions but just a couple hours of fun and giggles. Why does everything have to be so serious and deep? We are a culture to worried about offending people.

Title: Just watch the trailer and save 2 hours of your life
Review:
Recap: Four very good actors. One script apparently written by a focus group. A bundle of unfunny jokes. One not-so-bright and chronically shirtless Tatum. A bit of woke nonsense, a Brad Pitt appearance and gratuitous buttcheeks.

Not sure who this movie is made for. Possibly women, or who ever likes seeing Tatum's shirt fall off every 2 minutes. Although, that might also be a way to distract from the lack of jokes. The dialogue tries to show the characters' vulnerable and romantic sides, but I have a hard time believing even the biggest romantic would have any emotional reaction to their verbal and physical exchanges, other than pure cringe.

Brad Pitt is good in his short appearance, and there are definitely funny moments in the movie.

Unfortunately, they all appear in the trailer.

It's not a disaster, it's just not good.

I suggest Romancing the Stone, or any of the classic Indiana Jones movies if you're into romantic adventure/archeology flicks.

Or "Spy" with Melissa McCarthy if you feel like a good laugh.

Title: A good film to watch if you want something not especially deep but fun.
Review:
My summary might sound pejorative, but I am not saying anything negative when I say that "The Lost City" is a good film to watch if you just want something not particularly deep but fun. It fits the bill as a good date movie as well.

Loretta Sage (Sandra Bullock) is a successful romance writer whose best days are behind her. Following her husband's death, she's been in a five year funk and she has become, essentially, a hermit. However, her newest book is about to debut and her publicist wants her to attend a readers' convention...and she unexpectedly gets sucked into a plot by an evil man (Daniel Radcliff). He kidnaps her and two men (Brad Pitt and Channing Tatum) come to her rescue. What's next? See the film.

The film is fun...period. It's enjoyable and undemanding. My only complaints are that the big finale seems to happen too easily and Brad Pitt's character's final scene didn't make any sense at all. Still, it's engaging and worth seeing.

Title: Cute Film
Review:
With all the stress from work and the crazy out in the world this movie was a nice breath of fresh air. Besides the fact that I love all of the cast it was fun and entertaining. Me and my son laughed and enjoyed the movie. Glad we went and saw it tonight.

Title: You can do worse
Review:
A lightweight romantic comedy adventure romp with an exotic setting, THE LOST CITY is essentially an exercise in box-ticking but it does succeed in what it does, at least to a degree. It's a little more fun than UNCHARTED but it doesn't have very interesting action sequences and Sandra Bullock simply isn't very good as the lead, but then I've always thought that. The surprise here is Channing Tatum who is actually pretty funny as the male bimbo, although the scene stealer is Brad Pitt who has far too little screen time. Daniel Radcliffe I didn't really enjoy all that much and the second half does drag, but you can do worse.

Title: A very likeable movie
Review:
While not perfect by any stretch, The Lost City manages to put a dedcent comedy, a decent rom-com, and a decent adventure film all into one sleek 90-minute package.

Probably not going to be anyones favorite film, but feels like a prime contendor for "oh yea- that was a really fun movie, we should watch it" status in 3-4 years.

Everyone commits to their bit and play off of each other well. Even if Channing's character kind of silently morphs over the course of the story in a way that feels less like character growth and more like the writers favored the plot over the character, but that's a minor complaint.

Overall, strong movie that manages to add up to more than the sum of it's parts.

Title: Sweeter After Difficulty? Nah
Review:
I had high hopes for this film conjuring memorable images of the successful Indiana Jones movies. Boy, was I wrong. It tries to be both a funny movie and an action movie. It doesn't do well in both departments.

Thanks to Brad Pitt for the well-executed action sequences and the dry humor. But Da'Vine Joy Randolph tries to be hilarious but she comes off as campy bordering on inane. The same could be said of Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum's dialogue.

The word that Loretta Page (Bullock's character) uses is schlock. I hate to think of the movie in that way but maybe it is.

It's a regrettable waste of well-known and talented actors. I would like to say "sweeter after difficulty" but the movie is not this.

The saving factor is the beautiful island scenery. It is probably an island in the Atlantic perhaps somewhere off the coast of Ecuador. Could it be Isla de la Plata or Isla Lobos de Terra?

Title: Not a bad watch
Review: Feels weird watching a jungle adventure movie without Dwayne Johnson in it. Anyway, I must say I was sleepy heading into this so I may not have watched it in the best of moods. So since the only other jungle adventure film released around the same time was Uncharted I'm going to compare them and say this was slightly better but I don't it was great. Brad Pitt was probably the best thing that happened but his character only showed up for a few minutes during the movie (and post credit) so that's a little missed opportunity. Once again it's riddled with clichés but after so many films already made in the genre I guess it's hard to find something original that someone hasn't already thought about. There's the adventure side of it and the romance side of it, both were not so great, you got the typical well read, smarter character in Sandra bullock then Channing Tatum playing the good looking guy that everyone assumes is only as smart as bait but actually has more to him; and then you have the typical adventurer who's kidnapped by a rich evil man who's using her to uncover the treasure's location but is eventually saved. Both the adventure and romcom side of the movie are cliche. There are other elements added to it to give it a more unique feel but none of them deliver enough to make this an above average adventure movie. Most of the jokes didn't land but that could be due to my current drowsy state, still I don't think that changed much. It's worth a watch and something for the whole family but it's nothing special; if you do want a capering adventure film to watch, Jungle Cruise is the only recent one in memory that I enjoyed enough to recommend, that surprised me, this didn't. I am late to the party to watch The Cost City and thought I was missing out on something good and it turns out I wasn't really.

Title: Back on the Big Screen
Review:
I've mentioned before I'm not a big "chick flick" rom com kinda gal by nature. In terms of romance novels, pfft even less so (the few I've read I've done so as comedies through and through). However, I am a big Sandra Bullock fan, have been for ages, and couldn't pass up the opportunity to see my girl back up on the big screen where she belongs. Yes, I've enjoyed seeing her tear it up the last few years in various streaming endeavors (personally I don't buy into her whole Netflix is the only reason she still has a career thing) but.. anywho, Bullock + Big Screen = 4evr for me!

Moving on.

In The Lost City (2022) Bullock plays a reclusive, broken-hearted romance novelist that gets kidnaped during a book tour and swept up in a jungle adventure with her cover model Channing Tatum. TLC is part Raiders of the Lost Ark, Romancing the Stone, and Baywatch to name a few all mixed together with an over-the-top sense of self-awareness and a banging soundtrack. Yep, there will be seat dancing.

In short, The Lost City is good stupid fun.

While not as hilarious as The Proposal or endearing as While You Were Sleeping, The Lost City is funny, sweet, and charming in its own right. I snickered, giggled, and laughed-out-loud start to finish. Thoroughly enjoyed the characters, Tatum's plays the clueless but loveable idiot brilliantly. Daniel Radcliffe's unhinged, billionaire baddie is pure over-the-top fun. Da'Vine Joy Randolph's put upon, stressed out, BFF delights. And then there's Brad Pitt's Jack Trainer. OMG, I can't even with this one. The proverbial cherry on top is of course Bullock's doing what she does best. That special blend of sweetness, awkwardness, sarcasm, charm, and je ne sais quoi, *chef's kiss*.

The Lost City is a solid, throwback rom-com, action adventure that's comforting and nostalgic in its familiarity, has enough twists and surprises to keep it fresh and engaging, and offers up an entertaining movie experience. Be it at the theater now or watching at home later, The Lost City is a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours.

As always, your heads up not to bolt at the start of the credits, there's a bonus scene that's sure to bring a smile to your face and tops off the film wonderfully.

The Lost City is a 7.5.

Seriously.. Do you even call that an adventure? We have seen way better jungle adventure movies in the 90s.

Title: We Need Something New ...
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: The Lost City
Review:
6/10 - I'm kind of living for Daniel Radcliffe's trend of villain roles and Sandra Bullock is as fabulous as ever, but I was disappointed by the lack of good laughs in this mash-up of Uncharted and The Proposal.

Title: Entertaining because of Bullock and Tatum. But forgettable.
Review:
When I saw the trailer for this film I knew what it would be. My expectations were that it would be funny and feather light but it is usually the type of film that Sandra Bullock specializes in. And with that said it met those expectations. I was entertained and enjoyed it but it is so thin that I pretty much forgot it minutes after it ended. Chanum Tatum has also created a self-depracating persona which is very funny. The story if you want to call it that is a mash up of Romancing The Stone, Indiana Jones and every other Sandra Bullock romantic comedy before it. Romance novelist is kidnapped by a rich guy who wants to find a priceless object that he thinks she could help him find. Period. That's it. In between there is the typical banter, some of funny between the romantic leads. The film is self aware how ridiculous it is and just let's the leads charm carry the film

Entertaining but forgettable.

Grade: C+

Title: A Solid Adventure
Review:
"The Lost City" is an interesting take on the classic treasure hunting story, as it presents itself as more of a freewheeling jaunt than a suspense-driven tomb crawler. While some moments of expected peril still persist, the film as a whole goes out of its way to assume a more subdued approach that fits with the characters and narrative.

The plot overall is concise and imaginative, though the climactic moments could have been stronger had a more serious outlook been utilized: an example of this would be the direction that was taken for the main antagonist. While their repercussions are negligible and vague, a more fitting demise that could have stemmed from their blind arrogance and drive for notoriety would have been more memorable.

The humor throughout the film acts as a good counterweight for the somber tones introduced off and on in the main character's arch, and it lands decently overall. Minus a few gratuitous moments that could have been cut, most of the comedic output meshes well with the action and storyline.

One point of dissonance that unfortunately cropped up several times involved the poor build up and execution of moments dealing with the fate of a reoccurring side character. Twice, when two different supporting characters seemingly met their end, the story presented the scenes so abruptly that they felt jarring in contrast to what came before and after - A few wisecracks one moment and a visceral gunshot immediately after - While both of these scenes could have stood out positively and led to satisfying conclusions, they ultimately felt bizarly rushed.

In summery, "The Lost City" mostly achieves what it sets out to accomplish. It's a lighthearted adventure that stumbles at times, but holds its viewer's focus through clever plot, fun characters, and a heartwarming through-line of timeless love. While not the shiniest of cinematic gems, it remains a solid experience for anyone looking for a new adventure.

Title: Just plain Lost!
Review:
I was reading a review of Uncharted where someone said how bad it was and how Lost City was a much better film. Sorry. Uncharted may have been a C-, but this movies is a complete F. It's not funny, suspenseful or entertaining.

The movie was downright boring and I am going to assume the beautiful people are the only thing anyone loved about this movie. Sandar B may be pushing 60, but there is no doubt she has more beauty than 99.9 percent of women on the planet. Channing Tatum acts like an ignorant idiot so often that I'm starting to believe he is actually being himself and Harry Potter should sit on his own city of gold because the sorting hat should have told him that he'll never appear in another successful film with a hat or wand.

There is no redemption for the plot, the characters and again, unless eye candy is your bag, you are going to be disappointed. Worst movie I have seen in some time.

Title: A little gem of a film
Review:
Casting was perfect!

Sandy, Channing, Da'Vine, Daniel and the rest of the cast and crew, a big thank you from a bunch of us!

It's been a while since my friends and I had such a good time in a movie theatre, the entire audience laughed to tears more than once.

Because of the trailer I though that The Lost City would be walking a fine line of being a rip-off of Romancing the stone but in a way it turned out to be an homage to the entire rom-com genre. Wouldn't mind a sequel.

More than a solid 8/10.

Title: Great villains make great movies
Review:
Why so many really low ratings? Did this politically offend someone? Seems like a good silly comedy to me!

Plenty of good things about it. Lots said about that so I won't re-hash comedy, chemistry, etc. Not everything is perfect, a few secondary characters could have been fleshed out better, have long periods in between checking in.

But most of all, Daniel Radcliffe is perfect. I mean as an actor sure, but the character especially. Too many movies don't have a villain, and too many comedies make us rely on a serious villain with maybe one funny characteristic. Here, he's legit bad and... also ridiculous is exactly the same way everyone else is. He's perfect, so serves as a foil, and a threat, for the whole film.

Title: Disturbing
Review: It was raining, everything told us not to go, but we still went to see the movie. Once we arrived, the theater was closed due to power outage. We should have turned home, but decided to give it a chance and drove to another theater. At the parking lot I realized that we forgot to leave our beach chairs at home and my husband almost drove back, but I convinced him that nobody will break our windows. We should have just went home at this point. But no..we ended up staying and watching a movie. There were 4 sketchballs at the theater that really looked like they were up to no good. One of them whistled at me while starring at my backpack. We should have turned back and went home. At the theater a group of basic girls were laughing at each of Pitt's move. Actually no, they were laughing at any scene that supposed to be funny according to the screen writes. I was even wondering if they placed those girls in the audience just to show others how you should behave while watching a masterpiece. Anyways, the movie wasn't funny, not entertaining. However, there's one positive thing I learned today: if the universe clearly tells you not to do something I really should listen next time.

Title: Underrated Movie That Includes Invaluable Unconditional Love, Authenticity, Hilarious Scenes & Profound Wisdom
Review:
I read that this will be Sandra Bullock's last movie, which to me is a Divine Dichotomy of both sad news and great news.

It's sad because I've been fully enJOYing movies that she stars in, since they're usually great combo package deals of integrated Mind/Heart stories, that include various, interesting aspects that are highly beneficial for humanity and beyond.

However COMMA it's great news that she's leaving the energizer bunny on CRACK, SUPER BUSY Hollywood lifestyle, since she (and like others) deserve a more relaxing, free-spirited, peaceful, and joyful life.

She (and like others) has done MORE THAN ENOUGH to gift humanity with soul-igniting, deeply heartfelt, encouraging, uplifting, empowering, inspiring, and (individual and Collective) Consciousness expanding entertainment.

I trust that Sandra (and like others) is becoming more awake (as Soul & Spirit within), is becoming more aware, and is tuning into unconditionally loving more and more ultimately NEUTRAL aspects of her WHOLE self (physical self)/Self (Divine Self); hence, why she has chosen to gift herself much more FREEDOM.

Thank you Sandra, Tatum, and the rest of the team for co-creating a memorable movie.

Continue SHINING BRIGHT no matter: what neutral aspects you choose to freely Be at any given moment, where you are and what you do.

And always REMEMBER that it's your AUTHENTIC, Full Presence-your WHOLE self/Self, FEELING state/core vibrational frequency-that matters most.

EnJOY many present and pleasant moments of now. 😘💖💓💕

Title: Bullock + Tatum = Gold

A great cameo from Brad Pitt helps but it is the chemistry between Bullock & Tatum that decides whether the movie lives or dies and it delivers on all fronts. Special mention to Da'Vine Joy Randolph who is wonderful as Sandra Bullock's agent.

Title: Cute and Entertaining
Review:
This was a silly, cute movie that I had really no expectations when starting it. It entertained me and made me giggle from time to time. Sandra is adorable as always, maybe a little too skinny in this movie IMO. Channing played the dingy hot guy, which could have had a bit more depth tbh. There's been a lot of dumbing men down in movies lately and I am not a fan, but this is a silly movie and not meant to be a drama. Brad Pitt did really good, but was only in the movie for 2 seconds. The storyline was pretty rushed but the set looked beautiful. Daniel Radcliffe played the villain well, they didn't write him too well, but again this is meant to be a silly movie. Overall I watched it once and could maybe watch it again when bored at work.

Title: The Lost City
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: The Lost City
Review:
Successful and bored adventure writer Bullock is kidnapped by bad guy Radcliffe to help him find a hidden treasure within the legendary ancient city, he has just found. Her book cover model, Tatum, who has adopted his sexy, tough guy character rather too eagerly goes in search of her.

Old fashioned, undemanding adventure comedy fun with very little to dislike. Bullock and Tatum have good chemistry, Radcliffe is terrific as the Bond like villain, Brad Pitt has a fun cameo, the jokes work and the action sequences are strong. I could have lived without the current American comedic penchant for leads to waffle very fast over the top of each other about complete rubbish, but this didn't distract from an otherwise fun and quite charming movie.

Title: Original film
Review:
Beg you, throw away any adventure or animation movie you have seen and watch this movie with a new perspective, then you will realize that it is a masterpiece. I think that these two directors are trying to make jokes that sometimes become repetitive. Using it may damage the effect. I saw a movie. It was a bit of fun and very engaging for me. Although the film is at a lower level of special effects compared to films with big budgets, it uses visual effects to the highest extent. Very elegantly, for example, the part that shows the waterfall... we feel like we are seeing and feeling the waterfall up close. This movie has a script and this is important. Something that we don't see in many movies like this. I can only say that it's a good and accurate movie, it's exciting.

A very beautiful, artistic and magnificent film at the same time simple and unpretentious. This movie entertains you with cinema and teaches you the meaning of cinema without using technological and intellectual tricks. Everything in the movie becomes a character, even the colors, even the clothes. Everything I can say about this movie is still not enough. Although the design of the film is minimalistic, it is very beautiful. It was even better than beauty and the beast

I haven't seen a movie in a long time that I was so directly affected by it.

Title: Lovely
Review:
Ignore the serious critics. Took me out of myself for a couple of hours. * genuine laugh out loud moments throughout * gratuitous Channing Tatum torso and buttock close-ups * plenty of action in a stunning jungle location * Sandra looking amazing for her age (and retaining flawless full-make up through rivers, caves, mountains and baths) and * a Brad Pitt tough guy/hero cameo.

What's not to like?

Same feelgood vibes as a good Indiana Jones on Boxing Day with the family.

For those whom like to dis this movie, get over it. It is classic romance novel! It has humour, action, adventure and fun. I love this movie. It was everything I was expecting from a romance novel point of view. Sorry there wasn't enough blowing up of things.. lol.

Title: 4 Writers For This?!
Review:
Seemed to be going for the broadest audience possible, like a movie created by artificial intelligence; a bit of comedy, a bit of action, a bit of adventure, a bit of romance but not particularly successful at any of it. Anyone who has rated this movie highly has incredibly limited expectations for a move. Will hopefully disappear without a trace within a couple of years.

Incredibly implausible premise, I wouldn't even call it entertaining. I'm sure you are supposed to just go along for the ride but there's surprisingly little happening for a 2 hour movie.

Channing Tatum's manchild schtick was incredibly irritating. Sandra Bullock tries to make the most of her character but succumbs to attempts at physical comedy.

It would be great if Hollywood made an effort in future but I'm sure they won't given all the money this movie made.

Title: fun fluff, often very funny
Review:
When I read about this movie it sounded like the wonderful Romancing the Stone so in spite of the iffy reviews I decided that would be worth seeing. And it was!

In the movie Sandra Bullock is a romance novelist mourning the loss of her husband and Channing Tatum is a guy who's become famous as the cover model for her books. After she is kidnapped by the cheerful psychopath Daniel Radcliffe she finds herself searching for treasure on a mysterious Island while Tatum tries to rescue her with the hilarious assistance of an ultimate alpha male Brad Pitt.

Things go wrong and there's a lot of running around.

Pitt, Radcliffe, and Tatum are all excellent but Sandra Bullock shockingly doesn't seem to quite manage the character. She does a good job as a depressed rather angry woman but seems unable to transition into the predictable romantic part. It feels as though she believed, like a lot of us, that she could act a comedy romance in her sleep, decided to try it, and found she couldn't after all.

Still, while not perfect this is tremendous fun and I recommend it if you like light adventure comedies. I almost gave this an 8 and probably would have Bullock had been up to snuff.

Title: It took five writers for this!
Review: If Romancing the Stone and Raiders of the Lost Ark had not been made, I'm not sure that the writers of this would have come up with a script. I suppose, since some of it is so obvious, there might have been some thought of playing off of those two for fun, but it does not work. I did laugh once early on, though I can't remember why the very next day and there is absolutely no realistic drama, thrills or suspense at any point, if any were intended. Hard to tell. Read here that Ryan Reynolds was sought for the male lead. That was a loss for us, though perhaps a gain for him. To be kind, I'll just say that Tatum displays a great body which seems to be his sole contribution, though also to be kind, the role is terribly written. Bullock also displays, with more (ridiculous) clothing, that she too is in great shape, but she is back in her generic comic mode and if you haven't tired of this schtick yet, perhaps you will like her. She does have comic talent, but she too needs a script that is not embarassing. Brad Pitt makes a cameo and is by far the best thing about this film. The less said about the usually reliable Daniel Radcliffe the better. The ending is positively skin-crawlingly awful.

Title: It's not a treasure trove of laughs, but it's amusing
Review:
The Lost City isn't a treasure trove of laughs, but it kept me amused for the duration of the story. Channing Tatum is enjoyable as the clueless cover model, Alan, and Brad Pitt's role as Jack Trainer is definitely a highlight. However, the normally comical Sandra Bullock felt like a little more restrained in her performance as Loretta Sage, and I wanted a little more from Daniel Radcliffe. The plot of isn't overly original, but there were a few parts that surprised me. Even though this isn't going to have a lasting legacy, The Lost City worth a watch if you're looking for a lighthearted adventure flick.
1 out of 4 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: A somewhat funny, cringy mess that misses the mark.
Review:
This movie tries to a lot more than it actually is. It's a largely nonsensical mess that has so, so many cringy lines and terrible references to other movies. The cast performs well under what is obviously a strained script and a ludicrous plot. The jokes and one liners are a hit or miss, and most often they're a miss. The Lost City cannot be considered as a particularly good comedy. It is enjoyable, sure. But is it worth the effort of going to the cinema and watching it? Probably not.

Title: Gets everything right that Red Notice got wrong
Review:
It doesn't insult your intelligence.


It doesn't have an annoying character that says stupid jokes that are completely out of place.


The actors don't just act as themselves (except Channing Tatum). Sandra Bullock and Daniel Radcliffe give off charming performances.










Red Notice was aggravating to watch even though it was meant to be entertaining. But The Lost City succeeds and is actually watchable because it avoids making the same mistakes that Red Notice made. Good job, TLC.

Title: Not a family movie to watch with your young ones
Review:
Too much weird adult jokes or humors. Its like when a few good jokes are good, they kept trying to keep it going and that spoilt it. Some good sudden incidents that makes you laugh, but there is this attempt to try and blend a classic advernture story with today's twisted city life world that just does not work. Does not have any good mystery to to it. Also too much adult rated scenes. Felt like wasted our time. Better to have watched a rerun of any classic old adventure movie.

Title: This movie had a lot of moving parts to keep up with.
Review:
To start off the Actors were Phenomenal, I couldn't stop laughing and enjoying the action and adventure that always lurked just around the corner every 5 minutes of this movie except for the romantic parts.

So where did this go wrong? There was so much scientific information, as the story of the books was actually real and that is where they lost the audience because there wasn't that much information about this Island. We were only given the information bits and peace's along the way so we can piece it together later on. The cover model should have stayed as a cover model, Like Chris Farley (Tommy Boy) Wishing to be something more than he is couldn't be possible, and only accepting the fact that he is a cover model would have been funnier and acceptable. Instead, they made the scenes very complicated and redundant over his character being something more than a Cover model and more like he has a soul, Then here comes the back story, storytelling which was "BORING". I really enjoyed this movie despite my negative comment because, in the end, this is someone's rendition of a work of art and just "Sh%^ing "on it is counter-intuitive. Thank you for this art and thank you for this awesome movie.

Title: I loved this even though...
Review:
Some people are not giving it the best review. Why? What is not to love when you have Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum and Brad Pitt involved. It is meant to be silly and off the wall. This is what makes it so perfect. We needed a movie like this to make us laugh. We've come out of a dark and dreary time so we need to lighten up a bit. We don't need movies that make sense or are dramatic by design. We need fun and humor. All of the supporting actors were great and managed to capture the essence of the storyline. I've seen this movie three times now and watch it when I need to have a good laugh.

For those of us that have a sense of humor, we got it!

Title: Actually much better than I thought it would be.
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.
