Title: Bad pacing makes for an oddly quiet movie considering the genre
Review:
Most of these blockbusters treat their audience like morons and use music to force feed jokes and pacing. But this one has the exact opposite of a problem. Moments that seem to be communicating a joke have zero SFX, visual or musical punctuation and it makes for a bizarrely paced movie.

For an example of one of these moments, take a look at the moment where Channing Tatum early on in the film falls off a stage in front of a crowd. No music, no nothing. Just really weird silence that tells us almost nothing.

Oddly enough, it's something I've noticed in other Sandra Bullock films. 🤔

Title: Nothing could save this flick.
Review:
Sandra is almost 60, trying to play like when she was younger, with a younger actor. Tatum is no Brad Pitt, as one can see when Brad's cameos arrive, he sparkles...lights up the screen, the other actors...not so much. Preachy Rom-com, wished it had been more uplifting in dialogue without the need to use tacky language to encourage teenagers into the theaters. Sad really.

Hollywood has forgotten how romance and comedy are written.

Title: A great and much needed comedy
Review:
A combination I never knew I needed, a good comedy, very necessary for these times. They succeeded with combining a nice adventure, comedy, romance, action. It's fun, enjoyable, really good produced, great acted, witty, smart, with satire and nice suprinses. The trailer and promotion did not ruin anything, I'm glad I watched it at the cinema, it was much more fun. I was not dissapointed at all, laughed a lot and it exceeded my expectations.

Yes, it may seem silly at times or even predictable, but it still surprises you. It reminds me of the good comedies I grew up with, but it's so actual and qualitative at the same time.

The cast is great and should continue doing these movies, they're so natural and talented. The public needs and appreciates a good comedy like this, whatever the critics opinion is. We need fun, a good laugh, a great time watching a movie, hype up, good energy, not just a perfect plot, an original drama or serious happening.

I hope, there is a second part and I look forward to see Sandy and Brad in another movie together.

Title: It's More than an Adventure Movie
Review:
I found The Lost City to be just a fun sit down for a couple hours. I feel like we've been getting quite a few "treasure hunt" movies lately, and while it was better than Uncharted, it definitely wasn't a Raiders of the Lost Ark. It played its romance cards well, and while some scenes felt a little embarrassing to watch, none were unbearable. I never thought I'd see Sandra Bullock play a character like Loretta Sage, but she managed to a really good job. Same with Channing Tatum as Dash. Bradd Pitt, Daniel Radcliffe, and Oscar Nunez were all fun additions, and I loved how they fit this movie so well. The comedy was very much a hit or miss, with some of it being very dull and hard to laugh at, while other bits were hilarious. I found it really weird that some jokes were reused or had another shot taken at them, but it was good nonetheless. The adventure itself is fun, but felt a little long. But in a way that lets the scenes sink in a little better. I'd say all in all, this movie is definitely one I wouldn't mind watching again.

Title: I don't get it...
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: The Lost City is a good time full of laughter but feels like a typical rom-com adventure that hits all the tropes.
Review:
The Lost City is a goofy adventure with shades of romantic comedy, much like Romancing The Stone back in 1984 but with the absurdity and the laughs cranked up to 10. The movie basically revolves around Channing Tatum's hilarious reaction to every peril and danger. Sandra Bullock charms as always, and Daniel Radcliffe's kooky villain entertains but the best part of the film is Brad Pitt's over-the-top hero. His character is a gut-busting foil to Tatum's attempts to impress Sandra Bullock. The Lost City has plenty of funny moments and laughs but feels overly familiar like I have seen it all in other movies. I enjoyed The Lost City and recommend it, but I wish it did more to feel unique than rely on Tatum's wacky antics and Pitt's uproarious cameo.

Title: Could it be worse?
Review:
No one will remember this film, because it's as hollow as donut hole. There are bad but better films that are more watchable, like Jumanji 1 and 2. And if they tried to xerox Douglas and Turner "Romancing the Stone" it's two decades too late. And Brad Pitt in this, really? He needed money obviously. At one point, I was sure Channing Tatum was donning a Mark Whalberg's action figures. LOL, towards the end he became a GI Joe again?! Saving the day, kinda.

The most ridiculous thing was the makeup. After days of running in the jungle, sleeping in a hammock, camping, etc. Loretta had had perfect eye liners, makeups and lashes on! And had had blushes and shadow on to highlight her cheeks.

On top, it had awful dialogues and storyline. Despite all, Daniel Radcliffe was quite brilliant in it.

Bullock has to realize her time of Miss Congeniality was over a decade ago.

It's disappointing after watching her in Bird Box and Gravity, she would pick a project like this. Oh, I see, she was one of the producers. It makes perfect sense now.

Title: What Could Have Been
Review:
This wants to be a more satirical 'Romancing the Stone'. Problem is, it just isn't funny. It relies too much on improv and the script is lacking.

The dramatic moments are better but they're few and far between. I'm glad I didn't pay to see this in the theatre. Even after seeing it free on Paramount +, part of me me regrets wasting my time.

Title: Romancing the Stone with no romance and a stone dead script
Review:
Wow. I mean, wow. That was bad. Seriously bad. If you're going to steal the basic idea of an old (and good) movie, you've got to do better than this. Romancing the Stone was funny, full of action, and had great performances from a cast that worked well together. And it had excellent production values. This looked like a bad telemovie. Don't know what Sandra Bullock was doing in this. Daniel Ratcliffe proved once again that he is the luckiest man alive to have been cast as Harry Potter as a 10 year old, because he got to be a multi millionaire with virtually no visible talent. The one bright moment was Brad Pitt's cameo. I've never been a big fan, but his ten minutes made you realise how big the difference is between an A List actor and...whoever it was playing the love interest in this. The two stars I've given the movie are his; the rest of the movie is a big, flat zero.

Title: Disappointed!!
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: If this movie is average I want to see average movies forever
Review:
I think after " citizen Kane " and Dark knight this is the third big movie in history.

This year is the year of creating unique masterpieces of cinema. This is not a disposable movie. It was not a movie that I wanted to use as an example. I might even have a collaboration with Disney in making it. I never think that bullac will play a good movie again. This movie is one of the few movies that uses slow motion correctly.

It has unique actions and is among the best. . If this movie is an average movie, I would like to see only average movies for the rest of my life. And I don't even think about good and great movies anymore. I am willing to wear such glasses all the time to see this kind of movies all the time. There were films that helped cinema in terms of technology and turned the wheel of cinema in any way, but this is really a film. This movie seems to belong to a golden era.

Nee Brothers" as the director of the work, show a special ability in it. Production-wise, every aspect is competent enough to fill the standard expected of a mid-budget feature film.

Title: The Cast is the Star
Review:
The Lost City was everywhere. You couldn't watch television or go on the internet without seeing an advertisement for this film. Then all of a sudden, it was gone. I didn't hear anything about it. It was like the film straight-up disappeared. It didn't seem like something I would pay to see in theaters, so It just slipped through the cracks. Then while going back through films released this year, I realized I never ended up watching this film. So I dusted off the ole pen and pencil and went to work.

The Lost City's strength is the all-star cast and the chemistry of its lead roles. The highlight of this movie is the performance of Daniel Radcliffe. Radcliffe plays the film's villain in another performance that makes him one of my favorite actors of the past twenty years. For the small amount of screen time, Brad Pitt makes the most of it. He is easily one of the funniest parts of this movie, and it would be a much lower-rated film without him. Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum are also great as the lead characters. The chemistry their characters build throughout the film makes the film's second half bearable. What the film lacks is consistency. The first half caught my attention, and I was fully invested. By the second half, much of my attention had been lost due to a slow script. It makes me upset I was bored by the second half because when Daniel Radcliffe reenters the film, I really wanted to be excited for him, but I just couldn't.

7/10 A harmless, fun action-comedy that's missing something to make it great.

Title: Judgment on The Lost City
Review:
Overall I think it's great to have an author of a book to seek out for an adventure, instead of seating at home, having writers block while being pressured by your boss.

However I hate to wear a glittery outfit in the jungle that will definitely alert trouble. I do enjoy Daniel Ratcliffe's character. He's doesn't want to be second best. He wants to prove he can do it.

However his ego does get the best of him. I love Brad Pitt's character. Very mysterious and funny. Too bad he has such little screen time.

My judgment we'll be great for comedy and adventure. However mediocre on the plot and pacing. Since some scenes may slow down.

Title: As a return visit to the theaters this was a pleasant escape from reality
Review:
That may sound like a kind if backhanded compliment but that is not my intention. Rest assured, The Lost City (of D) is a lot of fun and is honestly better than it should be.

The story does like milking the plot structure from '80s classic adventure movies like Romancing the Stone or Indiana Jones. It follows frustrated romance novelist Loretta Sage (Bullock) and her dim cover model Alan (Tatum) after she's kidnapped by a weird billionaire (Radcliffe) who's looking for a lost treasure. And he thinks Loretta Sage knows how to locate it. The lovelorn Alan follows after them to rescue Loretta with the help of a cool-as-hell specialist (Brad Pitt) who is not onscreen very long.

The movie sounds tiresome on paper and I'll be honest, the first ten or fifteen minutes are both rushed and thinly written. I was worried if this was going to be the whole movie. But luckily once Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum are onscreen together trying to survive and fall in love, it is quite a lot of fun.

Once the adventure begins, it really picks up and the jokes are really funny. Despite being 57, Sandra Bullock remains a gorgeous woman and her comic timing is as good as ever. Channing Tatum has mastered playing the 'dumb but sweet manchild' to a tee now. I saw more of Tatum' ass than I ever wanted to see though. They had surprisingly good chemistry.

The show is nearly stolen by Daniel Radcliffe who is having an absolute blast as the bad guy Abigail Fairfax (yes really). He really yucks it up as a wacky rich lunatic and has some great lines. Brad Pitt really just has a cameo appearance in turns of screen-time without going into spoilers. But he is so cool and funny at the same time.

A couple of the side characters are kind of wasted unfortunately. There is a sidestory about Loretta Sage's assistant (Da'Vine Joy Randolph) who is also on a rescue mission and it is jarring whenever it cuts back from the main story to her. Randolph's demeanor and delivery could make some lines funny but they don't give her that many good jokes and that's a shame. A second character who is basically a grown woman acting like a teenager is very annoying but she's not onscreen long thank god.

On the flip slide, Oscar Nunez (from The Office) is in this and he is pretty damn funny. It's a one-joke stereotypical kind of character but man he is hilarious and did everything right.

There is not quite as much action in this as say Jungle Cruise or the more recent Jumanji movies. But it's clever how they handle the fight scenes and chases.

Despite its generic sounding title, The Lost City is a good time.

Title: Wow how negative reviews
Review:
The movie was adventurous. My favorite character had to be either the villain (Daniel Radcliffe as Fairfax) or the main character (Sandra Bullock as Loretta Sage). The filming was incredible and the locations looked absolutely beautiful (I know it wasn't as cool actually being there in the jungle). How they captured the mood in the setting was perfect and how they created a spot-on and talented cast was remarkable. The plot was kind of predictable but most of the action and adventure in it was involving comedy and drama. I'd love to see another movie like this but with the same actor as (one of) the antagonist(s). The movie in conclusion was spectacular.

Ok, I'm a guy and this movie is probably supposed to be enjoyed by women but I loved it so much. I love these adventure movies so much. The acting is superb and the plot is excellent. I would rewatch it in a second. I only wish Brad Pitt was in the whole movie and not just the beginning and the very end briefly but I understand the story line wouldn't have worked with all 3 of them or would it? That's the real question.

Title: It's ok, But Shakespeare it isn't
Review:
Sandra Bullock is capable of carrying a movie and has proven herself many times but here she seemed a bit sluggish. Guess she was in need of a break to recharge and reenergize herself. Channing Tatum is perfect and seems tireless, any role he's in he puts that extra thrust that never disappoints and so far everything I've seen him in I wasn't disappointed. Brad Pitt on the other hand literally stole the movie with the little screen time he had, I'm not big on him but he was magnificent in this movie. Daniel Radcliffe who plays a billionaire is the villain and again he trying to put those "Harry Potter" movie's behind him, again I say he just needs the right script unfortunately this isn't one of them. As a whole this one doesn't in my opinion deliver but offers just enough to get by.

It's not a remake of "Romancing The Stone" but does borrow heavily from it as it tries to offer a bit more than RTS does. The chemistry may have been stronger had Bullock been more refreshed but she made several movies back to back and was pretty much burned out and sadly it showed. The gimmicks and stunt's aren't are that great nor are some of the jokes and seemed to take a bit to get moving. The action is there but the acting wasn't to me up to par. Glad I waited to purchase this as I'll wait a bit till the hype wears off and try again.

Title: Well done formulaic copy
Review:
This movie is as expected- just fine. Not objectionable, not great, just a well produced story with the usual plot of this genre (find the lost "treasure" while bad guys interfere). While Bullock isn't at her best, she pulls off the role better than most would. Daniel Radcliffe is excellent in his silly role but still might not be the best choice for it... he's not really a believable bad guy imo.

Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Title: Mostly Dreadful
Review:
If you re going to the theatre expecting some film about discovering a lost city with epic fight scenes and grandeur this is not that. However, for a movie night it has some value with a familiar likeable cast and some decent yet mostly corny comedic moments. It's very much family comedy meaning it applies broadly but isn't spectacular for any group in particular.

Daniel Radcliffe is straight up terrible as the villain. There simply is no fit here at all. He isn't funny, nor can he really be taken very seriously. It seems uncertain he will ever be able to break from his role as Harry Potter. There are even moments he expresses his frustration almost identically to Harry.

Overal you can fill your time better with another film .

Title: Comes close to Romancing the Stone, not Uncharted
Review:
I liked The lost City surprisingly more than I was expected. From poster, I got impression that this is cheap clone of Uncharted, but it turned out to be lighthearted adventure romance comedy.

From the beginning It makes clear it never takes itself seriously, and thanks to due good cast and writing entertains till end.

Romance part is in my opinion weakest element of the movie, at least I was not entirely sold by chemistry of the lead actors.

Adventure part was really well made, with beautiful locations, and some great and funny action scenes.

I did not notice any CGI effects and which was refreshing for me. It has the fell like old adventure movies, that could have being made decades ago.

Maybe this could be also reason for some negative reviews - this is not Indy or Uncharted, nor superhero movie packed with action spectacle.

It has more than a few similarities to Romancing the Stone, which is a good thing, event though it may not match its qualities.

Some says the script was not original. While I would agree plot wise, I also think the writers created original characters, and there are some great comic moments, that were fresh and well executed.

When the movie ended, I felt lighter, smiling, and compelled to write review. While there may be something missing to achieve greatness, this is still solid entertainment, worth watching when in mood for something to relax with.

Title: Fine entertaining

Just a refresh romance story treasure hunt Not boring sandra and Channing are so good bard pit stunts amazing only for few minutes Overall good movie to watch.

Title: Plot was okay but the cast was better
Review:
Good as a comedy, I think Sandra bullock and Channing Tatum did well together. It was great to see Daniel Radcliffe in a villain-type role, I was unsure about this at first but I think he did very well and it was a fresh perspective on his acting abilities. I think it was well-cast, and all the actors all did well working together. I think it worked well but almost more of a romantic comedy feel than action adventure. It could have gone back to Daniel Radcliffe's character every once in a while to make the film plot more effective. I never really felt a true sense of danger after the opening part where they were first captured, and again towards the end when I was unsure how they were going to get off the island.

Title: Meh, unexciting but watchable
Review:
Whole time, I couldn't stop thinking about how uncomfortable main character must've been, by the time she was kidnapped. Quite apparent that the her one piece is literally a costume to stand out against the backdrop of the movie (though it is cute). On the other hand, perhaps it was very good quality. Loved seeing"Oscar" and the manager reminded me a bit of Queen Latifah. Sandra does the 'awkward stutter acting well' and so does Channing. Also loved seeing Daniel as a villain and Brad was a nice surprise. Unfortunately, the script relied a little too much on canned, predictable humor. I recommend as a popcorn flick, but I doubt I watch a second time as a first choice.

Title: Worst Sandra Bullock Movie Ever!!
Review:
This is my first review of a movie. I love Sandra Bullock as an actress. I have seen most of her movies. She usually makes me laugh, I love the romcoms. But this movie, which received so much hype, has to be her worst movie ever. I thought "The Heat" was bad, but this goes way beyond bad. Sandra, you cannot be that desperate for a paycheck. Channing Tatum, I don't know why he was picked, I didn't feel that they had any chemistry together. Brad Pitt's character would have made the movie more interesting, but I guess they couldn't afford his salary. Anyway you look at it, this will be the worst 90 minutes you will waste in your life. Go take a walk, play with the dog, wash your car, do anything but waste your time on this.

Title: Im not surprised that it was bad
Review:
Even before watching it I knew it was going to be average at best, but it was a little bit worse than average. The story was not great and it just felt very boring like I've seen it before a million times. The action scenes were okay, but there wasn't much of them and it didn't make the movie more thrilling. There wasn't much comedy in the movie; just some lame jokes here and there. The only thing I liked about the movie was Brad Pitt's cameo and maybe the movie might have been a bit better if he had a main role. Movies are getting more bad every year and it feels like Hollywood are running out of ideas; I feel the demise of cinema coming.

It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Fun hybrid retread
Review:
Aimed at tweens too young to remember Romancing the Stone, this blatant retread is reasonably mindless fun. The ageless Bullock plays the new Joan Wilder in an expert manner consistent with nearly every role in her career, while Tatum rehashes his 21 Jump Street style Himbo with a heart. 80s tropes are peppered throughout, including Stand By Leeches and even a brief musical homage to The Goonies. Radcliffe is amusing at times, but his detachment from Harry is probably never going to happen. Fun hybrid retread, and a sequel is inevitable depending on box office. 7/10.

Title: Comedy is Hard
Review:
Once again, another lighthearted comedy to fill my listless soul with joy. I absolutely love Brad Port's short but remarkable presentation, which amusingly contrasts with his serious appearance. Without exaggeration, Brad Pity's 10-minute performance is about 50 percent of the movie's jokes. Sandra Bullock, also accidentally discovering her comedic potential, depicts a self-centered intellect who slowly learns to let go of her trauma and hubris, and appreciate her loved ones. Besides these, the film barely reaches the bar. Channing and Sandra's chemistry is apparent but not convincing. Moreover, Alan's immature and guileless characteristic is somehow added with a sudden canniness towards life, which is just contradicting. Lastly, the plot is just plain - several times the film sprinkle Beth's completely unrelated solo slapsticks for the sake of time, and I am routinely distracted by sleepiness. Overall, a slightly below-average comedy.

Title: Boring
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Brad Pitt's scene stealing cameo is the highlight of this adventure flick
Review:
Directed by the Nee Brothers (Adam & Aaron Nee), The Lost City is the 2nd action adventure film to release this year (after Uncharted) but atleast this one isn't an adaptation or a sequel. With Sandra Bullock & Channing Tatum in the lead, the film is good fun despite the 'been there, done that' plot.

Loretta is a romance novelist and Alan is her cover model. When Loretta is kidnapped by a billionaire (Radcliffe), Alan decides to help her escape and in the process find the lost city.

Bullock & Tatum make for a great pair. Their on-screen chemistry is fabulous and they are both great at comedy. Daniel Radcliffe is good as the big bad. Brad Pitt has a scene stealing extended cameo. Though the casting is spot-on and the locales are exotic (similar to other adventure films -> an island off the coast); the film is quite derivative (with Pitt's character being the only surprise).

The Lost City is good fun despite it's faults. Tatum & Bullock are phenomenal and so is Brad Pitt as Jack Trainer.

Title: Let's hear it for the boys!
Review:
It's Easter and I like a bit of escapism at this time of year so this fitted the bill perfectly. Sandra Bullock surrounded by three of Hollywood's most personable guys: Channing Tatum, Brad Pitt and Daniel Radcliffe tuning into his sinister side. The plot is flimsy a hunt for treasure with a bit of romcom. Sandra loses out a bit as the boys are having fun, Channing adorably goofy, Brad Pitt, slick and funny and Mr La Di dah and sinister Daniel Radcliffe. Actually the chemistry is gorgeous between the he leads and the action and quips keep this afloat. And Channing is one hell of a dancer.

Title: This movie was much better than expected.
Review:
It doesn't do anything new or really tread any new ground however Channing and Bullock have some pretty decent chemistry and there's quite a few laughs to be had.

Daniel Radcliffe does an adequate job of being a villain. Felt like he goes back and forth between being a gentleman and a brat, I suppose that was intended however it feels off.

The assistant Beth was a character that really fell flat for me. She had some funny moments but overall it felt like the character was trying too hard to force a laugh.

Brad Pitt absolutely kills it. For a brief moment he gave me some good laughs. His character has a lot of anger and resentment to let go of.

Overall a fun watch and decent popcorn flick.

Title: The Lost City is a fun romantic adventure comedy with Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum
Review:
Sandra Bullock is an adventure romance novelist, Channing Tatum is the cover model of them. They both end up in an adventure in a jungle when Daniel Radcliffe as a villain kidnaps Ms. Bullock for her translation skills. Oh, and Brad Pitt also makes an appearance in a surprise role. I'll just now say this was both funny and adventurous and maybe a little touching in places. Both Mom and I enjoyed this one. It's a little like Romancing the Stone with more of the glam and even more of the slapstick scenes. I especially liked the rescue attempt while one of them is still tied to a chair! So on that note, we both recommend The Lost City.

Title: Maybe the real treasure was...
Review:
'The Lost City (2022)' isn't particularly funny, but it is fairly fun. This romantic comedy adventure follows a reclusive writer and an underestimated cover model as they get embroiled in a billionaire's plot to unearth a lost treasure. It's a breezy, fast-paced romp that plays with the same sort of chalk and cheese dynamic that has acted as the genre's bread and butter almost since its inception. Bullock and Tatum are charming in their familiar yet entertaining lead roles, while Radcliffe's villainous forehead vein outacts almost everyone else on screen. There are a handful of chuckles and even some disarming action sequences, too. Generally, it does exactly what you expect it to, but does most of it rather well; it's as generic as it is enjoyable. It's a solid, if somewhat forgettable, experience that should keep you in high spirits for its modest duration.

Title: A mock up of Romancing the Stone
Review:
Hilarious movie and not intended to be taken seriously. They covered all the tropes of romance novels and action movies. It's like Indiana Jones meets The Notebook (only way better than The Notebook). Sandy is dressed like a disco ball, Channing is unassuming my charming, and Brad Pitt is gorgeous and heroic. There are even some hints at Tropic Thunder (with the savior publisher). The soundtrack is perfect and it's clear that everyone had a good time while making it. I'm honestly not sure how they ever got it done because I imagine everyone laughing through the whole thing. Yes, the previews showed many of the funniest parts, but there was enough else to still be hilarious. Daniel Radcliffe is perfect as an obsessed villain. If you need an escape for a couple of hours, get over yourself and watch this.

Title: Very light reimagining of Romancing the Stone
Review:
The similarities with Romancing the Stone are evident, but the film is not a remake or a reboot or anything, just similar. Sandra Bullock is a romance writer fed up with the industry in which she works and dreaming of more. So she gets more, via Daniel Radcliffe who does a rather menacing yet funny psychopathic villain who kidnaps her. It is time for romantic interest (and 16 years younger) Channing Tatum to come to the rescue, even when he is completely clueless. The film goes from there, being entertaining and decently funny.

I have to say here that Sandra is still beautiful and there is real chemistry between all the characters, but Brad Pitt just steals the show. Poof! It's gone! No more show for you, Bullock and Tatum. Pitt basically does a cameo like in Deadpool and is confident and good looking and amazingly funny. He elevates the film just by showing up.

There is also the issue of the obligatory Black person that I would not want to get into, but it's impossible to avoid. She just has to be female, weird, bossy, "ethnic" in order to check off all the boxes, but her character just comes off as manipulative, annoying, pushy, hungry and mostly insensitive, because at the end she "has your back, girl!". And she also protects her investment while at it. If I would want as many people as possible to become racist, I would just plop one heavily overweight black person playing an obnoxious and unnecessary character in every movie. That's exactly what happens here!

Bottom line: there are huge leaps of faith necessary to enjoy this film without rolling your eyes, but it was never supposed to be serious. It is a very light comedy that presents even an island jungle as a green and clean place where you can ride your motorbike between trees and islanders who just go on with their daily lives while a volcano is erupting. As such, it was fun to watch, but I wouldn't really recommend it.

Title: Dreadful remake of 80s "Romancing the Stone"

Complete lack of chemistry between actors & the movie too often falling short of funny.

Definitely give it a miss!👎😴

Title: Cute and funny
Review:

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum had pretty decent chemistry, and Brad Pitt was a nice surprise. I could have done without the geriatric comments concerning Sandra Bullock throughout the movie. She looks great and gets the job done, so why go out of your way to belittle one of your lead actors? Da'Vine Joy Randolph's character (Beth) was unnecessary and her lines were stupid and unfunny. Daniel Radcliffe managed to overact and underact at the same time. The movie had some flaws, but overall not a bad way to spend a couple hours.

Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Good flick with a familiar plot
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Better chemistry and a better villain would have done wonders for this film
Review:
Whilst on a book tour, author Loretta Sage is kidnapped by mysterious billionaire Abigail Fairfax whom wants Loretta to help him find some lost treasure. Determined to rescue Loretta is Alan whom is the cover model for her story; whilst Alan is a hero in Loretta's novels, can he be the real-life hero to Loretta?

I've generally found Sandra Bullock to be an appealing actress; when the script is right she can sometimes have a quirky ability of making her characters likeable and turning trite material into something watchable (like Miss Congeniality 1 and 2 for example). However, The Lost City seems beyond her talents...

I get that The Lost City is not meant to be taken seriously (or at least I presume that is the intention), but even so in order for a film such as The Lost City to work it needs to have certain key ingredients;

CHARACTER CHEMISTRY; I've said this time and time again in my reviews and I will keep saying it when writers get this aspect wrong. I didn't think Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum worked very well as a double act. It says something that Brad Pitt managed to work up better chemistry with Sandra even though he shared much less screen time with her than Channing did; truth be told I'd have preferred it if they kept Brad and ditched Channing, but hey that's just me....

THE VILLAIN; films of this nature need to have one and sadly this film was saddled with Daniel Radcliffe in this respective role. I have nothing against Daniel and have found him to be good elsewhere, but as the villain here he played sucked. His spoilt man-child act was not funny and he was about as intimidating as Mr Bean. In fact the few laughs I got from the film were from him actually trying to be tough (though I'm unsure whether this was meant to be funny or not).

TENSION; well there just wasn't any and as usual Fairfax's goons were so inept that you never were in any doubt how the film would end or whether or not Alan and Loretta would get the better of them.

I think what's worse is that I sensed that this was supposed to be an adventure film, but where's the mystery, the suspense, the intrigue etc and don't even get me started on the nauseating and frankly ridiculous and unbelievable romance.

I found it boring and to be honest the only person I liked in this film was Brad Pitt, but he wasn't in the film enough for me to be able to truly like it.

Title: Return of the Comedy Adventure film. It's fine.
Review:
I thought overall it was cute, it was fun. There's nothing amazing this movie is trying to do, it knows what it is. It's here to make you laugh and excite here and there and it does its job. I didn't find it THAT funny personally, but where there was a lack in comedy (for me) it made up for with a lot of heart. It's genuinely a fun story, and it's very entertaining to watch these actors bounce off each other the way they do. Sandra and Channing have great on-screen chemistry and Daniel Radcliffe was clearly having fun in the role of a villain. On a side note, I really appreciate that the majority of this film seemed to be shot on location in an actual jungle. I just really enjoy it when they make that kind of effort instead of a "green screen". You can tell Sandra is really there and it adds so much more life to everything. I think there were a few "green screen" shots that were probably reshooting through production, but 90% of this movie is shot in a Dominican Republic jungle, and that's awesome.

If you need something light-hearted go check it out this weekend. I will admit there's nothing The Lost City does that we haven't already seen in a comedy. But you know what, the performances by all the actors and the clear intention to have fun with the concepts make this a pretty entertaining watch. That's the goal anyway.

Title: Nothing of value here
Review:
Firstly, there is no chemistry between Bullock and Tatum; other than some mother/son vibe given the age difference. Secondly, the story is paper thin - it just lurches scene to scene with no rhyme or reason for each event to be happening.

The central premise is contrite... after she's kidnapped there's no reason NOT to go along with Radcliffe character and find the treasure that your husband and you have been searching for. I guess that means there wouid be no movie but it's illogical.

Characters are comically 1 dimensional... was this intentional? Loretta judges Allan and then Allan responds with a list of all the reasons why she's spot on.. and then says 'oh you never judge a book by its cover'. Ummm... she just judged you perfectly 🤷‍♂️

The ONLY time I laughed is the assistants assistant.

Skip skip skip this awful movie and re-watch Romancing The Stone.

Title: Lost City of D
Review:
I was not expecting much out of this movie and from the trailer it looked stupid, but I thought I should give it a chance to see if I was wrong. And after seeing it I was mostly wrong to think it was bad because I enjoyed this movie a lot.

Sandra bullock and Channing Tatum were both excellent in this movie, they both were funny, and they had great chemistry in a good romance. When they talk about their backstory or their story in why they do what they do you understand where they are coming from.

Daniel Radcliffe is a great actor, and he is good in this movie, and you do believe his role as the bratty villain looking for treasure, but I thought they should have given more explanation for his reason in doing this. Even though Brad Pitt is only in some scenes he did an excellent job, and his character was funny in the scenes he was in.

There are nice looking camera shots in the jungle and in big wide shots of the island that looked pretty and nice to look at. The action scenes that movie had in the jungle was shot well and entertaining to watch along with it just looking nice when they are on walking through on their adventure.

There were some scenes that were not funny but if you look past that you will laugh at the actual funny lines and scenes. Some people will not like this movie and some people will like this movie, but I thought this was a funny, entertaining, adventure.

Title: OK if you like Sandra Bullock and adventure movie humor
Review:
It's a romantic adventure movie set in modern times, mainly on an unknown island in the Atlantic. It's a tongue-in-cheek film in the Harrison Ford model.

Loretta Sage (Sandra Bulluck) is an academic who used to work with her archeologist husband, who died five years earlier. They studied early Atlantic cultures. After that, she turned to writing romance novels but has retreated more and more to her home. She is finally coaxed by her publicist Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph), to undertake a tour with the cover model for all her books. Alan Caprison (Channing Tatum). Alan is always the character Dash McMahon in her novels, in which she is the model for the Angela character. He looks good but really isn't very competent at anything.

Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe) is the bitter older brother in a wealthy family. He didn't get the family business but pursues treasure, in this case, the "Crown of Fire" left by an early Atlantic culture. In reading Loretta's last book, he realizes she can read cuneiform-type writing and kidnaps her to assist in finding the treasure.

The film then follows the adventure as Abigail tries to force Loretta to find the treasure while Beth and Alan try to rescue her. Alan briefly works with a former Navy Seal, Jack Trainer (Brad Pitt), to save Loretta but finally has to work directly with Loretta to escape the villains. Their adventure forms the plot of Loretta's next book.

You'll probably enjoy the movie if you like Sandra Bullock and adventure humor. Brad Pitt is amazing in his cameo role as Jack Trainer. Daniel Radcliffe is a little odd as a master villain. However, some other characters fit stereotypes for this kind of movie.

Title: Brat Pitt stole the show.
Review:
Here's The 4K Lowedown on "The Lost City" (PG-13 - 2022 - 4K) Genre: Comedy/Adventure

My Score: 7.1 Cast=10 Acting=6 Plot=6 Ending=8 Story=5 Funny=7 Chemistry=9 Script=5 Mystery=7 Stunts=8

A reclusive romance novelist on a book tour with her cover model gets swept up in a kidnapping attempt that lands them both in a cutthroat jungle adventure.

"How do they keep finding us?

"You're basically a walking disco ball" I thought this was going to be like Romancing the Stone, but it was more like Fool's Gold. I had to treat this as a comedy first, especially with Daniel Radcliffe as the antagonist. Brad Pitt stole the show here and there was some really good physical comedy...it's too bad the script and the story needed some work to make this a great movie. As it was, I liked it and I think it's worth a watch...I'm not sure I would watch it again.

4K Score: 8.2 HDR=9 Audio=8 Bass=7 Bright=9 Speech=8

This was a fun transfer overall. Picture quality was really good, particularly the jungle scenes. I was hoping for a better audio experience with Atmos in place but it was alright. The only other word I can put to the transfer is "nice" and it's kind of disappointing when I think about it.

Title: Masterpiece.why???
Review:
Friends, out of 262 votes, Rotten Tomatoes website got 79. So this movie is unique and everyone should watch it. This movie can be a complete and enjoyable study of art. Because the details are observed. Unconsciously, the director has come on the screen. A movie that can be seen a hundred times and learn a lot from it. It makes our mind more active. The movie is heavy. And it has all the features of an action movie It's as if everything has come together to make a unique movie and everything will be engraved in the history of cinema. To make such a film, you must know literature, know classical cinema, know painting, and be a professional screenwriter. This film comes from the subconscious of its director.

The story of the movie was very beautiful and not repetitive or clichéd at all. Actors seem to be made only for these roles. Adam Nei and Aron Nei prove that they can follow in the footsteps of great filmmakers. But in this movie, it is clear that they are not looking for more profit and sales with the common stereotypes of Hollywood and made an artistic and masterpiece movie with heart and soul. In short, it is very important that a movie can affect us as much as fiction.

It was really a unique and first class movie. Do not be fooled by the poster. Hollywood has given us trash movies for years under the title of adventure genre, maybe we think this movie is one of them. Contrary to the simple appearance of the film, it is a masterpiece in the genre of adventure and drama. A great film, a film at the edge of the art of storytelling in cinema. Do not miss watching this movie. You will never forget the good impression this movie has on you.....

Title: A fun comedy adventure with great acting
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Inferior Re - imagining of Romancing the Stone.
Review:
Despite the presence of its 5 screen writers and 2 sibling directors, The Lost City ends up existing as a very ordinary remake come rip - off, of Robert Zemeckis's far, far better Romancing the Stone. This is kind of ironic, since Stone was frequently charged with ripping off Raiders of the Lost Ark, an accusation with which, I've never agreed and don't think is in any way sustainable.

At any rate believe me when I say the list of plot similarities between LC and RTS is pretty staggering, right down to the mid movie outdoor dance scenes, where both leads finally acknowledge the physical attractions they hold with each other. I won't bore you with a list of parallels. Suffice to say that billed as LC is, an action - adventure romantic comedy, RTS tops it in all those key areas. 38 years later, it still has better action scenes, more suspense, a greater sense of fun and a much higher - charged chemistry between leads Kathleen Turner and Michael Douglas, than LC could ever hope to achieve.

There are positives. The Lost City, like the somewhat similar (and disappointing) Jungle Cruise, is pretty harmless, in an almost bland, family - friendly way. Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum utilise the right approach to the material on offer and never play over - seriously. The Brad Pitt and Stephen Lang cameos are welcome and Pitt especially has a lot of fun with his part as a gruff soldier of fortune with a contemplative side, (though I have no idea why his role was made so obvious in the trailers. Well actually I do. Regrettably, it was probably all about money). Da'Vine Joy Randolph playing the over - stressed literary agent Beth, pretty much steals the show. She serves up the best lines and is involved in the funniest scenes, most noteworthy of which co - star a very sociable goat.

It's just a pity that the general involvement factor of the movie wasn't ratcheted up a lot more tightly. There seriously is minimalist action and what there is, is choreographed quite poorly. The dialogue is repetitious and there is too much of Loretta (Bullock) and Alan (Tatum) endlessly walking through the jungle just talking away. In fact head villain, Daniel Radcliffe (playing it completely for laughs) disappears off screen for such long periods, we almost forget about him and any threats or dangers he may pose to the welfare of our supposed heroes.

I much as anyone likes a good adventure come romance yarn, but sadly The Lost City, whilst innocent enough, just doesn't cut the mustard for me. Believe me when I say the majority of people will be checking their watches, long before the mid - credits, half - expected twist arrives.

Title: The Original "Romancing The Stone" is way better.
Review:
Do yourselves a favor and first watch "Romancing the Stone" starring Michael Douglas, Kathleen Turner, and Danny DeVito from 1984. While Bullock and Tatum are great, you can't beat the OG. The characters are better fleshed out, not nearly as over the top and more human.

Title: Didn't expect if we need it?
Review:
It's really great movie if still not sure what to watch in the cinemas. Just strolling around and giving this movie a shot. Some huge casts are shown up like Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum, Daniel Radcliffe, and Brad Pitt. The movie plot is simple to find the lost city through an unexpected adventurous journey.

The pros are this movie felt entertaining enough through jokes, clear external and internal Hollywood references - citing the movie and using OST music - and actor performances. Practical jokes and rom-com movies typically seem great. Movie narration and jokes seem at a suitable pace. Hollywood references make this movie relatable to the audience. Sorry, I'm not trying to spoil the reference because please just see it lol. Lastly, actor performances are absolutely no doubt caused they are great casts. Visual quality? Just good or Hollywood standards. The cons are the movie plot is too simple and the char's background is too shallow. But actually, these two cons are typical of comedy movies.

Title: Weak copy of 1984's Romancing the Stone.
Review:
What a load of crap. Nothing but a really, really weak copy of 1984's "Romancing the Stone".

Sandra Bullock, absolutely unconvincing in her part. Probably not her fault, because they gave her very little to work with. As this romance novelist and awkward, insecure, can't find a husband, hate my life, because I write trash, but really, I'm actually an intelligent, girly girl thrown into an adventure. And there you have it, the next novel. Bullock is briefly joined by some standard comedy items, like the loud, big, black woman and a mouse like assistant.

Pretty boy Channing Tatum, who of course happens to have so much more layers to his personality than his looks would suggest. Got to enjoy that for literally one short scene, and it's back to the stupid pretty boy. The PC way to go. Even guys aren't allowed to be pretty and stupid anymore.

Daniel Radcliff, once again as this spoiled, rich, frustrated, inferiority complex ridden A-hole, like he played in "Now You See Me 2". Done before and absolutely not an improvement, or in any way interesting. Joined by some stereotypical henchmen. Buffed and brainless, adding nothing.

One lame joke after another. All been done before in just about any adventure movie ever. And worst of all, the utterly failing attempt at some clever Gilmore Girls like dialogue, that more or less dies a horrible death after the second line. Guess the screenwriters got most of their material off the internet, or were hired fresh out of a Craigslist Comedy writing 101 class.

The only funny part in the entire movie was Brad Pitt, but that didn't last long.

In short, another failed Hollywood attempt to relive the good old years, where writers still came up with original ideas.

Title: This isn't a movie that helps.
Review:
I was disappointed in this movie. It's supposed to be so funny that our main female character is being tormented and teased because she's still mourning the death of her husband. It's insane. They mention it's only been 5 months since he died and her so called friend is guilting her for being depressed. Then she gets stuck with the male model and suddenly she's over the love she had for her husband. I thought this movie wasn't any good. This society never let's people mourn properly. Someone dies and you should be over it all in a week and reading to date again. There is nothing wrong with you if you never want to date again.

Title: A somewhat amusing action adventure comedy film that will become easily overlooked
Review:
This action adventure comedy doesn't take much risks and doesn't have an audacious enough storyline to make this a memorable comedy film. I thought a lot of the jokes fell flat and was surprised that this film only had a few genuine laugh-out-loud scenes. Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum have sufficient enough (but is it enough?) chemistry to buoy this film from faltering, but I think this film would've been better overall if Ryan Reynolds was casted instead as Bullock's foil & love interest (The Proposal film nostalgia anyone?). IMO, they have a more natural rom-com chemistry. The rest of the supporting cast is standard: Daniel Radcliffe looks like he had fun playing a bad guy role and Oscar Nuñez (same-named character from The Office) is funny in his minor role.

This film misses the mark yet it still has some entertainment value. Though, I wouldn't recommend watching it in theaters, just wait for it to be released on streaming services.

Title: Disappointing
Review:
Weren't they embarrassed by totally ripping off Romancing the Stone? Right down to Kathleen Turner using a convenient pay phone in a jungle village during a fiesta and then dancing with Michael Douglas. The least they could have done is given the Kathleen Turner part a different job than reclusive yet beautiful romance writer; a different locale than the jungle; a different goal than jewels. Yes - I think Bullock was embarrassed. Some of the movies she's in that are just derivative drivel using her to bring in the bucks, she overacts to the point of cringing. Speed 2, Miss Congeniality 2. She can be so lovely, so funny - but the aging zany mega star isn't working. Tatum - meh. Weird face on top of gym muscles.

Title: What a disappointment
Review:
This was one of those movies where the trailer was all of the best scenes. It had all the potential of "Indiana Jones" meets "Romancing the Stone" meets "The African Queen" but came nowhere close to any of those classics. And I suppose that is too much to ask but in spite of so much appealing talent cast, this was a ridiculous and boring snooze-fest. No chemistry between the too-old Bullock and the too-young Tatum. The Radcliff character had so many contradictions that he was neither funny, evil, sympathetic, or interesting. Pitt is a highlight but his role is far too limited. The plot made no sense and was beyond anything you could suspend your disbelief to embrace. ZZZZZ.....

Title: Zzzzzzzz
Review:
I'm a longtime fan of Sandra Bullock, Brad Pitt, and even Daniel Radcliffe. But not this time. Everybody in this dull adventure seemed like they were asleep, or distracted. Zero chemistry between the two principles (Bullock and Tatum), or between anyone. I kept imagining the directors being satisfied with each bland take and looking up from their iPhones and saying, "Okay. Cut! I think we got it. Check the gate." (That was unfair, I'm sure the directors/writers, the Nee bros, were on top of every take.

And then there's the so-called McGuffin, some vaguely described "Crown of Fire". So pedestrian and ill-described that you often forgot about what everybody was looking for. Radcliffe (I'm sure he loved the idea of trying to play a villain, weakly), who's supposed to be some sort of Elon Musk mega-billionaire, is obsessed to the point of risking his entire fortune with this obtaining this geegaw.

Then, as each character has that obligatory revelation scene to relate their backstory, you are struck by how boring all those stories are. It's like the script just said, "insert backstory here." Bullock's character was supposed to have once been a successful archaeologist but then she inexplicably got into writing bodice-ripper trash novels...yeah, there's a believable thread. Alan (Tatum) was just a good looking nobody in high school, then college, and ended up as a highly paid male model (how sad). Even the supporting characters' revelatory backstories are pointless.

Just what was the point of this whole movie? Yeah, yeah, yeah...I know it's supposed to be a comedy. Still waiting for the laughs.

Title: "Mummies are Human"
Review:
It was fun for a while, and then it was okay.

Well, it was sort of enjoyable and had a great start. And I certainly did not dislike it, or left with a sour taste in my mouth. It does have it's problems that I translate as a lack of "more". What you get is competently executed, beautifully shot/edited/acted, the whole package! Although, Channing even delivers a lines while laughing, and they allowed that take to stay in. Anyway, as an "action/adventure movie" is BEYOND tame, an lacks a big set-piece.. Then, the "Comedy" is terribly generic. So! You are left with "Romance" (which this movie isn't even listed as). Luckily, it is a character-driven story and the leads are well defined and totally work together (they won't be winning any awards, for sure). But it's sweet, and even has some very good/smart dialogue.. when it's not trying to do "dumb". The writer-framing is put to good use, and even for cute moments.

There's not much to get beyond a certain point, but it manages to finish.. somewhat. At least, is not a let down like Uncharted.

Title: Not original, but pretty and fun
Review:
Whether you enjoy this movie will really depend on what your expectations of it are.

If you are looking for something original, high-brow, or complex, you will seriously disappointed.

If, however, you are looking for some brain and eye candy, then you should be pleased.

Not to put to fine a point on it, but this is basically a less gritty version of Romancing the Stone.

Even though you know exactly what is going to happen, the beautiful backdrops and and Bullock's knack for comedy make this an enjoyable romp through the jungle.

Brad Pitt's appearance in the film, although brief, is a real boon to the story.

His performance really stands out and keeps the film from dragging over what is probably a longer runtime than it needed.

Daniel Radcliffe's appearance is less successful.

He seems to be trying too hard to live down his Harry Potter days by seeking out roles that allow him to play a villain, a weirdo, or both.

In the end, this is a silly rom com that is fairly forgettable, but still pretty and fun.

So long as you accept that you are not sitting down to watch the next Citizen Kane, this is a movie you will be able to enjoy.

Title: "Is that a Ken doll on a moped?"
Review:
(503-word review) I found this to be a bit cringy. Enough to immediately assume that the overall film will be a rating lower than what I've given it; the Q&A scene hammered that home for me. That awkward humor, topped with perpetual silence because some people want to make you suffer, is second-hand embarrassment galore. People who love that probably exist, and I'm perplexed.

However, that was only the case until the meat of it all started making headway, beginning with the introduction of Daniel Radcliffe's character, followed by the arrival at the island. It gradually improved from there, much to my relief, regarding the escape from that humor and the enjoyment increase.

The main cast (Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum, Daniel Radcliffe), including the supporting cast (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, Oscar Nuñez, Brad Pitt), were all good and contributed massively (Patti Harrison was alright) to the enjoyment of this film. That wouldn't have been as much of the case if the writing (the Nee Brothers, Oren Uziel, Dana Fox, revolved around the story by Seth Gordon) wasn't also good; the directing, too, also by the Nee Brothers.

Speaking of the supporting cast, specifically Brad Pitt, I want to mention my surprise about him being in this film. I remember reading a few things about it back in 2021, which included that. Well, I forgot. And something about Jack Trainer's voice over the phone was stroking my subconscious. That's why. He barely had any screen time (nowhere near enough, mind you), but he was one of the highlights. His "status" is at a level where his little screen time is understandable.

The best aspects beyond the cast were the cinematography by Jonathan Sela (the visuals looked excellent and picturesque, helped by the work of the location managers, Boni Canto and Isidro J. González) and the action-adventure genre, specifically the adventure part.

The whole 'adventure/exploration of ancient places, maybe to also find ancient treasure' thing has a particular appeal; the nice-to-look-at locations/scope of the world-building probably plays a factor. I may like it more than the murder mystery/whodunit sub-genre, for example, as I watched Murder Mystery two films ago, although it's still pretty close.

The most lackluster, although not THAT lackluster or that big of a deal, aspect was the chemistry between the two leads. Both Channing and Sandra had more chemistry with Brad. Yes, romantic chemistry. Yes, Channing and Brad, too. Channing and Sandra had more comedy-duo chemistry than romantically.

I'd welcome a second film but with a catch. Brad Pitt must return and have a more prominent role. Adding to that, it should revolve around all three of them. The trio was better than the duo. Hell, add a threesome into the mix. Why not? Come on, don't be shy and prudish. Don't "reserve" something like that for films like Fifty Shades of Grey/that trilogy only.

With a better first half and the short-lived trio of Channing, Sandra, and Brad, the action-adventure element did most of the work here, followed by specific characters, particularly Abigail Fairfax.
