Title: The Lost City is... lost within its own world
Review:
Since Ocean's 8, I have adored Sandra Bullock. She's one damn gorgeous woman with a wide range of acting abilities and I found her to be charming as ever. Channing Tatum looks so young, he makes me feel old. He's 41-year-old for the love of God. When The Lost City poster and trailer were released, it only took these two world renowned actors to catch my attention and I was immediately sold.

The Lost City is marketed as an action rom-com with a bit of spoofy elements so it's inevitable for audience to go in expecting it to be a comedy film. Did the comedy work? Yes and no. Some of them were effectively done, it received lots of gags from everyone but others were okay at best, mostly because of 2 reasons; either the trailer has spoilt what could have exploded the hall with laughter or it's just not funny enough to warrant a giggling response from the audience.

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum have a great chemistry and they are just adorable together. Albeit Bullock is 16 years older than Tatum, she knew how to act younger despite her character who leads a simple, boring and uninspired life. Tatum portrays a capable-looking bloke only to realize that he's not as strong as how people see him. Throughout, it felt like their characters are almost caricature-like, which was what elevated the chemistry for me.

Daniel Radcliffe is mehhh, he played the exact similar to his previous blockbuster role, Now You See Me 2 but I guess that's what made it funny, the fact that this movie just straight out let him played a similar role again which was kinda spoofy. Brad Pitt is charismatic as always although I knew his character only serves a few purposes for the movie.

Is it filled with action-packed? No, not really. Here's the thing about The Lost City, it spends most of their running time talking and elaborating its comedic scenes which are a hit-or-miss, that they sometimes forget to include 'action' in it. And even when there's one, it's mostly consisted of chasing sequences that are okay at best, and there's barely any action going on expect when Brad Pitt's in it.

Ironically, The Lost City is... lost within its own world. It fails to set a tone that enriches the world, resulting in a blockbuster movie that feels cheap and half-cooked. It doesn't look appealing to the point that it takes away what could have potentially be an enjoyable experience like Jumanji or Indiana Jones. Even for a semi-spoof film, it's bad considering it took about $70 million budget to make this.

Verdict: The Lost City sends a pair of attractive leads capable enough of surviving to the jungle. However, the deeper the journey, the more they realize it has lost its charm, resulting in a mundane expedition.

Title: Standard Formula & Casting, But Fun
Review:
Not the film to watch if you're wanting originality, unpredictability or any of the actors to display their range, but still a very solid, occasionally funny, and easy watch.

A-List actors are brought in to play the roles they've done a dozen times; Bullock as the intelligent yet socially awkward and insensitive lead, Tatum as the stupid eye candy who has the heart of gold, and Radcliffe as the billionaire Englishman trying to steady his insecurity, but at least you know what you're going to get when you're coming in.

There are some great additions, Pitt is an unexpected high, Nuñez is a bit more wacky than previously seen, but overall it is a cookie-cutter formula for a film. It is an enjoyable, light-hearted adventure comedy with a popular cast that provides a few laughs along the way.

Title: Thank to the protagonists, they manage to make their own film in addition to the parody comedy
Review:
The Lost City is a new adventure comedy directed and partly written by the Nee brothers, who co-directed Band of Robbers and The Last Romantic. The film is about the reclusive novelist Loretta Sage (Sandra Bullock), who has become quite popular with her book series. She owes this success partly to Dash the book cover model of her books who is played by the model Alan (Channing Tatum).

During her book promotion of her latest book The Lost City of D, Loretta is kidnapped by her wealthy fan Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). With her book knowledge about tombs on which she based her books, he thinks he can find an ancient treasure. Alan, who saw Loretta kidnapped, now tries to rescue her to prove that he is more than just a cover model of her book series. Ending up in the jungles of the Lost City, the two opposites must work together to survive their perilous jungle journey and find the treasure before it falls into the wrong hands. With this film they have made a kind of parody film, which brings out the clichés of other adventure films about hidden tombs in dangerous jungles with booby traps. Fortunately, in addition to the parody film, they were able to give the film its own story. This story itself also commits many of the clichés from the other adventure films, which they try to make a bit ridiculous. This is an entertaining film, but nothing really new or special.

Apart from the comedy of the clichés that they try to ridicule, the comedy of the movie itself works best to make the rest of the movie stand out compared to other adventure movies. Unfortunately, many of the comedic moments have already been seen in the trailers, so for a more entertaining experience, try to avoid the trailers. Other aspects that provide the best moments are unfortunately also used the least. As a result, the film is mainly about the contradictory humor between the two main characters. Fortunately, Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum have good chemistry together, which makes their comedic scenes come across better. They actually filmed the film on location, so the directors, together with photography director Jonathan Sela, managed to provide many beautiful images. This also makes the film a bit more realistic compared to other adventure films, which were mainly shot in film studios and were later given a background with a green screen. Most cast members have also been able to perform their own stunts on location. Sandra Bullock manages to return as a comedy star in the cinema world with this cinema film, because before this film she played more in films that were put on streaming services. Together with Channing Tatum she knows how to provide good comedy. Her character often comes across as sarcastic during what she's going through. Her character wears a purple glitter jumpsuit for a large part of the film, which also creates many comic moments. Channing Tatum also knows how to show his comedy sides in this film, with which he has become a talent since 21 Jump Street. In this film he does play a stupid bungler, who is always trying to prove himself. Daniel Radcliffe also knows how to play the villain of the film, but his character is not really well developed in the film. He also sends his accomplices after the duo more often, which means that he has less to do himself. Brad Pitt also has more of a cameo in the film in which he manages to steal the spotlight and you quickly start to miss him when his characters disappear from the film.

Title: A Little Lost at Times, But there is Treasure Found
Review:
The movie has a very entertaining premise. A romance novelist lost in the jungle with her cover model. For the most part the film is able to take full advantage of this set up. Tatum and Bullock do a great job, as well as Daniel Radcliffe as the villain. The supporting cast as well get some good time to shine, including a hilarious bit with the character of "Jack Trainer".

The two leads, Bullock and Tatum have a good back and forth throughout the film. Their lines have good comedic timing, and come across very natural. Sometimes their comedic banter does not land as well as the director may have thought. Certain sequences seem to last too long, as if the two actors improved a bunch of quips and the editor couldn't decide which ones to cut out.

The film does have its fair share of logical inconsistencies in the duo's escape. Certain plot points that leave the audience saying, "there is no way that should have worked." but we go along with it anyways. The movie does keep cutting back to a "B-Plot" that isn't nearly as funny or engaging as the main story. But it feels that the movie spends a lot of time here as homework they have to do for the finale. There is also a romantic subplot in the story that I was just not buying. That combined with some lazy story telling clichés towards the third act, hold this movie back from being great.

But all in all, I still had a good time. The jokes that landed out numbered the stretches of misfires. And the lame story beats are salvaged by the likable cast of characters. There may be some detours along the way, but I think there is treasure to be found in "The Lost City".

The only reason this isn't a 1 star is because Brad Pitt crushes it. This movie was better when it was Romancing The Stone. Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum clearing were doing this for an unreasonable amount of money.

Title: It will be no ones favourite film but it will be enjoyed by many and hated by few. Simple but solid fun and adventure.
Review:
Simple fun. Channing Tatum is so obviously and naturally a leading man, you have to hand it to him for being willing to take the mick out of himself like he does here. Dan Radcliffe is really coming into his own now and is no longer the boyish wizard, he is a believable villain here with plenty of charisma and solid professional chops. Sandra Bullock looks remarkably well and has a remarkable amount of energy for her age. Fair play to her also for continually being able to have a laugh at herself through her career. The story doesn't make a lot of sense but it provides some laughs and is lighthearted entertainment for a Friday night. Brad Pitt's cameo also brings some laughs. It is one you can imagine will be shown on TV a lot in the future because it is largely inoffensive, solidly made, with tried and tested fun and adventure.

Title: The Lost City (2022, Aaron & Adam Nee) Silly but sweet comedy where Bullock & Tatum are better as a comedic pair than a romantic one
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Just Terrible
Review:
With the cast involved, this should have been much better. Instead you get this listless, lifeless mess.

I'm not sure if the badly written screenplay or poor direction are to blame. Every cliche you've seen in every rom-com is here.

There has to be talented writers and directors out there waiting for an opportunity. Give them this cast and this budget and you would likely end up with something better.

My wife fell asleep three times watching this and she picked it.

Title: Wanted to love this
Review: RomCom adventure movies, something which was a big thing in the 80s. I love a Romcom, but why not add some adventure right? You might think so. The problem with mixing 3 genres is the balance, and at least one part suffering. The Lost City sounds good on paper... I mean, it has Bullock and Tatum... hell yeah, it even got Pitt. But when the supporting cast makes me laugh even more, than these 3 names... clearly something is off! Jokes are not landing, there is a lot of chemistry missing between Bullock/Tatum, the storyline is very predictable... I felt even awkward at some points, for sure the scene where Tatum clearly need to show off his body. Obviously a point in his contract, but the build-in how to do it, is rather lame and it just feels off. I often watch the end credits and see 4 script writers for a bunch of nonsense like this? Why??? Even the adventure part is pretty lame (a small little temple in front of a massive blown up CGI forrest) and some tomb. Where are the lush sets? The dangerous booby traps? The plot twists? I mean, nevertheless I enjoyed myself slightly during the movie. You know you can't expect much, going into this... but all was very frustrating and it could've been much more, and opened a new era in this kind of niche genre. I'm even surprised it scored more than 6/10 on imdb. I hardly can give it a 5.

Title: this movie is corny and knows it

David Ratcliffe as the zany supervillain was so enjoyable, I hope he gets to play these roles more often! The whole rescue scene with Nick Cave playing in the background? Amazing. I loved the soundtrack. There are so many iconic visuals as well.

This movie riffs on so many tropes and cliches, it's a delight. The stuff of tales. It also kind of makes it timeless? No notes, loved it and will watch it again! It's a classic in this household already.

Title: Stupidly hilarious 😂

Only negative for myself and my wife was Brad Pitt needed a bigger role.

Sandra Bulloch who never ages was her usual funny damsel in distress.

Title: An Tasteless Buffet of Typecasts
Review:
In her recent films Bird Box and The Unforgivable, Sandra Bullock delved into more serious, richer roles, leading to widespread acclaim. With her streak of strong performances, I was then looking forward to her next outing. In The Lost City however, Bullock disappointingly regresses to her typical klutz of a character, a role we've seen a thousand times that its reemergence was chore to endure. Channing Tatum does not escape his own typecast, as the film's dialogue relied heavily on his idiocy to spark comedy, which failed miserably in my books. Further bogged down by an an atrocious screenplay that presented unoriginal & boring physical comedy, chemistry that felt forced & unappealing, the result is then romantic comedy that comes up bland, awkward & cringe worthy. Oh, and the green screen sticks out like a sore thumb too FYI.

Overall, The Lost City failed on everything it tries to be. It presents itself as rom-com, yet good ol' laughter was a rarity. It declares itself as adventure-fueled, yet motivations & dangers were shallow, and technically, the film screams falsity. Tsk Tsk!

Title: First Feature Length TikTok EVER
Review:
As the trailers left me wondering if I'd been so inebriated that I'd missed any mention of a plot, I find comfort in confirming that my impression actually checked out. There is no plot. Indeed, this film is a kaleidoscope of things happening until they don't anymore. Then it ends.

The film mercilessly begins by offering no more than.0001352 teaspoon of character development. Tidbits of their backgrounds are offered up throught the course of the film, but the window of opportunity to care for a character's arc (or even the pseudo-plot) is nailed and cemented shut.

The attempted on-screen chemistry between Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum was probably the only humourous aspect of the film. I'm unsure of the reasoning behind Daniel Radcliffe's casting, but...he's there. Brad Pitt is in there, too.

In the end, I left the theater feeling as though I'd stumbled upon a Miss Congeniality + 21 Jump Street + Jumanji TikTok challenge. And that's fine. I guess.

Good Scripting Good Filming Good Acting Good Sound Track The Plot is Silly

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Disappointing
Review:
I really wanted to like this movie. I liked many members of the cast. This is billed as a drama/comedy. I kept waiting for something to at least make me chuckle. I felt for the cast as the writing was really stale. I'm not sure why it was so difficult for writers to give these talented actors better lines. While the plot was full of holes and a bit disjointed that isn't unusual for this type of "adventure" movie. I kept thinking how much more this movie could be with better writing and direction.

Title: Need More Films Like This!
Review:
This is a wonderful throwback to the 80's films that the whole family could enjoy. It's funny, fun, and doesn't try to be more. It's made for adults but accessible to a wider audience, and as a parent who's seen too many rape and torture scenes I am totally cool with that. There are a few parts inappropriate for children that will go right over their heads, the language is pretty tame, and the bad guys aren't completely dehumanized.

There are a few plot holes, and no it's not 100% realistic, but it's a lot of fun. Sandra Bullock is beautiful and on brand, Channing Tatum works in nicely, production quality is very good and overall the movie is well-cast. It is what it is, and there's not nearly enough of these anymore. 9/10.

Title: A Fun Jungle Movie That Had Good Jokes BUT....
Review:
The Lost City is funny, and had solid performances by Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum, who's banter made the movie very enjoyable, and the jokes they have are (Most of the Time) Comedy Gold, but once in a while, they drop really cheap jokes, which make me question what the movie's purpose even is. But, for a comedy movie, even if you have a bad story, if you deliver on the laughs, you have a good movie. And yes, this movie did have a messy story, but it was saved by the laughs the movie brought to the table. Daniel Radcliffe's villain only had like 15 Minutes of Screen Time throughout the entire movie, but everytime he was on screen, it was a good performance. It will not make it to my top movies of the year, but it did give me some laughs I really needed.

6/10 is a solid rating for The Lost City in my opinion.

Title: Despite Bullocks energetic performance there's no chemistry with Tatum to make this work
Review:
It's not clear whether directors Adam Nee and Aaron Nee set out to remake Romancing the Stone (1984) and update it for a new generation but it sure feels like it, and a playful poster spotted in the lobby of a hotel early on in the movie certainly hints at it. So while this is a mildly amusing action adventure romp that moves along at a brisk pace I wasn't totally swept along by the premise like I was with Robert Zemeckis' movie and I think this was due to some of the casting.

Sandra Bullock is excellent as romantic novelist Loretta Sage who gets caught up in a kidnapping after promoting her latest book and finds herself on a remote island in the jungle in the middle of nowhere with her cover model Channing Tatum in tow. Thinking that Loretta has insider knowledge about a lost ancient city which features in her fictional novel, a billionaire tries to get her to solve the whereabouts of the real ancient city so he can get his hands on the hidden treasure.

It's a nice idea but is sadly let down by the casting of Tatum who may have the looks and physique but doesn't possess the required charisma or on screen chemistry with his female lead to pull it off like Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner did in both Romancing the Stone movies. I get that the filmmakers are trying to flip the strong macho male lead cliche by making Bullock's character the stronger braver one which is a nice touch and obviously sits better with a modern audience, but the whole premise hinges on the relationship between the two leads which for me just doesn't work. You feel that the filmmakers are just going through the motions trying to channel their inner Indiana Jones rather than come up with something new.

The other mistake was casting Daniel Radcliffe as billionaire Abigail Fairfax who I found to be totally unconvincing. He seems too young to be the villain and shows little menace as the unscrupulous kidnapper hell bent on getting his hands on the treasure. The films saving grace though comes in the form of Brad Pitt who, although only having a brief appearance as CIA operative Jack Trainer, steals the scenes he's in which makes you realise Channing Tatum's shortcomings.

The Lost City delivers some thrills and escapism, and it's fun to see Bullock stranded in the jungle wearing a totally inappropriate pink sequined jumpsuit which adds to the ill equipped 'fish out of water' scenario she finds herself in, but the romance doesn't work, the comedy often falls flat and it's about half an hour too long.

Title: What Walts Watching
Review:
This adventure is real, the heroes are not.

In fact, they were heavily plagiarised from 1984's "Romancing The Stone".

Still what we have here is a fun rom com where in one of those rare Hollywood moments the female lead, Sandra Bullock (Loretta) is older than her leading man and romantic love interest Channing Tatum (Alan) by 16 years.

It's refreshing when so many older men normally have women their daughters age draped on their arms.

Harry Potters' Daniel Radcliffe is back exploring caves but alive this time...unlike his "Swiss Army Man" role as "Manny".

This time he plays a rich, spoilt brat who needs to discover more than just a crown of jewels, but in doing so abducts a romance novelist who could be the key to deciphering the "Lost City".

While Tatum fills in for original choice Ryan Reynolds as the Fabio of this island adventure filmed in the Dominican Republic.

Channing has come a long way since dancing in Ricky Martin's "She Bangs" music video for $400.

Brad Pitt makes a cameo as "Jack Trainer" a life coach, guru & rescuer who has more of a Scatman Crothers effect...ala "The Shining".

In return Bullock will appear in Pitts action, comedy "Bullet Train" later this year.

It's all fairly formulaic and predictable, but it's still a pleasant way to spend just under 2 hours relaxing, watching the big screen and sharing a laugh with other cinema patrons.

Title: I had FUN
Review:
I don't understand the low ratings. It feels like people want to take this movie seriously when it is not suppose to be serious. I had a lot of fun watching it and I am pretty sure that was the whole point. To relax and enjoy this light and silly movie. Made me feel happy. So thanks to everyone who made this one.

Oh, and all of you who rated this as a 1, because you found it dumb, maybe a bit of relaxing and taking things easier in life can help you be happier, just an advice from a silly movie lover.

Title: Bullock brings Romcom Back
Review:
Pretty much a paint by numbers romantic comedy. You can even consider this as a reimagining of Romancing the Stone, that 80s adventure romcom. It pretty much has the forest, the action, and the mystery that 80s film had.

In here, Tatum, Radcliff, Cruise and specially Bullock takes charge to push a really been there and done that concept. They are realistically clicking AND all them have great chemistry. A concept almost foreign in a lot movie production this days.

Overall, its just forgettable and nothing special. This also proves that movie stars are just a different breeds of actor. Without any of those names above, I do not think this would have work quite well as this finished product has.

Title: Just didn't work
Review:
I'm sure if it was the script, the directing or the lead actors, but this just didn't click for me. I'm fine with a remake of Romancing the Stone, but those are big shoes to fill and this one failed on main levels.

The leads seemed to lack the chemistry needed and although on a tropical island, the film just wasn't exotic or exciting. At one point there was a car chase and people were crawling on a truck and I noticed I was just bored by it. Although on paper it all sounds like fun, it simply didn't work for me and I'm a big fan of Sandra Bullock. Wish I could clarify it better and I hope she'll continue to make romantic comedies, but something here isn't working.

Title: Do yourself a favor and watch Romancing the Stone instead.
Review:

Don't get me wrong; there are a few funny and cute moments, but this is not worth the price of a movie theater ticket these days, let alone drinks and popcorn.

Watch "Romancing the Stone" or even "Jewel of the Nile" instead and wait for this thing to hit Netflix with ads, lol.

Title: Worth a watch
Review:
Those in the audience who remember the adventure movies from several decades ago may get a feeling of deja vu with 'Lost City', and that's not a bad thing. In no way is it on par with 'Raiders', or even 'Jewel of the Nile'--but it has a pleasing cast, a doable story if you don't look for too much logic, and a sense of fun. We all know Bullock has Oscar caliber acting chops, so she has a right to do something silly sometimes-and it's a delight watching her tap into her ditzy schtick. She plays well off Tatum's less-talented but serviceable reluctant-hero clone (the infamous "cheek shot" got him more attention than his acting) and they do radiate some charisma. It would have been interesting to see Brad Pitt in a bigger role rather than the precious few scenes he got, but all told it's worth at least one watch-just for the Saturday-afternoon movie-ness of it all.

He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Disappointing Comedic Rom Com
Review:
Loretta (Sandra Bullock) is a writer of exotic romance novels and includes exotic places in her books. She gets kidnapped by a billionaire Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe) who needs her to help locate The Lost City and the treasure within. Alan (Channing Tatum), who Loretta uses as a cover model on the covers of her books decides to be a hero and rescue her. Alan uses his meditation guru Jack Trainer (Brad Pitt) to help.

This is a disappointing Rom Com bordering on being annoying. Everything was forced. The only funny thing was when trying to get out of the jungle, Loretta, says, "I'll drive" and as she touches the car, it falls over the cliff. That was it. Yes, funny but was shown many times in the promos so we knew what would happen. Still it was funny. The script was okay, the execution of that script was lacking. Poor dialogues by others and incessant banter by Allen made no sense whatsoever. Like I said everything was disappointing.

The only bright spot in here was the performance of Brad Pitt as Jack Trainer. All went downhill after his scenes were done. Okay, okay, Daniel Radcliffe did okay with what he had to deal with. Sandra Bullock as Loretta, who Is the Kidnappee wasn't given memorable lines (and it's her show, bummer)

Notables: Patti Harrison as Alison, Loretta's Media Manager; Brad Pitt as Jack Trainer a Navy Seal turned CIA Agent and Trainer's scenes were spot on. DaVine Jay Randolph as Beth, Loretta's editor who finds a way to track Loretta down in that faraway jungle.

I expected better from Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum. For what it's worth, they should never attempt comedy again. They are not good at it. Okay, maybe the script was at fault too. (3/10)

Violence: Yes Sex: No.

Nudity: No.

Humor: Hardly.

Language: No.

Rating: D.

Title: Movie without aim, and 2 stars go to Brad...
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Title: Do yourself a favour...Watch Romancing the Stone instead
Review:
Love Sandra and Chatum but they have no chemistry together.

If your make a rom/com action adventure. You need romance, comedy and action adventure.

This was so cribbed from the far superior Romancing the Stone ...but forgot to add the elements from the movie that made it so enjoyable ...

Michael and Kathleen had so much chemistry and the secondary characters were hilarious such as DeVitto and the drug dealer with his 'little mule'

The only person who knew the assignment was Pitt in this movie and his extended cameo was over too soon

And the mid credit scene...I believe references the writers only using 10% of their brain when they wrote this

I really wanted to like this movie. Such a waste.

It's hard to find movies my mom likes that I also enjoy but it was enjoyable. Obviously there isn't much complexity and it was predictable but I still had a good time watching.

Title: Rom com action with no rom, com or action
Review:
I like the two leads. I generally like their other movies. This was terrible.

No chemistry between the stars. Nil, zero, zilch, nada.

Daniel Radcliffe playing the comedy bad guy should never happen again. Ever.

One star for the Brad Pitt cameo.

4 people apparently wrote this script. 4 people. Yes, I know you think I'm making this up, but I'm not. Script is so bad sandra Bullock resorts to the usual tripping up, falling over shenanigans she does in other films.

Romance nonexistant, comedy missing, action straight from a made for TV show from the 80s.

The only bright spot is the relatively short running time of 1hr 52 minutes. Sadly it overstays its welcome for 112 minutes.

Title: A modern "date night" movie
Review:
With some wokeness sprinkled in!

Literally the best part of this movie was Brad Pitt's character Jack Trainer. However outside of that 10 minutes or so, is just eye candy for the ladies with Channing Tatum, Brad Pitt and if you are somehow into "men" like Daniel Radcliffe.

What do the guys get or this modern "date night" Movie ? A old Sandra bullock in a shiny dress that she cannot fill out, looking all her 56 years of age. A morbidly obese woman with abnormally huge eyebrows, playing the publicist of Bullocks character.

For the wokeness, it is small but in some scenes it is obvious with the "powerful whamen" message & misandry of the men by portraying them as buffoons.

To Conclude: The story is an adventure which moves along at an OK pace, and the ending is decent at the adventures conclusion, however only go see this if you REALLY love your wife or owe her something.

Title: The lost opportunities as no romancing the stone for sure.
Review:
I'm a big fan of Sandra Bullock so was very disappointed with this film as not up to the quality I'm use to in her movies ( as the script was too ridiculous ).

The basic premise was a good idea & if the film had Channing Tatum & Brad Pitt both vying for Sandra's affections throughout & the film took itself much more seriously ( with the character motivations & what a real person would actually do in each situation ) then the comedy moments could have had a good contrast as the film has to feel more real for the comedy to work best.

A truly great film is Romancing the stone & this film is quite similar to that except this film The lost city is half as good & barely watchable once really.

The script needed to be more serious adventure based instead it was more like a comedy sketch film where the characters were way over the top silly.

I was expecting a good romantic adventure ( with humour ) & got a poor film as I felt a bit sorry for Da'Vine Joy Randolph ( who played Beth Hatton ) as her character arc would have worked a lot better in a more serious film, but the script really was not helping the talented cast this film had in it, though Daniel Radcliffe is just not good in his role as a villain ( apart from Harry Potter I've never seen him do well in any other part including this role ).

I think Daniel Radcliffe needs to play a nice guy & trying to act in roles that don't suit his real life personality just doesn't translate in film, so instead of trying to distance himself from Harry Potter just be a nice English gentleman as it's much easier to play a role that is more similar to your real life self.

Only true great character actors can play believable villains & that comes from years of putting the work in usually in theatre to understand how to do it.

So the film is a 5 out of 10 ( not worth buying but is worth watching once ).

Just go into with low expectations & know it is a silly attempt as adventure.

Title: It's exactly what it intended to be and that's not a problem
Review:
It's cotton candy. It's popcorn. No, even better it's popcorn's fancy cousin Fiddle-Faddle. The butter-toffee kind. Sandra Bullock is a grieving, reclusive romance-novel writer, a Danielle Steel or Nora Roberts type (I had to google romance writers cuz I have no idea). Channing Tatum is her Fabio. It riffs on Romancing the Stone and others of that ilk. Boy and girl who don't get along falling in love over the course of an unlikely adventure. I didn't need to see so much of Channing Tatum's backside, but to be honest if my butt looked like his I'd be waving it around too. And I'm a straight guy.

It's fun and engaging and at a time when it seems reality just keeps throwing haymakers (Monkey-Pox? Seriously?) an engaging distraction is what I needed, even though I didn't know it.

Title: Perfect for a weekday movie night

I would suggest watching this with friends, even tho there is not much you can think about later about it I hope if you watch it, you'll like it for the lighthearted piece of cinema that it wants to be.

Title: A bad version of Romancing the Stone
Review:
Where to start? Underdeveloped characters, storyline, plot, poor editing poor everything -A movie can be silly/stupid and fun this just simply is not (outside of Brad Pitt's character). This movie borrowed from everything that worked better and originally before it stole from them -primarily Romancing the Stone, Jewel of the Nile and Raiders of the Lost Ark (check car chase scene). My wife and I were thinking it'd be a silly, stupid fun rom-com worth watching but really it's just stupid and not worth it. Watch the much better version of it Romancing the stone or even True memoirs of an international assassin..

Title: Watched it for Tatum
Review:
It's not bad but also could have been better. If they added more puzzle solving and adventure like Indiana Jones, this movie could have been a solid adventure comedy, much like the Mummy.

The jungle looks fake sometimes, the trees were just too clean, and some of the cgi scene could have been better.

Brad pitt cameo scene was hilarious, but after that it went so so. Also some illogical thing like that thin paper being so resistant to water and wrinkle and anything (just having it inside a plastic doesn't mean it is safe...). Why did the bad guy even gave the real copy instead of just a photocopy. You don't even need the real thing to decipher it.

Tatum was excellent though. I love sandra bullock, but her character is a bit of hit and miss in this movie. I do like the little background that they gave her, how she lost her husband and that tied kinda tied in to the last scene of the movie, and also the fact she was given a new love too.

Overall, it could be better. Not a bad watch but could have been better.

Title: not bad
Review:
This script is not as good as some of Bullock's other comedies, and at times, she is almost a parody of characters she has played in the past. So, there is nothing new from her here, but she is always good and interesting to watch, and Tatum and Pitt manage to add some pizzazz to the story playing very likable and fun characters, and Radcliffe is an intriguing villain. All in all, not a bad way to spend a couple of hours, with some laughs along the way, but I doubt that this will be one of your favorite or most memorable comedies.

Title: Random

Title: Only Sandra Bullock works!
Review:
The movie is strictly for Sandra Bullock fans. Thread bare story line with serious plot holes and no originality. It's like watching "Dora and the City of Gold" with Jungle cruise thrown in and those two are hardly phenomenal movies. Yes Sandra Bullock looks awesome for her age but she has zero chemistry with Channing Tatum. And which book cover model is famous, not one book that I can think of, so the character is absurd in the first place. You are supposed to cheer for a guy who is shown as farcical and dumb at the start, this pairing will absolutely fail.

The comedy works because of Sandra Bullock else I am wondering how did this movie make so much money with such a thin cliched plot.

Title: A Bit of Fun... but Very Forgettable
Review:
Now if you say the opposite and will remember this tor the rest of your life, I would be surprised.

The Lost City is about a novelist who writes treasure hunting stories. Together with the main actor who acts out her stories onscreen, they wound up in a real treasure hunt, wrought with dangers (superficially) and window dressed with a lot of humor, some of which is pretty funny. It's a comedy more than a treasure hunt adventure.

It's all good fun. John Cena and Brad Pitt are quite charismatic. Sandra Bullock played a familiar part, not unlike her role in Two Weeks Notice. Daniel Radcliffe was ok... I feel he has a tendency to overact.

The plot is not much to write home about.

You'll be watching this mainly for the chemistry between John Cena and Sandra Bullock. It wasn't so electrifying for me.

Feminists will not be pleased that an intellectual of a woman succumbs to the romance of a meat head, if you care about that angle.

And that purple dress bothered me throughout the entire movie!

Title: Good Movie and Great Casting
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Predictable but fun, kind of Romancing the Stone modernised
Review:
This is lots of fun, silly, funny and enjoyable.

Mostly predictable but lots of fun. Was expecting a modernised Romancing the Stone and that is apt. The parts are perfectly cast and good to see Sandra Bullock back in the type of character she does so well. Channing Tatumn is fun as the hunk and Brad Pitt who would have once played the Tatum role is hilarious in his bit part.

It's a good Friday night escape the world movie. Yeah it's not the most original or best shot film, but that's missing the point. I actually found it a lot funnier than expected but having moderate expectations helps.

Have a few drinks, don't expect much and enjoy the fun.

Title: The lost city - A lost city and a film that lost its way finding it
Review:
In the world of American commercial cinema, one thing is clear: Sandra Bullock is the queen of the rom com. From "The Proposal" (2014), to "Two weeks notice" (2002), or even "Miss Congeniality" (2000), Bullock has delivered a string of hits that aren't of the highest quality but are enjoyable enought to be successful. This is also the case with "The lost city", which, while being on a higher level than most of Bullock's previous work, fails to deliver a completely satisfying result due to its unsuccessful mix of romance, drama and comedy.

In the first scene of the film, we are introduced with a sequence à la "Le magnifique" - a 1972 spy parody by Philippe de Broca- to our heroine, the writer Loretta Sage (Sandra Bullock) and her partner, Alan Caprison (Channing Tatum). These two are trapped in a temple à la Indiana Jones and are almost eaten by snakes. Then, something happens: Loretta can't believe what she sees. Nothing is logical, and everything disappears. It turns out all that was just the imaginary universe where her next book, "The lost city of D" takes place. It seems, though, that her book's plot is as illogical to her audience as to Sage. And so, it becomes a complete failure.

The only person who cares about the books is a millionaire with the apparently gender-neutral name Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He is convinced that the book gives the instructions to find a lost city, with its legendary Crown of Fire. So, who better to kidnap in order to help him than poor Loretta? The only problem is, that Alan witnesses the abduction and calls a former Navy Seal, Jack Trainer (Brad Pitt) to help him find her. When Alan is left alone by a sudden event, he will have to free Loretta and cross the jungle with her.

So starts this otherwise average film. And it is average because it doesn't know what it wants to be; a romantic comed, a laugh-out-loud movie, or a drama with space for character development. While it starts off as the second one, it slowly, develops into the first, and makes an unsuccessful attempt to become the third kind. To me, though, the result felt a bit dated, like these old Bullock hits I mentioned in the beginning of my review. Channing Tatum could easily be the new Hugh Grant or Ryan Reynolds on the side of Bullock, and if their adventure didn't take place in an ancient city but, in say, an office - of course this would require the plot to change a bit- it would without any doubt be a modernized "The Proposal".

Regardless, it needs to be said that Tatum and Bullock have good chemistry between them, which just grows stronger as the film progresses. Their best moments are those involving comedy, since they are both hilarious, Bullock with her trademark neuroticism, and Tatum acting as her completely antithetic companion. As for Radcliffe, his portrayal of the villain was maybe too passionate, with him getting annoying after two consecutive hours of hearing his rants and grand visions of finding the Crown.

It was the supporting cast that stole the show; Da'Vine Joy Randolph shines as the overstressed manager of Bullock, her constant anxiety making for some unforgettable comedic moments. Oscar Nuñez, who plays an eccentric cargo plane pilot, is perfect as the friendless, desperate for some adventure character. Even Patti Harrison, the actress that here interpreted Bullock's social media manager, is given some excellent lines, with her total indifference to the seriousness of the situation (Bullock being kidnapped) and her fixation with her client's online popularity giving the film its desirable lightheartedness during the beginning of its second half.

There is a successful series of books called "Why mummy..." , where the heroine presents her life as a working mother of two recalcitrant children. Most chapters start with her describing what would be a perfect day, until reality comes and destroys everything. "The lost city" followed this structure, but up to a point. In my opinion, it could have transformed to a hilarious comedy of contradictions between Bullock's dreams of being a brave explorer and her real, bland life. Being a more challenging form of story, this could of course turn off some viewers, but the film wouldn't lose its commercial character at all, actually improving it with an intelligent concept.

For all its faults, "The lost city" is a film that deserves most of the praise it's getting, since it accomplishes its goal; to be an engaging feature with likeable characters, using its actors' talent well, and offering what I would simply call a typical Bullock vehicle.

Title: Absolutely Dreadful
Review:
If I could select minus stars I would but this Romancing the stone remake but terrible. Did Sandra bullock & channing tatum read the script or did they just do it for the money. A b rate movie at best which both leading stars wish they'd never said yes to starring in. Almost 2hrs of my life lost & the price of the dvd. The script didn't work with the cast & all I can say that it was catastrophic at best, whatever they spent on this movie it was too much & shouldn't have even left editing. I want my 2hrs back and my money, save yourself from the time wasted & watch something else. I would say it couldn't be any worse but I would be lying.

Title: Hilarious brilliance crazy heart warming mood fix cheer up adventure
Review:
The Lost City is one hell of an amazing crazy ride full of joy, delicious laughs and brilliant narrative with stellar performance of main cast, Channing always great, Sandra in shape, Brad razor shape with "once upon a time in hollywood" glorious flashbacks and Daniel always a delight when playing some little messy upstairs maniacs.

I don't get the horrible ratings of this movie, I'm certain we saw completely different movie...

It's not 10/10 which i rated, it's legit clean 9/10, with sour mood 8,5/10, but this brilliant light comedy deserves some justice so I'm balancing those outrageous ratings, I feel sorry for everyone giving it below lets say 4/10, You cannot even possibly argue and admit why do you actually hated this movie so bad, you expected heavily complex ambitious sci fi mystery horror drama cyberpunk? That's the only justify of 1/10 rating... Wtf is going on in your heads? Ridiculous, as far as I'm concerned, The Lost City wasn't advertised as deeply complex mentions of genres above, it was supposed to be fun entertaining light adventure comedy AND IT CERTAINLY DELIVERED, period.

Rate the movie by it's genre please, good comedy should give you great time, lighten up the mood and give a good laugh, good horror should chill your spine, good drama should definitelly spice your eyes unless your emotionless stone. I can't even remind of myself when was the last time I had such a great time in terms of laughter and good time, Bad boys for life possibly?

Highly recommended movie, 2 hours off the gray abominable view of the outside which is real life, once for a week to month you just gotta blow off some steam and watch something cheering up, not dramas and horrors all the time ffs, let's be human. Amazing movie, especially nowadays with insanely flat low tier ocean of movies with just "woke press" and terrible humour draining your remaining braincells.

Excellent job, thank you,

Final conclusion : 9/10, movies like these are rare gems these days, you will appreciate it one day or another. Good comedy isn't easy to obtain sadly, there will be always a viewer target with too high iq, too low iq, different taste of humour and sensitivity, you can't please them all....

Title: Good cast and not much else.
Review:
This is star studded cast for sure. But this movie proves that a great cast can only do so much with a generic story and bad writing. Maybe it's the feeling that this should have been a straight to streaming movie, or maybe it's because we've seen about 5000 movies just like this, but The Lost City was miserable to watch. The cast holds this movie up... not easily though. You can tell they're holding it up but the legs are shaking a lot. It's a generic plot that's extremely predictable and older people who don't watch many movies might swear they've seen this before. To be rewarded for a great cast though I believe you should have to do something with that cast and they don't do anything special with them here, the main characters feel like cameos in a much worst film. For that I think this film deserves an average rating, nothing worst because there are way worst films in this genre but just average. Wait for home release when it's free on something.

Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: You get what you expect
Review:
Wonderful silliness and Sandra Bullock does it so well. Brad Pitts small part was hillarious, and Mr Tattums small part is a discussion on it's own. It was just fun and full of clichés.
1 out of 2 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Below Average Fun movie
Review:
The only factor to praise Lost City is the efforts taken to film maximum number of scenes in practical backgrounds. The beautiful island landscape where the movie is set is its biggest pro. Sandra Bullock's fun free style performance supported by Channing Tatum and Daniel Radcliffe adds to the entertainment of the movie. The colorful action sequences serve their purpose of making this flick watchable. Climax is another thing that saved this one from more problems by delivering a satisfying end. Last but not the least Brad Pitt steals the show with his role 😁.

However, none of the jokes seem to land for me, the B grade sequence is the worst part of the movie that ruined the experience for me. Prolonged dance sequence is another dull factor of the movie. Finally, the unwanted fan service mid credits adds to the disappointment of the movie.

Lost city with its ensemble cast is a below average entertainer that improves as it goes on!

Rating:54/100.

Title: Adverts was better
Review:
When I seen the adverts, I recollected Jewel of Nile and Romancing of Stone, so I was keen to see how it compared. There was some plot and character resemblance but it was mostly nothing like what I had imagine it could be. I was a guy (not the only single guy in the cinema I might mention) in a movie theatre where mostly women were having moments of laughter. For me, I felt like I was watching a week-day midday flick.

Title: "Romancing the Stone" knockoff that misses on the humor
Review:
From the basic plot right down to some individual gags and scenes, this feels like a poor counterfeit of "Romancing the Stone." Not only does it lack originality, but it isn't very funny either and proves yet again that even with a good cast - which it does have - you cannot overcome a weak script.

Title: It was just alright. 3 out of 10.
Review:
Well, it's not that funny. I chuckled 2 or 3 times. There just wasn't any chemistry between Sandra and Channing. She was born in 1964 and he in 1980, so that might have had something to do with it. Daniel Radcliffe was pretty good as the villain, and Brad Pitt did a nice cameo.

The soundtrack wasn't memorable except for the opening song, then of course, Dash tells us that he has a masters in gender studies. Excuse me while I retch from the wokeness. Thankfully, it didn't get much worse then that. Oops, I forgot about Radcliffe's characters gender neutral name, was it Aubrey? Wokeness meter was 3 out of 10, just like the movie rating.

I almost stopped watching halfway through, and said to myself, "When is this going to make me laugh?" I did stick it out, though. Watch it again, or recommend it to a friend? No way.

Title: Funny a bit, not so good a bit.
Review:
Trailer of this movie promised much comedy, but couldn't find that in the movie. Yes, there is comedy & I liked it, but I expected much more hilarious content. Love story between the leads was dull. On the whole it fared average, story wide & comedy wise.

Title: It's okay.
Review:
An author writes a novel believing it to be fiction only to find out it's all real. It's a seemingly perfect concept on paper, (pun intended), but the execution falls short. Lots of the jokes don't really land and the plot never seems to go in a satisfying direction. It's a bit entertaining, but I can't really say much else. Overall, it's mediocre.

Title: Not as bad as ppl make it out to B
Review:
Lets pre empty this with....yes, I am a SB fan. Love her (most anyway!)movies for what they are: fun escapism.

When I saw the trailer 4 this pic, I thought straight away of RTS (1984) but the vibe seemed more comedic.

I started watching it last night and didn't expect to laugh as quickly as I did.

Definetly a great turn from the main cast.

Though on its own Tatum's performance is up to par and self mockingly funny, I think he was miscast against Bullock.

I agree with others that the chemistry between them was a bit lacking. Maybe bcs of the age difference, the romance would have been better done with an older lead against SB.

I mean, they do poke fun/don't try to hide her age, so an older, maybe a bit out of shape (wanting to recapture his youth) male lead would have enhanced the comedic parts and allowed for a more, I believe Hollywood likes to refer to it as 'organic' romance. This would have also helped the contrast with the Brad Pitt (perfect specimen) alternative love interest.

A quick shout out to Radcliffe as well as he camps up his baddie just enough, whilst keeping him believable as a whiny spoilt rich manchild.

Last but not least, yes I enjoyed SB performance.

Title: Remake of romancing the stone but worse not funny
Review:
This movie is like a remake of romancing the stone. It's updated to 2022 however it's worse than that movie. The premise is the same and some of the scenes are the same and Sandra is even wearing the same 80s clothing but it's worse and boring. I saw the trailer and didn't think it was funny. I don't Understand why the critics gave it a good review. I recommend the original romancing the stone to watch. Sandra Channing and Daniel and Brad are all ok but the script is so boring. I don't understand why the critics liked this film. There's a mid credit scene.

Title: Fun for the whole family!
Review:
A good adventure movie with a star studded cast and plenty of laughs! Sandra Bullock looks good as ever and her chemistry on screen with Brad Pitt was amazing! A fun movie I'll be watching again once it's out on demand.

Title: Funnier than I expected
Review:
Watched this with low expectation, but it turned out to be a decent, fun light-hearted adventure comedy. Great chemistry from both lead actors, the jokes were stupid sometimes but still hilarious, and the addition of Brad Pitt as the super badass ex-soldier Jack Trainer (even only for a brief time), made everything better. Daniel Radcliffe delivered a great performance as the movie villain, though I can't say the same about the writing. There were few scenes that felt dragged just a bit too long for the sake of jokes, but it's only a minor complaint from me and the movie was still very enjoyable to watch, at least compared to other similar jungle adventure movies from the last few years.

Title: A derivative missable mess
Review:
Been a fan of Sandra Bullock's since Love Potion #9 - been a few clinkers, but I seriously never thought she would do one like this. At 58, is she trying to relive her earlier success? Hard to say. Brad Pitt and Channing Tatum have moments (very few!) and the lack of chemistry is painfully apparent. The action is stilted, the plot is incredibly derivative. Imagine the worst moments of The Rundown (well, at least it was fun!) Indiana Jones 2 and 4, the few bad parts of Romancing the Stone, mash them together with Daniel Radcliffe as a colorlessly unthreatening guy. Oh, and Sandra pretty much phones in her part, too. Find something better to do for two hours, like watching paint dry.

Title: Modern reconfiguration of well-worn adventure, I hate then love you, slapstick, White-centric movies
Review:
For a person under 20, for whom this is going to the first adventure-action movie in life, this movie is amusing and reasonably well produced. It contains three known actors: S. Bullock, T. Channing and D. Radcliff, with a few scenes with B. Pitt. The casting, from a believability viewpoint, wasn't ideal. S. Bullock is both outside of the demographics to be a credible character and David Radcliff, who excelled at playing a nerdy wizard child, now seems like a child with a child's voice and strident mania, who is an unconvincing "baddie".

Only Channing seems more or less well cast even though it is a bit of a stretch that a 40 year old of his appeal would be a) unattached, b) so naive about women and c) fit enough to play the role.

This was basically a reconfigured rehash of different past movies that was a "money maker" - nothing more.

Title: The lost talent
Review:
This is absolutely dire! I expected to look on this page and see people panning it. Where is the comedy? What action? I thought that Sandra Bullock could act but that proved to be untrue. Not high expectations for Channing Tatum but actually he has comic timing, he just had a God awful lame script. Seriously I can't believe that there are people on here giving this a score of 10 who thought it was hysterical and that there was chemistry between the leads. I found myself double checking that I had the right movie! I resented giving this pile even one star but perhaps it was worth that for casting Harry Potter as a bad guy.

Title: Appreciate it for what it is!
Review:
If you watch this movie expecting it to be a life changing, Oscar winning film - yeah, you'll be disappointed. I feel like a lot of people have unrealistic expectations of the movies they watch. This is a lighthearted, RomCom with in my opinion, a lot of very funny moments. I laughed out loud many times throughout. Sandra Bullock is of course incredible in it and makes a lot of the more emotional scenes very believable and touching. I'm not a huge Channing Tatum fan, but I definitely didn't hate his performance. If you watch this movie expecting it to be something it's not, you won't enjoy it. But it is a really fun and silly movie that I will definitely watch again!

Title: Ok movie if you have nothing else to do

The good- had a decent story and liked the twist at end. Some funny moments, most in the Brad Pitt scene. Channing Tatum was pretty good in his character. Brought some nice comedic moments.

The bad - Sorry, Daniel Radcliff as villain was not great. It was reminiscent of his role in Now You See Me 2, which was annoying. The pacing is disjointed. There are some parts that could have really used some editing.

The ugly - most of the secondary characters are a why. It's as if they just needed to hire a few more people and wrote them in like the characters of Allison and Oscar. Both were annoying and didn't fit in at all.

Title: Good chemistry but not as good as Bullock and Reynolds
Review:
Hoping to share a similar success by pairing Sandra Bullock who in my opinion can do no wrong, with a heart throb actor (Channing Tatum) in a romantic comedy, The Lost City is an inoffensive safe choice.

Great cast, fun storyline and some comical writing with more than a few giggles, but no laugh out loud moments.

I did enjoy the adventure/romance hybrid theme, and Bullock and Tatum's characters were reminiscent of Rachel Weisz and Brendan Fraser in 'The Mummy'. They had good chemistry, but not as good as her and Ryan Reynolds in 'The Proposal'.

Not an awful film, but certainly not the best of the year.

Title: Zero story, Radcliffe as weak as usual!
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Very good modern romantic comedy
Review:
In today's very low TV standard, one disappointment after another, this movie has been very refreshing and enjoyable to watch.

The biggest plus was no forced wokism, no forced jokes (Im speaking to you, MCU...), no forced gender and other political BS. Simply a romantic comedy, like the ones in old times + modern trends (technology + new age stuff which served well for character development) . A little bit silly, but not overly stupid (ekhm, anyone seen "Love and Thunder"?....) to the point of unwatchable. The movie was just like classic romantic comedies, very silly but funny and light. There was absolutely NOTHING cringy in this movie in a bad way, which again should be standard for all movies but sadly is hard to come by nowadays. Daniel Radcliffe made such a good villain, I think he was cast perfectly for this role and Im happy for him that he is trying out his skills in different genres as different characters, good for him. He did a great job! Overall, all actors were great. Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum was not a combination Id ever consider but they had such great chemistry throughout the movie! Alan was very likable and charming and relatable. Beth was awesome and very likable, I wish she had more time for development, would love to know more of her story!

Overall, I was very pleased with this movie. A perfect balance of humor, romance, and fantasy. The creators of this movie have proven that it IS possible to create a neutral movie for the purpose of enjoyment and entertainment solely, and they proven that romantic comedy is not dead and a modern spin on it makes for an easy and enjoable movie.

If you don't like her why did you even choose to see the movie? Just so you can be negative and criticize everything... The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Worth it on all counts, value for money film making.
Review:
With reportedly half the $68 million budget going to the four headline actors. 20, 10, 2, and 2 ( Bullock, Tatum, Radcliffe, Pitt). It is not surprising that production wise, this was never going to be a spectacular recreation of an actual lost city. Yes some nice tropical island locations and effective CGI where required, nothing breathtaking. But its effective, with enough eye candy to satisfy.

The strength of this movie is something that a lot (if not most) of the $200 million plus movies lack, which is Heart. The actors give of their best performances, they know this is a cheesy, rom com adventure, but its never overplayed as such, being just the right amount of self aware that lets the audience partake in the experience along with the actors, without ever being condescending. This makes it possible to forgive the inevitable plot holes, and contrivances, that pop up.

Its a funny, warm, if occasionally violent mix. An extra $40m spent on developing the plot, creating an actual lost city, and maybe some throwback scenes to the actual lost city story, would have fleshed this out to real Saturday night blockbuster level. But for a Friday night, or an afternoon matinee viewing, this makes for a rewarding 1 hour 50 of your time.

Title: same generic formula - not done better

First thoughts - horribly miscast, agree with most that harry potter should not have been the villian but would also like to add that tatum should not have been the hero, for me they should have roles reversed.

Sandra B is great at playing what does does, looks like she has had a ton of work done but still looks great.

Brad pitt is a funny cameo.

Just below average as a whole. Been there, done that formula.
