Title: This was terrible.
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Fluff

And just a tad too old for the younger male. The 15ish year gap seemed noticeable (maybe be design) Still it wasn't the chemistry of the Bullock/Reynolds of the Proposal 2009 where the gaps played apon but still you got the feeling they wanted to go at it like savage beasts... I feel this would have been a straight to DVD film back in the day almost like half the turd fests Netflix pump out.

But it's got some fun and silliness to it so fair play.

Title: Does exactly what it says on the tin...
Review:
If you are expecting a brilliant cinematic masterpiece you will probably be disappointed. If, however, you are expecting a fun-filled, action packed, over the top adventure/comedy/romance you will love it.

Sandra Bullock is her usual comedic top class act, her physical comedy is the best, Channing Tatum is never afraid to send himself up and does so to great effect as Dash and Daniel Radcliffe makes a first class comedy bad guy with a great balance of charm and villainy.

It is, to some extent, and updated Romancing The Stone, but loses nothing in that. The story really doesn't matter all that much, it's the formulaic searching for the lost treasure vibe, but all the charging around in the jungle is very funny - not least because Sandra Bullock does it all in a sequinned pink jumpsuit - kudos.

Brad Pitt is hilarious - he doesn't have a big part in the movie but he makes the absolute best of what he does have - and the vibe between him and Channing is terrific.

Just grab your popcorn, settle down on the sofa and have a good laugh. It's a feel-good movie with a great cast, and doesn't pretend to be anything else. I loved it.

Title: One or the Other needs to be Recast
Review: There's no denying it was an entertaining enjoyable movie. The problem is something about Sandra Bullock's performance seemed off even awkward at times and I don't think that it was just her character. It feels like she was phoning it in and didn't particularly want to do this role or at least not with Channing Tatum. Once I found out there is a 16 year age difference between the two of them I have to figure that's what it is. I don't think she feels comfortable with him or maybe she didn't want to work with him. Everyone said she had good chemistry with Brad Pitt which she did and I think it might be because they're similar in age. There's still a pretty big age difference between her and Ryan Reynolds but I wish I hadn't heard that he was supposed to be cast because now I can't stop picturing him instead of Tatum since their chemistry in The Proposal was much better than what happened here. I do think Channing Tatum gave it his all. I also think he was much more excited to work with Sandra Bullock than the other way around. He wasn't bad either and though I love Sandra Bullock if I was going to recast her I'd probably do someone like Rachel McAdams. Again closer in age and they had good chemistry in The Vow. Plus perhaps her goofy nerdiness would have felt more genuine than Sandra Bullock's performance. Other than the off chemistry the movie is typical rom com material meets Unchartered (or yes Indiana Jones).

Title: Hilarious!

It was a like going to an amusement park. You know it's going to be cheesy but you're glad to be going along for the ride. I actually hope there is a sequel.

Title: Hilarious Quirky Dialogue Carries it
Review:
Without going into a deep dive on whether or not talent was wasted, I recommend giving this movie a watch -- or rather a listen. It's not about the star quality. It's not about the plot. Or the setting. Or the state-of-the-art bang-bang. It's about the dialogue: hilarious and quirky. (I suggest putting the captions on, so you don't miss anything.) And the actors deliver their craft, so maybe it IS a little about star quality.

Oscar Nuñez is full-blown delight . Daniel Radcliffe shows off well-aged acting chops, and Da'Vine Joy Randolph is fabulous, as always.

But it's the quirky throw-away lines that make it. The story is just the toast on which the sweet dialogue marmalade is thickly spread.

Title: The Lost Movie
Review:
I thought The Lost City was going to be similar to "Romancing the Stone," the 1984 Robert Zemeckis film, starring Kathleen Turner as romance novelist Joan Wilder. Joan ventures out of the safety of her New York City apartment into a Colombian jungle to save her sister from smugglers. She meets Jack, and their romantic adventures begin, ultimately leading to Joan's next best seller. Meanwhile, Jack shows up in New York, to fulfill the the promise of more romance with Joan. The film captured a fan base & began an era of movies in the Rom-Com-Adventure genre.

The Lost City features Sandra Bullock as romance novelist, Loretta Sage. Loretta, a widow, has painfully cranked out another installment in her romantic adventure series, which features a dashing hero, aptly named Dash. Loretta is bullied by her publisher into going on tour to promote the book. Channing Tatum plays the part of Alan Caprison, a model who stars as Dash during a promo appearance. When Dash's long-tressed blond wig falls off, and he's out of character, he's just Alan, a bumbling puppy dog with a crush on Loretta. Meanwhile, Loretta is kidnapped by Daniel Radcliffe, a billionaire amateur archaeologist, for her translation skills (she's a closet nerd who writes romance novels to pay the bills). Radcliffe wants Loretta to decode some hieroglyphics in order to find lost treasure. Brad Pitt joins the action for a brief stint as a rescue consultant & spiritual adviser. He plays the part of a real Dash, in contrast to Alan. He's only there for the usual Brad Pitt sex appeal. Unfortunately, Tatum's attempt at bumbling humor, a la Ryan Reynolds, never gets liftoff. Bullock, a pro at comic timing, has nothing to work with here. Hence, her valiant attempts to inject humor fall flat.

Actually, the whole movie is just embarrassing. Sandra Bullock, Brad Pitt, Channing Tatum, and Daniel Radcliffe surely had something better to do than get involved with this turkey.

Okay I just could not take it looking at Sandra Bullocks plastic face. The lack of natural movement in her facial expressions was disturbing. These famous female celebs are getting worse with the plastic surgery, better of using cgi to make them looking young than the plastic face on display.

Movie had its moments and there were with the much Talented Brad Pitt, but unfortunately he is only a little more than a cameo.

This sort of story has been done before with better lead actors and direction.

Title: The first two minutes of Romancing The Stone is better than this full movie
Review:
There are many things that can be said about this is meaningless trash of a movie.

The script is bloated to the max with useless, boring poorly written dialogue that doesn't take the movie ANYWHERE. Who greenlit this script? Why so many useless and unnecessary side characters like her manager, her managers mother, the social media manager, the guy that flies the cargo plane etc. All these characters could be cut from the script to make it tighter and more entertaining. Even the backstory about her dead husband made no meaning to the story.

If you are going to make an action adventure like Romancing The Stone or Indiana Jones you have to focus on

1. Chemistry in the acting. There was none at all except from a short cameo from Brad Pitt. Tatum and Bullock both phoned in this performance and I honestly can't blame them due to the state of the script.

2. Create a good and believable villain. Daniel Radcliffe did not pull this one of at all. Also him being a famous person from a famous family made no sense

3. Focus on action and adventure. This movie focused more on dull dialogue instead of pacing it up with some good action scenes. Every time something happened the movie stopped so Bullock and Tatum could talk about irrelevant stuff for 5 mins.

Avoid this movie at all costs and rewatch Romancing The Stone, The Mummy or Indiana Jones instead.

Title: Very simply? It's definitely 'worth your time'.
Review:
While I can't say that this was the greatest movie in the world, it totally fits the bill for a silly romcom & unlike reviewers who clearly suffer from a pathetic level of ageism, Sandra Bullock is anything other than an 'old enough to be a grandmother' actress, when it comes to her performance in films.

This movie is cute, well acted, well cast & definitely keeps your attention. It's a silly, romcom that fits the bill for how it is being marketed.

Brad Pitt really does play a great character & it would have been nice if he had more scenes. His character is such a badass, but that's simply not how the story was written. As for the others: Sandra is great as Loretta - simply a classic Sandra Bullock character. She's uptight but lovable, a little snobby but deep down still humble & she's just silly enough to make it all work, Da'Vine Joy Randolph's performance as Beth is phenomenal, as is Loretta's social media asst Allison, played by Patti Harrison. I should also add the Daniel Radcliffe does a great job (of course) w his character, even though it's almost odd to see him as a bad guy. These are well cast, albeit silly characters & it 'works'.

This movie is not anything worthy of huge praise, awards or anything of that nature. It's just a fun, silly film, basically just being exactly what it says it will be - a silly adventure romcom taking place in a rather unique environment (which really is beautiful, BTW).

I don't know when everyone became such full-blown critics of every show & movie out there but had this been 10 years ago, at least 75% of these negative reviews would have been people who either didn't watch the movie, didn't bother to take their frustrations out on some IMDb review page, or just watched, shrugged it off & moved on. But these days everyone feels the need to complain about something, so take those reviews for what they're worth - people just want to criticize others constantly & everyone seems to think they are the next Steven Spielberg when half of the US (the world, maybe?) are just a bunch of frustrated, know at alls who really should not be writing reviews at all. :-)

I'm really not here to complain about the reviewers though, just trying to give the movie a fair review by pointing out that those who had the worst things to say tend to give one star on nearly EVERY review they post. These individuals only pop in here to diss films, so maybe don't take THEM too seriously :-)

Bottom line? I'd say just a ignore those negative peeps (remember, they give everything 1 star) in stride & give this fun flick a chance - I think most people will enjoy it.

Title: made me laugh out loud
Review:

Title: No Chemistry Between Bullock and Tatum
Review:
I was so looking forward to this film and disappointed to find it a snooze-fest. One reviewer is correct: it's a really bad remake of Romancing the Stone. I thought it had a King Solomon's Mines (1985) vibe to it, as well.

Bullock and Tatum have absolutely no chemistry and even though Sandra shines in some of her films, for the most part her talent is nowhere to be seen in this one.

I'm not sure why Tatum was cast.

Pitt was the only redeeming quality in this film. I know he was only supposed to have a cameo and he truly shined in his role.

Bottom line: what a bore.

Title: Not a classic but not awful.

Title: Terrible.
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Tow point of views
Review:
If Sandra Bullock is in the movie, I go see it! She never disappoints and everyone I know agrees! Channing Tatum was so, so funny - their chemistry was RIGHT ON. He has really come a long way from Mag Mike! His performance gave me the biggest laughs...really added/balanced Sandy's understandably sad character. Daniel Radcliff was equal parts awful but likable and so handsome n grown up. He was ridiculously elegant/cute as he was stupidly ineffective:) Da'Vine Joy Randolph, stunning, brilliant delivery and vulnerable-see a bright career for her, a stand out in every way!! Oscar Nunez' second movie with Sandy B and he always turns in seamlessly funny performance, The Proposal is one of my faves because of Oscar:) Brad Pitt can still rock it from A to Z, no question! The casting in the previews had me doubtful but WOW! Such a welcome and entertaining movie after the last 2.5 years! THANK YOU.

I Love Sandra Bullock. I am a lifelong fan. Channing Tatum, I have also been a fan from the start. I looked forward to watching this for a while. I rarely have time to watch movies. Incredibly beautiful balance in this movie. I love these two together. So much so that I really wish true love for both of you, and that is the first time I have ever wished that for anyone. Sandra did such a remarkable impression in creating this. I loved every element that was thoughtfully felt and part of this. The entire story fits together perfectly. Sandra, thank you for giving Channing an opportunity to stand up for his talent and skills, while also embracing your femininity in a natural strong way. I had no idea this would be so good on the sophistication and kind humor, romance, and adventure. From Boulder, Colorado .. so much love and blessings to you both, the entire caste and crew. Also, I appreciate the financial investment that made this film quality in all ways. God Bless you. Kerri 10 Stars.

Title: Mind-bogglingly Painful
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: It does the job
Review:
What can you expect from a comedy-romantic movie that also works as a parody of the classic family friendly adventure-in-the-jungle story? Precisely what 'The Lost City' gives you.

Well, maybe it's not that romantic. And maybe there are too many/absurd/easy jokes even during dramatic or tense situations. But again, it does the job. You go to the cinema, you enjoy your popcorn, you laugh a few times while actually caring for this or that character, the lights turn on again and you won't probably remember this movie that much once you've left.

That's how this kind of movie works; it probably won't be a personal favorite to most people and may become one of those... "Oh, yeah, there was a movie about Bullock in the jungle wearing those exagerated purple shiny clothes... How was it called? The Lost Jungle or something, yeah, yeah. It was fun. And there was a blond guy that was hot".

Sometimes you don't need anything else than an easy movie to spend some time, have fun and disconnect from life for a couple of hours without thinking too much. If that's what you're looking for, this is your kind of movie.

Title: A poorly written low budget snooze fest.
Review:
If you're expecting a great little action adventure, this is not the one to choose.

The anti-hero who has a thing for Sandra and has come to believe he is the dashing, handsome hero of her romance novels, was annoying at best. His incessant whining and limp wrist-ed little boy act was overplayed and did help this bomb in any way.

Brad Pitt showed up just long enough to save our heroine, only to be shot after about a 10 min appearance, He was in the movie to what? Help it at the box office.

The whole movie was slow and slower, with an occasional burst of action that fizzled out as soon as it began.

We have given this one 5 stars only because 4 /12 are not available. I can guarantee that this is one flick we won't be watching a second time.

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. Title: A Remake of "Romancing The Stone".... Without the Romancing
Review:
The similarities between this and the great movie "Romancing the Stone" are very strong. But it's not an official remake. This movie lacks passion and story and replaces them with Mustache Twirling Victims and a Character Bullock has played several times already .... Think "Miss Congeniality." Too smart to be doing what she's doing and she only deigns to do her job, and eventually learns something about herself. Channing Tatum has one thing: Pretty, and he uses it well here. There are some funny moments, but nothing that had me rolling on the floor. It's a good rainy afternoon kind of movie. But if you want something better that doesnt rely on cheap slapstick and has a palpable romantic storyline where both characters have a beginning, middle, and an end, something with substance... go with "Romancing the Stone"

Title: Funny
Review:
I'm a huge romance reader, so I figured that this movie would be right up my alley and I was pleasantly surprised that this movie did well with some of the romance tropes.

The casting was great, I've always enjoyed Sandra Bullock's movies, Channing Tatum was hilarious in here and I thought he looked like the old school Fabio on the romance covers. Surprising in here was Brad Pitt, he only had a cameo, but I wish that he had a bigger role.

I know that Daniel Radcliffe has been trying his best to be known for someone else other than Harry Potter, though try as he may, he will forever be known for that iconic role. I think he was funny in here as well, though not really believable as a villain.

Overall this was a fun and hilarious ride, and I'm sad to here that Sandra Bullock is stepping away from acting and I will definitely miss her, because she has been one of my favorite actresses for years.

Title: So much fun
Review:
I loved this movie not just because of the story but the fun I had watching it ! I love Sandra Bullock and the comedic interaction between Channing Tatum and her just made me laugh out loud. Haven't had that much fun watching a movie in a long time . Thank you guys. Much appreciated after a couple of years dealing with my grandsons leukemia and covid.

Title: Been there, seen it
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Chronic, so disappointing
Review:
I really was expecting something special: I adore Sandra Bullock and Daniel Radcliffe, I like Brad Pitt and can tolerate Channing Tatum. I was hoping for something along the lines of Raiders of the Lost Ark - or at least a bit of humour. The humour in this film plodded along with leaden feet. Yes, there was some action (not brilliant, but fairly OK) and they certainly tried re the humour, but most of the jokes didn't really land. They were really trying too hard!

There were also a lot of continuity bloopers, which was really irritating. First, Daniel Radcliffe donning white cotton gloves to hand a box over to Sandra Bullock (very early in the film) then taking it back a moment later without gloves on. Sandra at the bottom of a cliff with her hair in a chignon. Then halfway up, with hair long and flowing. Etc etc. I started to watch with an open mind, but ended up looking at emails from the halfway point onwards, and couldn't wait for the film to finish. I was hoping for a good ending. Don't bother.

Title: A ten seems high but...
Review:
Have you seen the recent adventure crap movies out recently??? Uncharted and Red Notice to name a few. I literally gave up hope on finding a solid movie in this genre released after 2020. But tonight I finally gave in and thought, why not try this movie?

I mean it's Sandra Bullock. She has a loooooong trail of phenomenal movies made. The only movie I could think of that was disappointing in her trail was Miss Congeniality 2. But let's pretend that never happened.

This movie was what other movies of it's kind attempted but could not do! It's funny! My husband and I genuinely laughed out loud! I can't tell you the last time a recently released movie made us do that!

The character development and back stories were well done! What really did it for us was the characters themselves. They were so layered. They had heart!

Even the cheesy parts of this movie was well earned. Not out of place. Cringey but in a way that added to the story.

I really enjoyed this movie. I wouldn't go out of my way to watch it again. But it put a great smile on my face and warmed my heart. It gave me hope for movies yet to be released. So it gets a 10/10 because it went above and beyond movies of it's kind that were recently released.

Title: Smart funny
Review:
Loads of fantastic clever one liners; it was spoof movie. Channing is definitely a super underrated comedy star. Brad was a gold star cameo. I can only guess those giving low stars don't get or like sarcasm/spoof humor and we're expecting something else.

Title: A Lot Of Laughs & A Lot Of Fun
Review:
I loved it, not because of great acting but because of the humor. I laughed because of deliberately corny scenes, the deadpan humor, the very subtle jokes and puns which I'll bet a lot of people didn't catch, and because of Sandra Bullock who I think is great at playing comic roles. It's just a lot of fun. I think the people who didn't like it are too serious and need to the lighter side of things.

Title: Great fun if you remember how to just enjoy a movie
Review:
I wasn't really up for watching this to be honest; I knew nothing about it and though I really like Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum, I wasn't really in the mood.

It took about 30 seconds to turn me around. This is the kind of old-fashioned movie silliness that you so rarely find anymore; it's unrealistic and completely over the top and all the better for it. The aforementioned leads are both fantastic in their roles; funny, charming and both bring some great physical comedy that alone had me in stitches. The story itself is pretty basic, but that feels like it's by design. It's a comedy adventure romp and in that it definitely succeeds.

If you remember how to sit back and enjoy a silly, funny popcorn flick you'll probably enjoy it. I did!

Title: Yet Another Reason to Dislike Channing Tatum!

Tatum was his typical untalented and unfunny self whose only claim to fame is only revealed, apparently, when he removes his shirt. Title: Old, reused plot line and not very entertaining
Review:
I went into this movie without seeing the trailer or reading any reviews but seeing as it was billed as an adventure/comedy I was expecting something funny and full of adventure.

Well...I was disappointed. The plot line has been done before, time and time again. I mean, it's been years since I've seen Romancing the Stone but as I recall it's basically the same story line. The climax scene I'm pretty sure they just took from the Goonies, although not done nearly as well.

The scenes that are meant to be comedic are really not that funny. I didn't have one point in the movie that I actually laughed. Maybe a little snicker at one scene but that's about it. Even the adventure aspect of it wasn't original or very adventurous. It didn't have the ability to pull me into the adventure like other great adventure movies do.

I still give it 4 stars for some good acting and some cool jungle scenes but that's really about all this movie has going for it.

Title: Cheap knockoff of Romancing the Stone
Review:
Except it doesn't have the great chemistry that Kathleen Turner and Michael Douglas had. Storyline was blah, I had no desire to see the leads become a couple, and it wasn't funny. The music was way too loud, so we had to turn the volume down too low to really hear the movie.

The funniest part of the whole movie wasn't even in the movie. When a character gave Loretta a drink, it was the color of urine. I itthought Loretta said, "Urination," so in disgust, I asked my family to confirm she was going to drink his urine. Turns out she said, "You're an angel." That was the most we laughed during the movie.

Title: So cheesy it WASN'T funny
Review:
So, I've never posted a review before but after seeing how highly others have rated this, I just had to do so.

There were so many things that didn't work in this movie for me, where to begin?

1. This is obviously a rehash of Romancing the Stone and a bad one at that.

2. Ther character development was seriously underdeveloped. Sandra's character was completely unsympathetic and pretty unlikable. Channing's character was bit of an idiot and never proved to be different.

3. There was no chemistry between the 2 main characters.

3. The "jokes" weren't all that funny. They seemed to try a little to hard.

4. To me, a long time romance reader, it kind of felt like the movie was making fun of me and others who love the genre.

5. Against all odds, I just don't see the appeal of Channing Tatum. I feel like this movie would've been better if they had cast another actor in his role. (Maybe Keanu Reeves since they already have shown that those 2 have terrific chemistry.) The only thing that was good about this movie was getting to see Daniel Radcliffe be the villain and even that was not as developed as it could've been. I know hollywood could've done better than this.

Title: Cinema isn't dead afterall...
Review:
Changed my perspective on modern day cinema tropes. Think 'Indiana Jones' but with grit. Bullocks and Tatums onscreen chemistry reminds me of my mother. Couldn't stop watching. Sick of b list rubbish at the picture shows these days, finally we're getting back on track to the golden era of Hollywood. Austism friendly. 10/10.

Title: Pretty Cliche in an Very Unendearing Way
Review:
Between Bullock's over-botoxed facial expression (singular) and Tatum's super dumb guy acting, this movie is pretty bad. Everything is supremely cliched in the most predictable way. As in the character dynamics are based on old movie formulas that you can guess ahead of time with minimum surprises. The only thing missing is the sassy black woman and bumbling cops. Wait, nope, they got those in there too. The plot doesn't make any sense from who's involved in the overall adventure. An "evil genius" who is ignoring using experts for his plan. It makes you question why the hell wouldn't he go for someone who could actually help. Why aren't the people on the rescue team from local authorities? The bad dick jokes that make dad jokes look genius. I guess it's worth it if you want a movie to play as background noise while you're cleaning on the weekend. 2 stars because of the actors involved, but that's about it. People are saying that the "intentional banality of the movie is on purpose. That's what makes it great!". I'm just going to say I've been cliche movies done right and this one isn't one of them.

Title: What I wanted
Review:
I liked this movie. It had the elements of an adventure-comedy like the newer Jumanji movies which is what I was looking for, though it lacked the dynamics of a great cast like Jack Black and Dwayne Johnson in those movies so wasn't quite as strong. Daniel Radcliffe was weak as the villain and didn't seem entirely believable. Channing Tatum and Sandra Bullock were great but I think they lack a certain element to really bring this movie to greatness, though their on screen chemistry was perfect. The plot was pretty mediocre but about what I expected, a fun adventure through the jungle to find treasure. Overall a fun chill adventure. I'm glad I didn't see it in theaters but it's perfect to watch while chilling at home.

Title: It served it's purpose
Review:
For being an Action - Rom/Com, it served its purpose with regard to being entertaining. There were parts that I laughed at, so I will give it credit where it's due.

That said, the whole romance side of things fell pretty flat. I thought that Channing and Sandra had good banter - as friends. Even when Channing's character, Alan, was somewhat confessing his feelings, I couldn't buy into it. No sexual chemistry between them, no tension, nothing that made me feel like they were genuinely physically attracted to each other. Especially with Sandra's character, Loretta. In fact, she was pretty condescending to him for most of the movie.

For the five seconds Brad Pitt's character was there, I actually felt like she had better chemistry with him than Channing.

That said, I don't think I will rush to watch this again, but I would recommend it to someone curious to watch.

Title: Perfect popcorn movie
Review:
Tough not to compare with Romancing the Stone. Nothing new with the plot but we laugh a lot and spend a good time.

The duo Bullock-Tatum works well. The Brad Pitt cameo is hilarious. And the biggest surprise must certainly be Daniel Radcliffe, far from his Harry Potter years. He's fantastic and funny.

It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: A light comedy with pretty good cast!
Review:
The movie is like a light chick flick with a few good laughs and a good acting cast.

If you are looking for a serious movie with some deep thoughts or meaning - this isn't your one. It's just for some light, non-engaging entertainment, to relax and have fun.

There are a few references to other movies, at certain point it felt like giving a wink to the Indiana Jones series.

The thing between Sandra Bullock and Brad Pitt started so promising... There was chemistry, they feel comfortable together, obviously had some fun, and could be quite witty. Both are great comedians!

I loved Daniel Radcliffe's performance; as usual - he's a brilliant actor, and especially his accent. Such a pleasure to see him and listen to him talk!

There's a thing I really didn't like - it's the goat moment. There shouldn't be any such references to animals.

Watch it till the very end, guys!

The end was fun :)

Title: I watched it and I was invested

And throwing in a fat black chick for no reason is 1 star off just for that, obviously her only purpose was inclusiveness, and its a shame too because she is a good actress, its just that her purpose in the film was non existent. No idea why some complain about the cgi, I honestly didn't even notice any cgi, the film felt very grounded .

Title: Not enough metal to magnetize.
Review:
Sandra Bullock is a good actress. That's about all the positive about the movie.

With a dearth of good adventure movies in last few years, when a movie with an enticing title for any avid connoisseur like "The Lost City" comes along, the anticipation is high, especially with actors like Sandra, Daniel Radcliffe and Brad Pitt. Oh, and Channing Tatum. But this one falls flat on almost every aspect.

Lack of a menacing antagonist, who is never really a threat is just one of the many things which go wrong here. Background score is aridly unoriginal. You never quite feel the sense of urgency or "adventure" like you do in trendsetters like The Mummy franchise.

The banter between the characters is more like a conversation between tweens. Dialogues directed towards the working class people in the movie are more scornful than anything else.

Acting here is subpar at best. Actors feel bored with no real chemistry.

Story line is predictable. No serious attempt to make the treasure hunt even a little cerebral. Even the twists in the tale are visible from a 100 miles away. All's just happening by chance.

Best to avoid the movie. Definitely not for multiple viewing.

Title: A masterful review that will stir emotions
Review:
So Great.... I'm not sure how I should start this review, I only know that it should be about The Lost City and how I feel about it, and that it should relay the feelings to others accurately. So here we go... so here come all the highs and lows and in betweens, and dare I say some spoilers. It wouldn't be right if I was to drop spoilers and not warn you ahead of time. I may even give you a sneak peek into what you can expect in the sequel. It's always exciting when you come across a really good review. Not only does it allow you to delve into your own imagination, but also the imagination and the mind of narrator of that review. So let's do this.....

Title: Lost in D
Review:
Acting: 9/10 Chemistry: 2/10 Plot: 3/10 Dialogue: 3/10 Pacing: 5/10 Action: 9/10 Comedy:7/10 Romance: 1/10 Setting: 7/10

This movie was barely watchable. It wasn't self aware which was the whole point of the premise and would have elevated the film. This movie follows Loretta Stone, a sad, depressed woman who wants to kill off her main male character because she doesn't get along with the vapid air headed cover model played by Tatum. She very randomly and abruptly ends up on an island adventure with tatum where they fall into cliche tropes, but they aren't self aware or sexy or romantic. It's stupidly awkward and uncomfortable due to the lack of chemistry between the characters. This is a major flaw because nothing gets built and the whole movie had no payoff- except an awkward kiss and mismatched banter at the end.

Title: I can't sayI didn't enjoy it, but....
Review:
The movie was fun to watch, until it wasn't. Sandra and Channing have chemistry and Daniel Radcliffe does a pretty good job as villain. Unfortunately, the creators didn't know what to do with them, except to throw them into familiar, sometimes funny situations, and cliché action sequences. Let's just say that this movie really doesn't have a reason for existing, as it lacks imagination and originality. I really don't understand it. How is it that the big movie studios keep recycling the same material over and over. They just don't care about the lasting impact a well told story may have as long as it makes a profit. This is Dora the explorer for adults.

Title: Fun film!
Review:
This was truly one of the fun films to watch this year! It was also one of the few films that my husband wanted to see twice! He has wanted to see other movies twice, but usually several decades after he first saw it; this one we watched on cable about a week after seeing it in the theater! Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum, Daniel Radcliffe, Brad Pitt, and the rest of the cast were great! The only real complaint we had was that the car falling off the mountain could have been done in a funnier way!

Title: If you didnt like this movie, you're a sad monster.
Review:

Title: Great!

Title: Cute movie that follows the simple formula but still manages lots of laughs
Review:
This is a movie you know what's going to happen, but you watch it anyway because the journey is fun. Really enjoyed Sandra & Tatum as leads, just wish their relationship had more time to develop over the course of the movie.

Daniel Radcliffe was great as the "bad guy" and enjoyable to see him performing on the big screen.

Tatum thrives in this character role & his chemistry with Sandra Bullock is great.

Title: Not high art but very enjoyable.
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Very disappointing!
Review:
I saw this advertised a while ago, and put it on my watch list. Finally got round to watching it, well around 40 minutes of it before I gave up. I'm a fan of Sandra Bullock, and from the story line I can understand why she agreed to do it. However she must be wondering now why she agreed, this is one of the most lacklustre films I've seen (or partly seen) in a long time. Changing Tatum (a fine actor) was not suited to his part, and I really felt embarrassed for Daniel Radcliffe who was definitely mis-cast. One to avoid!

Title: The lost plot
Review:
Fairly entertaining film with plenty of action. However the storyline was very thin and lacked any originality. Rather a lot of cringeworthy scenes with the fifty-something writer fantasising about the hunky male model, while they run away from a group of villains. Lots of bits that didn't make sense. Apparently it was supposed to be a comedy, but the humour fell terribly flat. I quite enjoyed it, but it was poorly constructed.

Title: Worth it only for Brad Pitt and Daniel Radcliffe
Review:
Those 2 are great. Channing Tatum is funny alright. Sandra Bullock... It's a pity because with her (same as with Nicole Kidman and similar actresses and actors who have splurged on botox), I am able only to look at their terrible plastic surgeries... Their inmovable faces, their lack of expression, their unnaturally flat skin... She's always been funny, but when you try to crack a smile and only half of the bottom lip moves, or when the same face is used to express compassion, terror, grief, hilarity, comedy or anger, then it just kills the entire movie.

Apart from that, the plot is meh, the location is fantastic, the characters are full cliches with little development... At least it's not way too long.

If you don's have anything else to watch, I guess you can grab a bicycle and enjoy the good weather outside.

Title: The Meh City
Review:
I don't even know what i expected from watching this but i thought it would be like uncharted just a fun adventure movie. I apologize if this offends anyone but i think its time for Sandra to call it quits on acting- she has done plenty of great movies but she just did nothing for me this entire movie. Shes not funny or charismatic all she does is talk about her book and complain. When Brad Pitt came in the movie got way better but spoilers he dies and its back to Sandra and Channing. Channing Tatum was funny in this movie but he needs someone funnier than him to bounce off him and Sandra is not that. If you replaced Sandra with Patti Harrison who stole the show in her minor appearance then this movie would work! She is hilarious! The movie is shot very well and has some cool action but its not enough. Also i already saw Danielle Radcliffe do this same exact role and performance in Now You See Me 2. Just a poorly casted movie. You can turn your brain off and have a fun time with this movie but you have to cast a good lead.

Title: The case of the long cameo
Review:
The Lost City has all the ingredients that make up a classic Hollywood adventure-comedy film, it hits all the notes at the right times, and is casted to perfection, but perhaps it's only flaw is precisely in just how formulaic it actually is. Fear no further dear reader, to the rescue comes what possibly is the longest cameo in film history: Brad Pitt. Pitt's carachter is perhaps the most interesting and better developed one, stealing scenes and hearts at every heroic glance. One could even argue that this dude even deserves a spin-off of his own. But if a cameo is truly the highlight of an entire film, that's not saying much, is it? Save from the hysterical physical comedy of Sandra Bullock and a few well-oiled jokes, there is not much left for the audience but a few giggles. Still, The Lost City is a pretty exciting and light movie to keep the audiences entertained on a rainy day.

Title: Romancing The Crown
Review:
Sandra Bullock, Daniel Radcliffe and Channing Tatum are willing, but the flimsy plot, disjointed pacing and rom com sensibilities are tiring. Come for the star power and stay for the promise of something weightier (which arrives in fits and starts). Popcorn was made exactly for this silver screen feature.

Title: Brad Pitt saving a boring and forgetable movie about something I already forgot
Review:
I would give Brad Pitt an Oscar just for his appearance in this movie. In fact, that's what kept me from sleeping while watching this movie. The most boring two hours I spent on a theather, and I watched "The Eternals" recently.

I already knew that The Lost City was the kind of movie where you turn your brain off and have fun; the problem is, even if I rip the brain out of my head, I still wouldn't enjoy this movie. The beginning is very promising, it establishes the tone of the film, introduces characters, situations, and context in a pretty good way, but towards the half of the runtime, the story starts to get stuck, and it just doesn't turn into a very expensive sleeping pill because Channing Tatum and Sandra Bullock are really good in here.

The story is way more interested in the silly adventure, but sometimes it tries to invest in an uninteresting drama just to put the main couple together. Booooring. I could easily cut off 40 minutes of this movie. Even things that should get more attention, like action scenes, visual effects and production design are really bad.

Anyway, if you like to see Brad Pitt being hot, this movie may suit you (even if he only appears for about 10 minutes). Otherwise, a totally forgettable adventure. The Rock loves to make movies in the jungle, maybe if he were here, the film would be a little less boring.

Title: Good acting, but poor story and looses momentum
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: As you would expect, Fun overall, lazy and troped moments
Review:
5/10

The first 2/3 of the movie were decently funny, and set the goofy, lighthearted tone. There are some jokes and awkward script moments that fall flat, and the villain is incredibly boring. After the classic 3rd-act "everyone needs to hate each other for no reason, so the ending is more emotional", shtick the writing starts going down hill. Expected a cheesy, formulaic, Hollywood film and got a fairly competent one.

Title: Appealing stars, but dumb script

Title: Not what I anticipated
Review:
When I first laid eyes on the trailer, I experienced a fit of uncontrollable laughter. My excitement to watch this film knew no bounds, especially given the star-studded cast it boasted. It rekindled my childhood enthusiasm for adventurous treasure hunts on hidden islands, deciphering cryptic hieroglyphics, and embarking on thrilling escapades.

At the heart of the movie are two protagonists: Loretta Sage (played by Sandra Bullock), a romance novelist, and Alan/Dash (portrayed by Channing Tatum), her renowned cover model. Loretta's novel, "The Lost City of D," tantalizes readers with its enigmatic title, sparking wild speculations. But it's not what you might assume. Their journey unfolds on a perilous expedition to an uncharted paradise island, albeit not of their own volition. Loretta is kidnapped by a delusional, bittersweet billionaire, a media mogul who believes she holds the key to discovering treasure in a lost city on that very island, mirroring the plot of her own book.

My initial expectation, fueled by uproarious laughter induced by the trailer, was that this movie would captivate me from start to finish. Regrettably, that wasn't the case. It turned out to be somewhat lackluster, with moments of disappointment and monotony. Nevertheless, the same scenes that had amused me in the trailer still had me in stitches, along with some previously unseen gems. These redeeming moments make me inclined to recommend the film to others. I would, however, temper my recommendation by acknowledging that it may not live up to the hype but is still suitable for a laid-back day of viewing. Given the track record of Brad Pitt, Channing Tatum, and Sandra Bullock, I can't recall a single instance where their performances have fallen flat. Consequently, I attribute any shortcomings solely to the production team.

The plot was passable, while the storyline struck me as a bit wishy-washy. Certain segments left me pondering, "Why was that even included?" Additionally, I have reservations about the casting choices. Sandra and Channing certainly embodied their roles, and Brad Pitt, while fitting his character, seemed an unconventional choice for this particular storyline or genre. Frankly, I don't envision him as a comedic actor. I regret to say that Daniel Radcliffe felt out of place in this ensemble. He was an exceptional child actor in the Harry Potter series, but this role didn't suit him. I found myself wincing, thinking, "No, perhaps it's time to step away from acting." The remaining cast members appeared disengaged and seemed to be present merely to fulfill their roles in making a movie, resulting in characters that felt lackluster.

Maybe I should consider watching a 'behind the scenes' episode to uncover the rationale behind that rather questionable outfit (the onesie) they dressed Loretta in. I must admit, I found it quite dreadful. Sandra Bullock possesses an enviable physique, especially for her age, but that suit felt entirely out of place, even for a book interview. The color choice was off, and sequins? Seriously? I couldn't help but wonder, what kind of novelist wears a sequin onesie? And let's not forget about Beth's eyebrows... I suppose we were meant to take notice because they certainly stood out prominently.

Now, on to the peculiar moment when Alan covers his eyes as he asks Loretta, in a state of undress, to 'check his front' for leeches. It's a puzzling choice, to say the least. But credit where it's due, I appreciated the witty wordplay with the quote, "oh your plucky warrior hangs in tranquil solitude," which did manage to elicit a giggle from me.

All in all, I'd say it's a passable movie to watch, primarily for the sheer delight of witnessing these acclaimed actors share the screen. However, it might have caused a slight dent in their status as actors and actresses, given some of the creative choices and moments in the film.

Is 'cheese & rice' supposed to be a substitute for Jesus Christ? Just wondered.

Title: Unnecessary killing
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Not Good
Review:
Terrible, obvious storyline. Cut-out Sandra Bullock character. Annoying support characters. Waste of good talent. Goodness knows why so many people like this (low expectations? Dumbing down?)

There is nothing new here. Nothing that hasn't been done before, and better. I can only assume that the stars were well paid, as it could not have been the script and 2D characters that enticed them.

It tries far too hard to be funny and quirky and fails miserably. There is the odd chucklesome line, but most of it falls way short of the mark.

I gave up after less than 30 minutes. I think I may have smiled or giggled twice in that time. Avoid.

Awful.

Title: From a Rating of 9 to a 5 with the Ending
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Title: Can't production professionals see what we, the audience, is seeing?
Review:
There is no romantic chemistry whatsoever between Channing Tatum and Sandra Bullock. That was irritating throughout the movie. The plot was predictable, offering very few surprises. Title: Star Studded - Romcom
Review:
The cast is the strongest aspect of this film. Although it had it's comical moments, it struggled to make me laugh physically, just a few chuckles throughout. It turns into a hard romance, lovey comedy, over the top writing, mush. The action throughout was nothing special, and the editing was very poorly done, I was really expecting more having a star studded film. I was really looking forward to Bullock and Tatum paired together, but this wasn't the movie for it to be done. All in all, you can skip this movie and not feel like your missing out, is boarders on waiting for it to be over, and calling what's going to happen next. I used loyalty points to see for free, and I still paid too much, wait until it comes to a streaming service.

Title: Not bad
Review:
Overall it's...not bad.

Both Channing Tatum & Brad Pitt were amusing. I feel like Daniel Radcliffe could've been used better.

Sandra Bullock was...okay.

I feel like the first half of the movie she shone. Then for some reason the second half of the movie her character just felt off. Maybe she was dealing with personal issues? I don't think the second half of the movie was her strongest.

So because of that I wonder if the movie was shot in two parts . Maybe before /during the pandemic? I dunno but it felt like there was a shift. I wouldn't blame anyone fir dealing with that though.

To be honest this movie was kind of a parody of the movie Romancing the Stone. A few others that watched it said the same thing.

But overall it was still entertaining.

Title: Not Romancing the Stone.. or anything else
Review:
I love Sandra Bullock as a comedic actress but this movie fell flat for me. Sandra did what she could with the character but Channing Tatum's character is inconsistent. The chemistry just wasn't quite right either. I realize this was attempting to be a bit more comedy than its concept inspiration Romancing the Stone, but the humor was a little tired. RTS storyline was far better and the chemistry of Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner far better. Maybe a younger audience who does not know or hasn't seen the predecessor movies will receive it better. However Gen X...save your money.

Title: Funny, action-packed
Review:
This movie was cute, funny, action-packed entertainment. It was very reminiscent of Romancing The Stone. I was a little spoofy, but not so much so that it ruined my enjoyment. I thoroughly enjoyed it. I hope they make a sequel. All the actors did a wonderful job at their roles. Sandra Bullock was her usual beautiful powerful self. Channing Tatum was endearing, hunky as usual, with a soft side. I liked Daniel Radcliffe cast as the villain.

All in all it was a fun movie. Great for a date-night. Appropriate for younger viewers since it's PG-13. Some mild violence, romance depicted, but tastefully.

Title: Mediocre
Review:
When I first saw Daniel Radcliffe on screen and glimpsed the intriguing setting he found himself in, I was filled with anticipation. The movie seemed poised to deliver an engaging story. Unfortunately, it devolved into a hodgepodge of poor writing and illogical drama. One glaring inconsistency was the portrayal of a billionaire riding in a makeshift ambulance, being chased down by an unarmed, average individual. Even more baffling was that this supposed billionaire had only a single gun for protection, undermining the sense of danger and urgency.

The romantic subplot felt forced and uninspired, detracting from the film's overall impact. One of the most perplexing moments involved the lead actress inexplicably turning down an incredible opportunity to recover a lost, valuable item. This choice not only lacked motive but also severed any connection I had with her character.

Lastly, the film was rife with numerous smaller loopholes that were hard to overlook. For instance, a character struggled to open a simple plastic clip while, oddly enough, carrying a chair throughout a chase scene. These issues collectively shattered my suspension of disbelief, leaving me to lament what could have been a much more compelling cinematic experience.

Title: It's ok
Review:
I've enjoyed the first half of the movie much more than I expected, good humor, some smarter than average jokes and a story that while not new or revolutionary was well written and told. Not amazing but a really decent start.

The second part of the movie goes down dramatically, the jokes become a tiny bit dumber, many puns don't really land and the editing gets more and more disjointed with each scene. Still watchable but definitely subpar.

The main leads made a decent job. I believe Channing Tatum out-acted Sandra Bullock, which sincerely surprised me. However, neither of them were specially great.

In the other hand, Daniel Radcliffe and Brad Pitt shined through and through. Radcliffe is capable of portraying a morally ambiguous antagonist in a serious yet funny way. Pitt made me laugh at every turn, he distilled humor at every word he said and every jump he made. Good stuff.

Sadly, we don't enjoy much of these characters. Pitt's appearance is more of a cameo and Radcliffe's character becomes flatter and dumber as the time goes by, becoming a caricature of the complex character we met at first. In turn, the movie tries to flesh Tatum and Bullock's relationship out but there's really nothing there, just the same old "don't judge a book by its cover" kind of unlikely couple we've seen a million times already.

All in all, it's an innocuous silly rom-com with some very decent action and special effects and a story that, while not really innovative, is mostly out of the ordinary. I expected to laugh more, probably some changes to the script could have made a better flick, but all in all, it's ok.

Do I regret spending two hours watching it? Nope, it was good enough. Would I remember its plot and characters in six months? Probably not. Would I watch it again? Oh no, thank you.

Title: Sit back & enjoy the laughs
Review:
