Title: Forgettable and cliche but enough wit to be enjoyed.
Review:
Going into the cinema to see The Lost City I knew not to expect anything "new" or "groundbreaking"...we've all seen this movie before somewhere, whether that be 'Romancing the Stone' , 'Jungle Cruise' or basically every Adventure Rom-Com out there. But still, despite my wavering hopes about the story itself, the hilarious trailer and charming leads kept my expectations far above average.

After a rough first 30 minutes it was much appreciated once Bullock and Tatum finally arrived in the jungle along with a hilarious Brad Pitt in a very welcome yet minuscule role. During this short part of the film while our protagonists are accustoming themselves with the jungle every slightly funny scene is HILARIOUS with multiple sequences where the whole cinema was roaring in laughter!

Unfortunately not soon after, directors Adam and Aaron Nee lose all of their steam , swapping belly laughs with little to no light grins. It is tiring to see predictable plots unfold and unfunny jokes being made along with flimsy CGI and an utterly underwhelming ending.

Brad Pitt is the star of the show while both Tatum and Bullock get the job done. A miscast Daniel Radcliff plays villain 'Abigail Fairfax', a both cliche and uninteresting antagonist. Meanwhile Da'Vine Joy Randolph is a delightful surprise with a likable persona and an amusing sub-plot.

At the end of the day The Lost City is not a TERRIBLE movie, it has it's moments and surprisingly deep characters to route for. Despite it's major problems The Lost City is still enjoyable and will pass the time ...but don't expect to be blown away!

Title: Was forced to watch it, had a pretty good time
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Pleasantly surprised
Review:
I wasn't expecting much I put this movie on in the background one day while working around the house and ended up watching most of it and thinking it wasn't what I expected and not bad. I saw a lot of negative reviews idk what ppl are expecting it's a cheesy romantic comedy and that's what you get. Theres a part with brad Pitt that is actually pretty funny and definitely un expected. This movie wasn't what I was expecting but in a good way. It's not the best movie ever but if you want a movie to watch with a date or who ever it's not a bad choice.

Title: GREAT MOVIE
Review:
Absolutely loved watching this!! I was scrolling to amazing prime and saw this movie. It interested me since the cast seems great. It was funny, the scripting was good, acting was spectacular, it was witty, there was action ect.

This had Sandra bullock, Channing Tatum, Daniel Radcliffe and Brad Pitt. I've seen a lot is Sandra's movies and I already love her work so I'm slightly bias about any movie of her's I watch, but I haven't really watched anything of Channing Tatum's, but in this he smashed his role. He was so funny and played his part really well. The chemistry between Sandra and Channing, worked wonders for the relationship between their characters, Loretta and Alan.

The whole cast are fantastic! It definitely didn't fail to put a smile on my face. I watched it again with my family and enjoyed their laughs.

There are sweet moments between Loretta and Alan, that really brought it all together. I would DEFINITELY RECOMMEND for anyone that needs cheering up or as a fun family movie!! Hope this helps! W MOVIE FR I LOVED IT LAGUHED SO HARD . :)

Title: Just the tip
Review:
This movie starts strong, promising a new rendering on the old "reluctant heroes bonding" formula. Daniel Radcliffe is known for picking up interesting and unorthodox roles, so it seemed that this movie will offer something fresh and unexpected. Then the second act started, and it turned into generic adventure movie we had seen thousands of times. It's not bad, just... fine. I cannot blame any of the actors for the mediocre plot, just the first act was promising so much more.

Title: Her typical movie
Review:
I was expecting a better and slightly different story from Sandra's previous comedy films. But again the story presents a lot of Sandra's typical dialogue that is too excessive. The conversations tend to carry feminism sentiments. Many funny scenes are incomplete in delivery, jokes are a bit stale and childish. Again, Sandra's character is very dominant, which has been boring since her previous films.

But luckily the story is pretty good, the adventure sceneries help a lot. I think if this film is not made with a comedy genre, this movie is more interesting to watch.

Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Romancing the Stone III
Review:
After 37 years, finally the long awaited final piece of the trilogy is here. A show of hands for those of us die hard fans who have been waiting. Obviously we couldn't let Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner reprise their roles, have you seen them lately! So we got Channing and Sandy to step up. Basically it follows the root plot of #1, with a few differences. Is it worth the watch you ask. Well, if you enjoyed Romancing the Stone but not Jewel of the Nile, yes. The substitution of Daniel Radcliffe for Danny DeVito was clever. Overall, good for an afternoon romp but not up to snuff for a Saturday night watch party.

I'm so sorry but this movie is gonna be a huge pass for me...

Title: Surprisingly clever and not a waste of time
Review:
This was a surprisingly good romp. It is a great adventure comedy for when you don't really want to think, but you don't want something super dumb. The writing was much more clever than I expected and I actually laughed aloud a few times, which is a rarity regardless.

As with all other movies I watch, I went in quite stoned and without watching the trailer, though I had seen frames and tiny bits and pieces. Pitt and Radcliffe definitely stole the show. Channing Tatum and Sandra Bullock have good chemistry and they both grow during the film, which I guess is pretty likable. But there was good character development all around. The bits held up pretty well throughout. And though a lot of the film universe is fake, the plot is more or less realistic, and realistic enough to enjoy.

For movies like these, I usually don't pay too much attention to the cinematography or sound and whatnot, but there were some good solid songs at appropriate times. The scenery is quite beautiful, and volcanoes are fun.

Honestly, I'd recommend it. It kept my attention throughout the entire film almost completely, which I'd say is very good for an adventure comedy. The story was cute and quite strong; the characters had some really exceptional lines. They might even make some people snort-laugh, though that really isn't my jam or jelly.

Just give it a whirl. If you like any of the actors/actresses or if you like adventure and exploration movies, or if you like a smartly-enough written comedy, you'll find the gamble was worth it, and may even come out pleasantly surprised.

Title: So great!!!!
Review:
This movie was hilarious and so cute. One of the best rom coms I have seen in a very long time. I was laughing so hard which was a surprise. The wit and humor are very hard to come by in a movie. The adventure, humor and love story had me on the edge of my seat quite literally. I love Sandra Bullock and of course Mr. Tanning what a adorable match and bravo to the directors. This reminded me of romancing the stone movie but with lots more humor. She's a romance novelist who lives out her adventure unknowingly very similar to Romancing the Stone . The man though is not the typical knight in shining armor, but kind of a little sissy but then he evolves into himself . Overall a wonderful movie.

Title: Skip it
Review:
What possessed Sandara Bullock to take this role? There was no ball game on last night, and I decided to watch this disaster. It was just awful. The plot is a satire on the Indiana Jones series (except this one is based upon a romance novel series). The dialogue is juvenile, the acting over the top, the romance was a flop, and the action was tongue in cheek. If this is what audiences want, I'm sticking with European fare.

Title: Romancing the Stone meets Congo
Review:
It felt like this for the most part with a few original scenes here and there. Daniel Radcliffe plays a humorous villain at best. He's not a believable mastermind, and acted to cheerful for a man of power and money as his character claimed. It had it's slightly charming moments and inevitable haha "clueless" moments/lines.

Title: So, so stupid
Review:
I thought this movie would be really funny. And cute. It wasn't. I am SO glad I didn't waste money going to the theater. My husband commented that no one in this film could act. I know that's not the case. I just think everything was cheesy, exaggerated, and over-the-top on purpose. It just made it seem ridiculous. The plot was mediocre at best. There were a couple of ha-ha moments, and Channing Tatum is great to look at. But that's about it. With 30 minutes left, I wasn't even sure if I cared to finish it. I did, but I felt like I lost a few brain cells in the process. If you decide to see it anyway, keep your expectations low!

Title: Enjoyable
Review:
Greetings again from the darkness. It's not billed as a remake of ROMANCING THE STONE (1984), and perhaps that's because it borrows from many adventure romantic-comedies over the years. Brothers and co-directors Aaron Nee and Adam Nee (BAND OF ROBBERS, 2015) have proven they can deliver exactly what is promised from a script by co-writers Oren Uziel (MORTAL COMBAT, 2021) and Dana Fox (CRUELLA, 2021). Seth Gordon receives a story credit, which is a bit ironic considering he has been quoted with, "The best stories are rooted in reality."

Oscar winner Sandra Bullock stars as grieving, reclusive and highly successful romance novelist Loretta Sage, and Channing Tatum co-stars as her long-time and extremely popular cover model, Adam (in what is obviously a 'wink and a nod' to Fabio). Loretta's love of history, and the passing of her husband, have combined to make her despise the books she writes and the publicity tours she's required to attend ... especially when being forced to wear a skintight purple/fuchsia sequined onesie. On the other hand, vapid model Adam relishes giving the audience what they want - strutting, hair waving, and bare chest.

After their most recent event goes sideways, Loretta is kidnapped by the villainous rich guy with a so-called gender-neutral name of Abigail Fairfax (Daniel Radcliffe). He's read her latest book and needs her help in locating the 'Crown of Fire' hidden somewhere on a remote island he purchased for this reason. Things have to move quickly before the volcano erupts and buries the treasure. At this point, Adam is committed to rescuing Loretta and proving that he's more than a pretty face. Loretta's stressed out literary agent Beth (Da'Vine Joy Randolph, DOLEMITE IS MY NAME, 2019) is determined to save her writer-asset, while the newly hired social media director (Patti Harrison) acts goofy (and deserved better lines).

It's regrettable, yet a sign of the times, that (2-time Oscar winner) Brad Pitt's cameo is included in the trailer. This should have been a pleasant surprise for viewers, and instead is spoiled by the clip. He has fun with his role as former Navy Seal and meditation partner with Adam, as the two work towards Loretta's rescue. The time on the island combines the adventure sequences with the slow-build of the romantic bond between Loretta and Adam, and both actors do their thing. It's mostly Mr. Radcliffe who seems a bit out of place as he goes big in his role as villain, when some subtlety might have played better. Then again, there is nothing subtle about this production, including the scenes with Beth and an oddball pilot with a goat-fetish played by Oscar Nunez ("The Office").

Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum can play these characters in their sleep, and to their credit, they both seem engaged and willing to put forth the necessary effort. Tatum especially embraces the duality of a preening cover boy and the sensitive type out to prove he has substance. It's an easy film to criticize, but why would you? It's meant to be harmless fun and bring joy to movie lovers. It's totally fine to make a silly formulaic movie when your objective is to make a silly formulaic movie.

Opening in theaters on March 25, 2022.

Title: Good fun
Review:
The Lost City is a lot of fun with some great acting and a lot of fun to be had. Channing Tatum and Sandra Bullock are brilliant at physical comedy and had some good chemistry on screen.

The story while very formulaic gave lots of room for the actors to do their thing on screen.

Daniel Radcliffe was brilliant as the villain and was genuinely hilarious in most of his scenes. It's nothing special but it's good fun.
